taxonomicNotes: This species is very similar in appearance to the sympatric Villosa choctawensis Athearn, 1964, so that the taxonomic status of this species requires verification (NatureServe 2010).

Seven subspecies are generally accepted (TTWG 2017):

Malaclemys terrapin terrapin (Schoepff, 1793) - Northern Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin centrata (Latreille in Sonnini and Latreille, 1801) - Carolina Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin littoralis Hay, 1905 - Texas Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin macrospilota Hay, 1905 - Ornate Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin pileata (Wied, 1865) - Mississippi Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin rhizophorarum Fowler, 1906 - Mangrove Diamondback Terrapin
Malaclemys terrapin tequesta Schwartz, 1955 - Eastern Florida Diamondback Terrapin

These subspecific designations of terrapins were based on morphological characteristics (Carr 1952). However, molecular studies indicate that the morphological subspecific designations do not match well with the range-wide genetic differentiation, suggesting fewer independent lineages. Lamb and Avise (1992) first suggested two subpopulations that diverged near Jacksonville, Florida. More recent work using microsatellites suggested that five genetically distinct terrapin management units exist throughout the range (Hart et al. 2014). One unfortunate consequence of the previous heavy trade and farming of terrapins was the transport of individuals among populations, and the genetic signature of those translocations can still be detected today (Hauswaldt and Glen 2005; Converse et al. 2017; Converse and Kuchta 2018). A more thorough range-wide molecular study using more populations and loci is sorely needed to resolve the phylogenetic relationships and update the taxonomy of Malaclemys.
There is currently a publication in review on the species delineation of Menidia conchorum and Menidia peninsulae (S. O'Leary pers. comm. 2013).
Halffter (1961) proposed three subspecies: C. indigaceus indigaceus, C. indigaceus chaipas and C. indigaceus chevrolati.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 32 (d'Orbigny 1913), which is widely distributed across the dry to moist savannas of the Afrotropical region.

Two other common and very similar species of western Atlantic Strongylura occur alongside Strongylura marina in the Western Central Atlantic: Strongylura notata and Strongylura timucu. Until the late 1960s, S. timucu was largely considered to be synonymous with S. marina (Berry and Rivas 1962). Collette (1968) notes that S. notata differs from S. marina and S. timucu in having fewer anal rays and fewer predorsal scales, and internal examination also reveals fewer vertebrae and other distinguishing skeletal features. Internal examination also reveals that both gonads are developed in S. tumucu while only the right gonad is developed in S. marina. Typically, S. timucu is also somewhat darker in coloration than S. marina (Hoese and Moore 1977). Strongylura notata differs externally from S. marina, possessing 13-15 dorsal rays and 13-16 anal rays (Hoese and Moore 1977).
This species was recently revised and S. ovale and S. nucleus spilt from S. corneum, hence the data will often be for the old concept of.S. corneum (Glöer and Meier-Brook 2003).

Genetic studies of Pagrus pagrus have shown Western Atlantic samples to be more closely related to each other than to samples from the Eastern North Atlantic. Within the Western North Atlantic, no significant population differentiation was observed, and within the eastern North Atlantic, only the Azores sample showed detectable differences from those from Crete and Madeira. These data indicate general homogeneity within large areas, and deep divisions between these areas (Ball et al. 2007).

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

The recent description of Papilio rumiko, which closely resembles this species, meant that many specimens previously identified as P. cresphontes have now been assigned to the new species P. rumiko, meaning that the overall distribution of cresphontes is now primarily restricted to North America, and its extent into Central America is unknown, but unlikely to reach beyond Mexico.
Limenitis archippus has numerous recognised subspecies: spp. archippus; spp. idaho; spp. iahontani; spp. obsoleta; spp. floridensis; spp. watsoni; and ssp. hoffmani (www.butterfliesofamerica.com).

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

The American Snout (Libytheana carinenta) has several subspecies: L. c. carinenta, L. c.mexicana, L. c. streckeri, L. c. larvata, and L. c. bachmanii (the Mexican Snout); the latter was formerly recognised as a separate species, Libytheana bachmanii (Warren et al. 2016).
This species is split into several subspecies across its range (Scott 1986).
Has previously been confused with Leucoraja garmani (McEachran and Carvalho 2002).

Records of eastern Atlantic Myliobatis aquila from southern Brazil probably refer to this species, if both species are indeed distinct (if not, the name M. aquila has priority). There are two sister species in the southern part of its range under the present name M. goodei, with a description of the second species pending (Ruocco et al. 2012).
The similar, but larger, Etmopterus bigelowi was previously confused with this species until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).

This species can be visually distinguished from two morphologically similar regional congeners, the Dusky Smoothhound (Mustelus canis) and the Gulf of Mexico Smoothhound (M. sinusmexicanus) by several characters including fin shape and ampullary pore patterns (Giresi et al. 2013).
The Bignose Shark is morphologically distinct but genetically similar to the Sandbar Shark (Carcharhinus plumbeus) (Naylor et al. 2012, Duffy and Struthers 2017).
Easily confused with the Southern Eagle Ray (Myliobatis goodei) (Last et al. 2016).

White et al. (2017) concluded that Mobula rochebrunei (East Atlantic Devilray) is a junior synonym of M. hypostoma (Atlantic Devilray), with the latter species being confirmed as occurring in both the Western and Eastern Atlantic.
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
Given its wide geographic distribution, this species may represent a species complex   (Reid and Jereb 2005).
Vecchione and Young (2007) believe this species may be synonymous with H. dispar.

Spirula's discontinuous distribution in the northern and southern hemisphere has led to suggestions that more than one species exists (e.g., Warnke 2007). Currently, this is the only species in the family Spirulidae.
The taxonomy of this genus remains unresolved   (Reid and Jereb 2005).

Reid and Jereb (2005) believe that subpopulations in the eastern and western Atlantic are probably isolated. In contrast, Vecchione and Young (2007) believe that this species may be synonymous with Heteroteuthis hawaiiensis (treated separately herein). Genetic data are required to solve these taxonomic issues.
Tetracheledone spinicirrus is the type species of the genus Tetracheledone by monotypy.

Idioctopus gracilipes Taki, 1962 is likely a junior synonym of Amphitretus pelagicus. Hochberg et al. (1992) suggest this on the basis of hectocotylised arm morphology. Voight (1997) places Idioctopodidae in synonymy of Amphitretidae based on additional characters. Until recently, A. thielei Robson, 1930 was considered to be a junior synonym of A. pelagicus, however O'Shea 1999 considers it to be a valid species.
This species closely resembles the sympatric Enoploteuthis jonesi in appearance (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
The species of this genus are poorly defined.
This moderate sized species of squid appears to consist of large, slender and small body types (Kubodera 2006). The taxonomic status of these morphs have not been assessed (Kubodera 2006).
The type locality is the Old Rhodes Key, Florida, Gulf of Mexico (Sweeney 2012).
This is the only species in the genus Cranchia.
This genus contains at least three species (Taonius borealis, Taonius pavo and Taonius belone) (Young and Mangold 2009), although Voss and co-workers (1992) suggest as many as five species may occur.
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.
This is the only member of the genus Grimalditeuthis.

D. gigas is a well defined species that cannot be confused with any other squid. Within its geographic range, however, there is great variation in the size and age at maturity and size frequency distribution. But there is no evidence at present (2009) that any subpopulations are genetically distinct although Nigmatullin et al. (2001) suggest that they may be separate stocks.
This is the only species in the family Joubiniteuthidae (Young 2008).
Currently three nominal taxa are recognised in the genus (Megalocranchia fisheri, M. maxima, M. oceanica), although Voss et al. (1992) suggest that six species may occur.

Following Young (2008), we herein treat Dorsopsis taningi Thore, 1949 and Eledonella heathi Berry, 1911 as junior synonyms of Japatella diaphana. The type locality of D. taningi is 13o31' N 18o03'W (off The Gambia), that of E. heathi is Albatross Station 4393 near San Diego, California, whilst that of the J. diaphana is north of Papua New Guinea (0o42'S 147oE). Molecular work may eventually show that Japatella comprises more than one species, but there is insufficient evidence currently to support this.

Thore (1949) moved to place V. alberti Joubin, 1924, V. ingeborgae Joubin, 1929 and V. translucida Robson, 1930 into the synonymy of V. richardi after examination of these and 113 specimens of various sizes caught during the Dana expeditions.
The type locality is in Puget Sound in the eastern North Pacific (Sweeney 2012).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.

This species was described as Grimpoteuthis tuftsi Voss and Pearcy 1990. It is known only from the type series of seven specimens all collected on the Tufts Abyssal Plain off Oregon, USA. The type locality is at 45°05.2'N, 134°43.4'W. O’Shea (1999) and O’Shea and Lu (2002) suggested that G. tuftsi should be included in Luteuthis, but we follow Collins and Villanueva (2006) and consider it a species of Grimpoteuthis. The Atlantic abyssal species G. challengeri Collins, 2003 is very similar. Both species possess a radula (Collins and Villanueva 2006), a feature that is generally absent in grimpoteuthid species, and may be closely related.
The type locality is Martinique, West Indies, western North Atlantic Ocean (Sweeney 2012).
It is similar in appearance to the Pacific Ocean species, Abralia similis (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).
This species is similar in appearance to Abralia redfieldi, Abralia similis and Abralia omiae but is recognisable by the extra photophores on the eye (Tsuchiya 2009).

Differences in morphology between paralarvae in the Atlantic and Pacific suggest more than one species exists (Young et al. 1992), however, currently not enough specimens from different regions are available for proper species-level comparisons (Vecchione and Young 2008). Thelidioteuthis alessandrini is the misidentified juvenile form of this species (Bello 1992).
This species now has precedence over Abraliopsis pfefferi which is now considered to be the junior synonym (Tsuchiya 2009).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

The sucker pattern of males is very similar to that of O. californiana and the two species could be synonymous, suggesting that an updated classification of Opisthoteuthis in the North Pacific is needed (Young and Vecchione 2003, Collins and Villanueva 2006).
This is currently the only species in the genus, however, Voss and co-workers (1992) suggest that it may in fact consist of 3-4 closely related species.

This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Type locality: Gulf of Mexico, United States, Florida, off Dry Tortugas and Tampa (Jereb et al. 2014).

The disjunct distribution and variable morphology of H. bonnellii specimens suggest several distinct populations occur. For example, based on spermatophore morphology three separate populations may occur in the Atlantic (i.e. Southwest Atlantic, Eastern Tropical Atlantic and Northwest Atlantic) (Young and Vecchione 2009).

Numerous species of Argonauta have been described. A full list is given by Mangold, Vecchione and Young (2008). Taxonomic work on this genus is required, but A. argo is undoubtedly a good species and is the type species of the genus. We treat A. pacifica (type locality California) as a junior synonym of A. argo (type locality Mediterranean Sea).
The type locality is given as "Brazil and Carolina strands" (Sweeney 2012).

The systematics of Tremoctopodidae was reviewed by Thomas (1977). He concluded that two species existed, T. violaceus, comprising the subspecies T. v. violaceus in the Atlantic Ocean and T. v. gracilis in the Pacific Ocean, and a new deep-water species T. gelatus Thomas, 1977.  O'Shea (1999) resurrected the New Zealand species, T. robsoni. Given that T. v. violaceus was no more different from T. robsoni than it was from T. v. gracilis, Mangold et al. (2008) elevated the two subspecies of T. violaceus to specific level.
The species of this genus are poorly defined.
It has been suggested that Abraliopsis felis is sufficiently different to be placed in its own subgenus, Boreabraliopsis (Young and Tsuchiya 2009).
This species may actually represent a species complex (Roper and Jereb 2010).
This species closely resembles the sympatric Enoploteuthis higginsi in appearance (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).

Although Ancistroteuthis is monotypic four geographic morphotypes have been described, however further specimens are required in order to investigate their taxonomic significance (Kubodera et al. 1998).

Grimpoteuthis megaptera (Verrill, 1885) was described from five specimens from the northwest Atlantic. Collins (2003) and Villanueva and Collins (2006) searched for these specimens. They were unable to locate four, which are now presumed lost. They identified the fifth specimen, which was small and damaged, as Cirrothauma murrayi Chun, 1911. They believe the larger specimen taken from abyssal depths (4,708 m), which was illustrated by Verrill (1885; Plate XLIII), is a Grimpoteuthis, but believe new material is required from the type locality to redescribe G. megaptera.

Members of Asperoteuthis can easily be misidentified as Grimalditeuthis if they have lost their tentacles (Young and Roper 2008).  Asperoteuthis acanthoderma, A. mangoldae, A. sp. B and A. lui and A. nesisi belong to the genus Asperoteuthis (Young and Roper 2008) but A. sp. B is probably a junior synonym of A. nesisi (Arkhipkin and Laptikhovsky 2008).
Jereb et al. (2014) deal with this species under 'Octopus' californicus.  No indication is given as to why it has been removed from Enteroctopus.
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Following Strugnell et al. (2009), we consider Benthoctopus macrophallus Voss and Pearcy 1990 (holotype USNM 730713 from 44º58'N 126º32'W) to be a junior synonym of this species.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognized as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

This species was redescribed by Toll (1981) who did not examine the lectotype.  Gleadall et al. (2004) examined the lectotype and Toll's specimens and concluded they were conspecific despite the considerable distance between their capture locations.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.
Muus (2002) proposed this as a new species, but also suggested that it might be a hybrid of B. arcticus and B. bairdii or might be a stunted form of B. bairdii.

Nesis (1993) has described a complex population structure for S. oualaniensis that incorporates three major and possibly two minor forms:
1. A giant form that occurs only in the northern Indian Ocean in the region of the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden and Arabian Sea (modal  sizes of 400-500 mm ML in the Arabian Sea, maximum size of 650 mm ML). It has the same type of gladius as no. 3 below.
2. A medium form (modal sizes of 120-150 mm for mature males and 190-250 mm for mature females) that occurs throughout most of the range of the species and has a gladius double lateral axes (stiffened ribs) of the rhachis.
3. A medium form but with a gladius having single lateral axes of  the rhachis. It occurs only in the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden and the Arabian Sea north of 15°-17°N.
4. A dwarf form (modal size of 90-100 mm ML for mature males and 90-120 mm ML for mature females, 140-150 mm ML maximum) that occurs in equatorial waters (roughly within 10°-20° latitude of the equator) of the Pacific and Indian Oceans and lacks the dorsal mantle photophore patch characteristic of the species.         
5.  A small form, similar to the medium form but maturing at a smaller size (mode for females is 120-140 mm with a range of 90-160 mm ML) that is nearly the same size as the dwarf form and is known from the Western Indian Ocean and the eastern tropical Pacific.

The genetic status of the different forms is unknown. The dwarf form is often thought to be a separate species but it has not been given a separate name and its separate specific status has not been proven.
Graneledone verrucosa is the type species of the genus Graneledone.

This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis agassizii species group that is based on morphological similarities (Vecchione et al. 2007). It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis agassizii, from tropical to temperate regions of the Atlantic; M. dentata, from tropical to temperate regions of the Indo-Pacific; and M. psychrophila from Southern Ocean (Young and Vecchione 2007). There are currently no reliable morphological differences to separate M. dentata from M. agassizii.

Until recently, Eogonatus tinro was only known from juvenile specimens, although it had been suggested that Gonatopsis okutanii might represent the adult form of this species.  Spent females of Gonatopsis okutanii were found to have possessed tentacles just prior to attaining maturity and spawning, which suggested it didn't belong to the genus Gonatopsis (Hochberg 2006), but might in fact represent adult Eogonatus tinro which has a similar distribution range.  This has been confirmed by Katugin et al. (2011) and we treat Gonatopsis okutanii as a junior synonym of Eogonatus tinro.

Ommastrephes bartramii has a cosmopolitan distribution in temperate to subtropical waters. However, genetic tests of populations in different oceans, to determine if gene flow occurs, have not been made.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
The type locality is South Carolina, western North Atlantic Ocean (Sweeney 2012).

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).
This species was recently redescribed by Collins and Henriques (2000).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
According to Young (1999), this genus may consist of four species (Discoteuthis discus, Discoteuthis laciniosa, Discoteuthis sp. A and Discoteuthis sp. B).
The type locality of this species is 32<sup>o</sup>05'N, 64<sup>o</sup>38'W, in the Sargasso Sea, off Bermuda (Sweeney 2012).
Abralia andamanica robsoni Grimp, 1931 is considered to be the junior synonym of Abralia andamanica (Tsuchiya 2009).
Muus (2002) removed this species from the genus Bathypolypus and placed it in the genus Benthoctopus. Jorgensen (2009) then renamed it under its own genus.

Numerous synonyms have been proposed including Alloposus mollis Verrill, 1880, Octopus alberti Joubin, 1895, Alloposus pacificus Ijima & Ikeda, 1902, Heptapus danai Joubin, 1929, Alloposus hardyi Robson, 1930 and Alloposina albatrossi Robson, 1931. Although the genus name is recognized as Haliphron, the correct family name is Alloposidae.

Earlier workers attribute the name to Solander. This attribution relates to an unpublished manuscript (which fails to meet Art. 8 and hence does not constitute a nomenclatural act) referred to in Lightfoot's (1786) sale catalogue. There is no description in the sale catalogue, but this also refers to Rumphius (1705). Although the latter predates the starting point for zoological nomenclature (Art. 3) the information therein may be referred to. Hence A. hians Lightfoot 1876 is a valid name. However, A. hians appears to be very variable in form and taxonomic work is required to delineate the species limits.  According to Jereb et al. (2014), Moolenbeek (2008) designated a neotype with type locality Ambon Indonesia.
This species may actually be a species complex (Voss et al. 1992).
Two species have been described in this genus, however, Cycloteuthis akimushkini is likely to be the junior synonym of Cycloteuthis serventi (Young 2009).
O. antillarum can be distinguished from its IndoPacific counterpart, O. volitalis only by the detailed structure of the male hectocotylus.
This species was redescribed by Muus (2002).
Although controversy exists over the validity of this species, recent genetic evidence suggests it is distinct and therefore a valid species (Mart ínez et al. 2005).
The taxonomic validity of this species is still in question, large individuals closely resemble Gonatus madokai and G. japonicus may represent the immature form of this species (Kubodera 2006).

According to Young (1999), this genus may consist of four species (Discoteuthis discus, Discoteuthis laciniosa, Discoteuthis sp. A and Discoteuthis sp. B), however, Discoteuthis sp. A may be the mature male of Discoteuthis discus.
Specimens from the North Atlantic may be misidentifications of Planctoteuthis lippula (Young and Roper 2008).
This species is similar to Abralia andamanica in appearance (Tsuchiya and Young 2009).

The systematics of the Architeuthis group is not well understood since many species have been described from single and often incomplete specimens (Roper 1998). Some authors believe three distinct species may exist based on differences in their geographic distribution: Architeuthis dux in the North Atlantic, A. martensi in the North Pacific and A. sanctipauli in the Southern Ocean (Roper 1998; Norman 2003).  However, we treat Architeuthis as comprising a single global species.
We consider Taningia persica, which is known only from the paralarval type material, to be a junior synonym of T. danae.

Four very similar species of Mastigoteuthis (M. agassizii, M. grimaldi, M. schmidti and M. flammea) have been described from the North Atlantic. These were recently synonomized, based partly on the MAR-ECO material, under M. agassizii (Young and Vecchione 2007).  Mastigoteuthis agassizii may itself consist of a temperate/boreal and a tropical form in the Atlantic, in which case M. flammea is the correct name for the tropical form (see Vecchione and Young 2007).  This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis agassizii species group that is based on morphological similarities (Vecchione et al. 2007). It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis agassizii, from tropical to temperate regions of the Atlantic; M. dentata, from tropical to temperate regions of the Indo-Pacific; and M. psychrophila from Southern Ocean (Young and Vecchione 2007).
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.
Hochberg (1998) synonymised Graneledone pacifica with G. boreopacifica but it is likely that both species are valid with G. boreopacifica having a shallower distribution.

O’Shea (1999) included Grimpoteuthis bathynectes Voss and Pearcy 1990 in his new genus, Enigmatiteuthis.  Enigmatiteuthis mainly differs from Grimpoteuthis in the form of the shell; however, following examination of specimens of G. bathynectes, Collins (2003) suggested it remain in Grimpoteuthis (Collins and Villanueva 2006).  Only one other species of Grimpoteuthis, G. hippocrepium (Hoyle, 1904) is known from the North Pacific Ocean.

This is an easily recognized species but it is a mesopelagic boundary species and therefore found in close association with land masses. As a result, the numerous "subpopulations" may have some genetic separation. DNA sequencing, however, has not been carried out.

This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis magna species group (Vecchione et al. 2007). It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis magna, in the Atlantic Ocean; M. microlucens, in the tropical Pacific Ocean; and an undescribed species from the subantarctic Pacific Ocean (Vecchione et al. 2007). Members of this group are distinctive and easily identified from other Mastigoteuthis species (Young and Vecchione 2007).
Following Young (2008), we treat Bolitaena microtyla Steenstrup in Hoyle, 1886 as a junior synonym of Bolitaena pygmaea.
The type locality is Martinique (Sweeney 2012).
The species of this genus are poorly defined.
This is the only species in the genus Bathothauma.

Molecular and morphological studies suggest that Onychoteuthis compacta and two other closely related species (O. prolatus and O. aequimanus) inhabit Hawaiian waters (Bonnaud et al. 1998; Kubodera et al. 1998).

Specimens from different regions of the Pacific show variation in the number and size arrangement of their tentacle-photophores compared to individuals from the Atlantic, therefore the taxonomic status of P. margaritifera is unresolved (Young and Mangold 1996).
The North Pacific subpopulation exhibits some different morphological features from its Atlantic counterpart and may prove to be genetically distinct (Young 1972).

It is possible that this family may consist of as many as five species (Magnapinna atlantica, North Atlantic; Magnapinna sp. B, North Atlantic; Magnapinna sp. C, South Atlantic; Magnapinna pacifica, North Pacific and North Atlantic; and Magnapinna talismani, North Atlantic) but requires further research and specimens (Vecchione and Young 2008).
Originally this species was believed to have a circumglobal distribution but (Vecchione et al. 2007) considered that these distribution records comprised more than one species.

Originally described from a single specimen as Opisthoteuthis agassizii Verrill 1883, this is the type species of the genus Opisthoteuthis. The type locality is off Grenada, Lesser Antilles, tropical Western North Atlantic, 535 m depth.
This species was removed from the genus Octopus sensu stricto by Norman and Hochberg (2005) but has not been placed in another genus. Its genetic affinity remains unclear.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus.  We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

Hochberg designated a neotype for this species (CASIZ 031369), redescribed the species based on material from Alaska to California and transferred it to Benthoctopus.  However, he did not examine the neotype he designated.

Numerous species of Argonauta have been described. A full list is given by Mangold, Vecchione and Young (2008). No type material has been located for A. boettgeri and the type locality was unknown ("Patria ignota") at the time of the description, however, the original description contained a clear illustration of the shell. Designation of a neotype might help stabilize nomenclature. The species is often seen spelt A. bottgeri, however the correct transliteration of the name Argonauta Böttgeri given in the original description is Argonauta boettgeri according to Article 32.5.2.1 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature.

This species has a complicated history entwined with that of Gonatus middendorffi. The latter was erected by Kubodera and Okutani (1981) who had declared Gonatus kamtschaticus nomen dubium on account of the poor description, lack of type material and limited use of its name.  However, Nesis considered G. middendorffi to be a junior synonym of G. kamtschaticus and re-elevated G. kamtschaticus to senior synonym.  We treat Gonatus middendorffi as junior synonym of G. kamtschaticus.

Large morphological interpopulation variability and differences in chromosome numbers suggest that several species may be confused under the name M. anguillicaudatus. Some populations from Viet Nam earlier identified as this species are in fact M. multimaculatus and M. tonkinensis.
The species limits are poorly defined with respect to other described taxa in this family, and they are in need of revision, and any change of status will require a revised conservation assessment.

Species formerly known under the genus Poecilophis are synonyms of the genus Echidna. Poecilophis tritor and Poecilophis pikei are synonyms of Echidna polyzona. In addition, Echidna leihala, Echidna obscura, Echidna psalion, Echidna sauvagel, Echidna vincta, Echidna zonata, and Echidna zonophaea are all considered synonyms of Echidna polyzona. Other synonyms also included under Echidna polyzona are Muraena dizona and Muraena fascigula.
This species may be part of a complex of similar species (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
Some authors have placed this species in the genus Pleuranacanthus (Su and Li 2002).

Archosargus probatocephalus is subdivided into three subspecies by some authors: A. probatocephalus probatocephalus for the northern form from Nova Scotia to Cedar Key on the west coast of Florida; A. probatocephalus oviceps Ginsburg (which is associated with muddy bottoms) in the Gulf of Mexico from St. Harks, Florida to the Campeche Bank; and A. probatocephalus aries from Belize to Bahia de Sepetiba, Brazil (Carpenter 2002).

The Chesapeake Bay Sheepshead population is suggested to constitute a separate population, as large differences in vital rates are often indicative of this. The differences observed in growth could arise due to a variety of factors, including differences in mortality rates, environmental conditions, food sources, or genetic variation (Ballenger et al. 2007).

Frequency distributions of each of five meristic counts are significantly different between the subspecies found in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico: A. probatocephalus probatocephalus and A. probatocephalus oviceps (P < 0.05). However, Bayesian structure analysis of microsatellite genotypes indicated that all Gulf of Mexico Sheepshead populations constitute a single stock.Variance partitioning of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) haplotypes suggests significant but limited divergence between subspecies (genetic differentiation index FST = 0.036, P < 0.005). Molecular data from North American subspecies of  Sheepshead indicate very limited genetic subdivision between the subspecies despite considerable divergence of morphological characters. Genetic structure is defined primarily by the geographic distance between sampling locales from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic. Overall, Sheepshead molecular genetic data indicate very limited genetic subdivision between the subspecies despite considerable divergence of morphological characters (Anderson et al. 2008).

The ellipse has been treated as three separate species (Ortmann 1918) or as one species with two subspecies (Oesch 1984, 1995). Today, two species are recognized (Turgeon et al. 1998), the ellipse, Venustaconcha ellipsiformis (Conrad 1836) in the upper Midwest south through the Ozarks and the bleedingtooth mussel, Venustaconcha pleasii (Marsh, 1891) limited to the White River basin of the Ozarks (Riusech 2000, Barnhart 2001). Recent pylogenetic analysis of the subfamily Ambleminae confirms this. Venustaconcha ellipsiformis is a member of the Tribe Lampsilini, but it did not group closely with species with similar mantle flap morphology such as Lampsilis cardium, Lampsilis higginsii, Lampsilis siliquoidea, and Ligumia recta (Campbell et al. 2005; Allen et al. 2007). It was formerly placed in the genera Unio, Lampsilis, Nephronaias, Eurynia, Ligumia, and Actinonaias.  It is also known under the name Unio venustus (Lea, 1838) and Unio spatulatus (Lea, 1845).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site  (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Recently, Oesch (1984, 1995) introduced the combination Pleurobema sintoxia (Rafinesque, 1820) as the senior synonym of Pleurobema coccineum (Conrad, 1836). Oesch did not provide any discussion or justification in resurrecting the Rafinesque name, but did include several morphological forms on the basis of habitat (Pleurobema coccineum form coccineum = headwater streams, Pleurobema coccineum form catillus = medium rivers, Pleurobema coccineum form solida = big rivers).

The members of the genus Pleurobema are among the most difficult to identify in North America. Arguments arise even among taxonomists regarding the "species" represented in the genus Pleurobema. Stansbery (1983) summarized many of the problems and identified a few of the shell characters used to separate Pleurobema sintoxia from the morphologically similar and often co-occurring Pleurobema plenum, Pleurobema cordatum, and Pleurobema rubrum. A few "morphs" have been variously identified and named but no rigorous genetic, anatomic, or conchologic study has ever been published on this group to help elucidate species boundaries or relationships.

Another important synonym of the species is Pleurobema catillus (Conrad, 1836). A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

There is much taxonomic confusion associated with southern and eastern forms of this genus. Dozens of forms of this character-poor genus have been described. This species was overlooked as a synonym in the synonomies of both Uniomerus obesus (Lea, 1831) by Clench and Turner (1956), and of Uniomerus tetralasmus (Say, 1831) by Johnson (1972). Fuller (1972) stated that it "had best be considered a nomen dubium" based on the very brief description, lack of type specimens, an ambiguous figure, and high potential for confusion with Elliptio complanata (Lightfoot, 1786). However, Morrison (1976), who had once considered it a synonym of E. complanata, considered this species valid based on its habitat, which was described in the original description, and quoted from Morrison (1976) as being "found living in mud which was dried so hard it could not be broken with a spade...any species found in such a habitat could only be a member of the genus Uniomerus". With this in mind, Uniomerus carolinana should be considered a valid taxon. This species has been recognized in recent works by Heard (1979), Turgeon et al. (1998), Butler (1989) and Graf and Cummings (2007).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

There is much taxonomic confusion associated with southern and eastern forms of this genus. Dozens of forms of this character-poor genus have been described. Uniomerus declivis was included in the synonomies of both Uniomerus obesus (Lea, 1831) by Clench and Turner (1956), and of Uniomerus tetralasmus (Say 1831) by Johnson (1972) and Simpson (1914). Clench and Turner (1956) erroneously stated it as Unio declivis Conrad (1836), not Unio declivis Say (1831). It is recognized as a distinct species by Morrison (1976), Heard (1979), and Turgeon et al. (1998). Johnson (1999) questions whether Uniomerus declivis is merely a phenotypic variant of Uniomerus tetralasmus. This species is also known under Unio camptodon (Say, 1829) and Unio budianus (Lea, 1841).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site  (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species was moved from the genus Quincuncina to Fusconaia (Williams et al. 2008).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Based on mitochondrial and nuclear DNA sequences, Zarza et al. (2008) suggested that the southern portion of the distribution of Ctenosaura pectinata belongs to the Ctenosaura acanthura clade. However, with a more complete and inclusive analysis, the limits of the distribution of both species is maintained as previously known, where C. acanthura is located north of the Tehuantepec Isthmus and C. pectinata to the south (Zarza et al. 2019). Additionally, the authors suggest this species should be split based on three different molecular and geographically concordant clades. The name Ctenosaura brachylopha can be resurrected to name northeastearn populations (originally described by Bailey 1928). Ctenosaura pectinata will remain for the central and eastern populations, and a new species will be described for the southern populations with further morphological data in progress. For the time being, the assessment of the species considers the standing taxonomy for C. pectinata, and evaluates its status throughout the entire distribution.

The systematics of Tremoctopodidae was reviewed by Thomas (1977). He concluded that two species existed, T. violaceus, comprising the subspecies T. v. violaceus in the Atlantic Ocean and T. v. gracilis in the Pacific Ocean, and a new deep-water species T. gelatus Thomas, 1977.  O'Shea (1999) resurrected the New Zealand species, T. robsoni. Given that T. v. violaceus was no more different from T. robsoni than it was from T. v. gracilis, Mangold et al. (2008) elevated the two subspecies of T. violaceus to specific level.

The systematics of Tremoctopodidae was reviewed by Thomas (1977). He concluded that two species existed, T. violaceus, comprising the subspecies T. v. violaceus in the Atlantic Ocean and T. v. gracilis in the Pacific Ocean, and a new deep-water species T. gelatus Thomas, 1977.  O'Shea (1999) resurrected the New Zealand species, T. robsoni. Given that T. v. violaceus was no more different from T. robsoni than it was from T. v. gracilis, Mangold et al. (2008) elevated the two subspecies of T. violaceus to specific level.

Members of Asperoteuthis can easily be misidentified as Grimalditeuthis if they have lost their tentacles (Young and Roper 2008). Asperoteuthis acanthoderma, A. mangoldae, A. sp. B and A. lui and A. nesisi belong to the genus Asperoteuthis (Young and Roper 2008) but A. sp. B is probably a junior synonym of A. nesisi (Arkhipkin and Laptikhovsky 2008).
Given its wide geographic distribution and morphological variation between regions it is likely that more than one species is present (Roper and Young 1999).

Recently two subspecies have been described. Berryteuthis magister nipponensis occurs in the waters around northern Japan, and B. magister shevtsovi occurs in the Sea of Japan between 200 and 600m in depth (Kubodera 2006a; Kubodera 2006b).
Unfortunately, identification problems with this species mean that it is not clear which records are valid.
This is one of the most taxonomically confused families of squid.

Subspecies:
C. calyptratus calcarifer Peters, 1871.

Bogan and Pierson (1993) recommended that Pleurocera prasinata, P. vestita, P. foremani, P. showalteri and P. annuliferum should be compared to see if these species are actually clinal variants of the same species. However, this has not been peer reviewed. Based on unpublished molecular data, P. foremani should be recognized as Elimia foremani. For this assessment, we follow the current taxonomy of P. foremani as a valid species.

Jackiewicz (1998) states that there are several problems concerning the nomenclature of the family Lymnaeidae, and that there is probably no other snail group in such taxonomical disarray. Stagnicola has been used as a synonym for Lymnaea by various authors, and as a subgenus of Lymnaea by others (Ponder and Waterhouse 1997, Vinarski 2003, NatureServe 2009). Hovingh (1993) lists this species as Lymnaea (Stagnicola) pilsbryi, whereas NatureServe (2009) name it Stagnicola pilsbryi. Dillon (2009) suggests that Lymnaea pilsbryi is a synonym of Lymnaea humilis, but this is neither supported or denied in other literature. Stagnicola is used by Turgeon et al. (1998) in the most recent list. However, Hubendick (1951) used Lymnaea. For the purpose of this assessment, we follow the taxonomy used by NatureServe.
Naso lituratus was observed to be actively hybriding with N. elegans at Cocos-Keeling (J.H. Choat pers. comm. 2010, Klanten 2003).
There was a significant level of genetic structure observed between North and South Atlantic populations, suggesting limited dispersal across the Amazon barrier (Rocha et al. 2002).

This species is a member of the Acanthurus achilles species complex known for their propensity to hybridize (Randall and Frische 2000). The four species in this complex (A. achilles Shaw, A. japonicus Schmidt, A. leucosternon Bennett, and A. nigricans Linnaeus) are thought to hybridize when their distributional ranges overlap (Craig 2008).
There is strong geographical pattern in the genetic structure of Acanthurus triostegus throughout the tropical Pacific but this does not warrant species recognition (Planes and Fauvelot 2002).

Acanthurus nigricans is a member of the A. achilles species complex known for their propensity to hybridize (Randall and Frische 2000). The four species in this complex (A. achilles Shaw, A. japonicus Schmidt, A. leucosternon Bennett, and A. nigricans) are thought to hybridize when their distributional ranges overlap (Craig 2008). Hybrids have been recorded from the Hawaiian Islands (Acanthurus achilles x nigricans), Taiwan (Acanthurus japonicus x nigricans), Indonesia, Christmas and Cocos Island (Acanthurus leucosternon x nigricans) (Randall 2001a, Marie et al. 2007).

Naso unicornis is widespread throughout the Indo-Pacific region, genetic studies conducted by Horne et al. (2008) did not find any evidence of geographic population structure even at the largest spatial scales.

Naso brevirostris is widespread throughout the Indo-Pacific region, genetic studies conducted by Horne et al. (2008) did not find any evidence of geographic population structure even at the largest spatial scales.
This species hybridizes with Acanthurus nigricauda in the Marshall Is. and A. tennentii in Bali (Randall 2001a).

Acanthurus nigroris is an endemic species in the Hawaiian Islands and Johnston Atoll,  Acanthurus nigros is valid for the species elsewhere in Oceania and the Great Barrier Reef. The genetic analyses, based on mtDNA cytochrome b sequences from a total of 544 Acanthurus nigroris samples, revealed a clear separation (d = 0.041) between individuals from the Hawaiian Archipelago and the rest of the Pacific indicating a cryptic species pair (Randall et al. submitted manuscript, DiBattista et al. 2011).
Zebrasoma rostratum hybridizes with Z. scopas. Taxonomic status is unkown (L. Rocha pers comm. 2010).

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid.

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid. Victor (2013) provides a taxonomic revision of this species.

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid.
A synonym for this species is Platyperona rowei.
This species can hybridize with Holothuria mexicana. The hybrids are viable and difficult to differentiate.
This species may also be known as Holothuria ludwigi.
This species was known as Stichopus variegatus (Rasolofonirina pers comm. 2010), which is now synonomized under S. horrens.
Halodeima surinamensis and Semperothuria surinamensis may be other names for this species.
This species is also known as Pseudostichopus atlanticus in the literature (Hansson 2001, Briggs 1985).
This species is often mistaken for Holothuria arenicola.

Clark, H.L. (1922) erected the genus Parastichopus with as main characteristic the presence of Thelenota-like dichotomous branching rods. This is a characteristic of the species regalis and tremulus. According to this fact, Rowe (unpublished data) put regalis and tremulus in the genus Parastichopus, in contrast to Cutress & Miller (1982), who included regalis in the genus Eostichopus.


Eostichopus regalis (Cuvier, 1817)
Gastrothuria limbata R. Perrier, 1899 (synonym)
Holothuria columnae Cuvier, 1817 (synonym)
Holothuria regalis Cuvier, 1817 (synonym)
Holothuria triquetra Delle Chiaje, 1841 (synonym)
Stichopus regalis (Cuvier, 1817) (synonym)

[Most of the information for this account comes from publications dealing with Stichopus regalis]
This species is also known as Sticopus macroparentheses.
Uthicke et al. (2004) by genetic analysis differentiated H. whitmaei, H. fuscogilva and H. nobilis, which were previously confused.
The taxonomy for this species is debated between the Atlantic and Pacific distributions (Hansen, 1956).
There are a few different morphs in the Africa and Indian Ocean region (Conand 2008) which may make correct identification of the species difficult.
There are two subspecies of Actinopyga obesa, entitled A. obesa obesa and A. obesa palauensi.

A critical review is needed, as there is some confusion with B. marmorata and B. tenuissima (Rasolofonirina pers. comm. 2010).

This species may be confused with B. subrubra (Conand 2008). Samyn et al. (2006) consider B. similis and B. vitiensis as synonyms of B. marmorata. Conand (2008) recommends the taxonomic revision of the whole genus Bohadschia.

A taxonomic review is in progress (Uthicke et al. 2010, and Byrne et al. 2010).

Conand (2008) suggests a taxonomic revision of S. monotuberculatus. In Réunion it was formerly known as S. horrens.
This species is recognized as Parastichopus parvimensis or Apostichopus parvimensis.
This species may warrant a taxonomic revision (Alvarado pers. comm. 2010).
Bathyplotes bipartitus, Stichopus pourtalessi are synonyms of this species (WORMS database).
This species is sometimes confused with Holothuria cubana (Deichmann 1930).
This species may also be known as Holothuria triremis.
This species used to be called Holothuria axiloga.

There are two morphs (one is smaller by the coast that asexually reproduces, and another which is larger in outer reefs with no asexual reproduction) that were found to be genetically identical (Uthicke et al. 2010).
Holothuria californica, Stichopus californicus, and Stichopus johnsonni may be synonyms for this species. Was previously confused with S. fuscus.
The Holothuria arenicola reported for the Caribbean may be a different species (Samyn et al. 2006). Current status of this species is likely to be a complex and taxonomic revision is needed.
Uthicke et al. (2004), by genetic analysis, differentiated H. whitmaei, H. fuscogilva and H. nobilis, which were previously confused.
Fossothuria rigida may be another name for this species.

Bathyplotes assimilis, Bathyplotes heterotilydes, Bathyplotes moseleyi, Bathyplotes ostergreni, Bathyplotes papillosus, Bathyplotes patagiatus, Holothuria natans, and Stichopus moseleyi are synonyms for this species (WORMs database). It can be confused with Bathyplotes fallax and with Bathyplotes pouratalesii. A taxonomic revision of this species is recommended (Borrero-Perez et al. 2003).
Synonyms for this species are Zygothuria lactea, Holothuria lactea, and H. aspera.
This species is easily confused with Holothuria surinamensis.
This species is also known as Stichopus cylindricus and Stichopus hirotai .
There is a taxonomic review in process (Uthicke et al. 2010, Byrne et al. 2010).
Fossothuria cubana is a synonym of this species (Quinones 1981).
Synonyms for this species include Holothuria stellati dakarensis (Pawson et al. 2010).
Synonyms for this species are Fistularia mollis, Holothuria intestinalis, and Thyonidium scabrum.
This species may also be known as Theelothuria princeps. The synonym with H. imperator needs to be reviewed to see if they are different species.

This species has previously been identified as Gerres simillimus, however, G. simillimus occurs in the eastern Pacific (Robertson 2006) and Gerres cinereus in the western Atlantic is considered a distinct species.
Bithynia combines the two subgenera Gabbia and Digoniostoma. B. pygmaea belongs to the subgenera Gabbia.
Western Atlantic subpopulations are now recognized as a separate species (Ophioblennius macclurei).
Phylogenetic analysis has placed this species within the genus Eucinostomus (Chen et al. 2007).
This may be a species complex of several species.
Evermannichthys spongicola (Radcliffe, 1917) is a valid species that is present in the Western Central Atlantic (previously known as Garmannia spongicola).
This species is very visually similar to G. brasilliensis, and they are often confused.

A revision of the Acyrtops genus is currently under way. Due to questions surrounding the validity of Acyrtops amplicirrus (a very similar species), the distribution of A. beryllinus is not clearly understood at this time (K. Conway pers. comm. 2015).
There are known taxonomic issues with this species; more than one undescribed species may be masquerading as A. quadrisquamatus.

There is some confusion surrounding the validity of this name, some workers consider Arcos nudus to be correct (replacing A. macrophthalmus), while Gobiesox cephalus should be applied to the western central Atlantic freshwater clingfish currently known as Gobiesox nudus (R. Robertson and K. Conway pers. comm. 2014).
Records outside of Brazil for A. tajasica may refer A. banana.
This species is easily confused with Coryphopterus glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae.

This species is sometimes misidentified as Coryphopterus tortugae or C. venezuelae. Furthermore, although genetically distinct, C. glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae are extremely similar (Baldwin et al. 2009).
This species is easily confused with Coryphopterus hyalinus. Coryphopterus hyalinus and C. personatus are genetically distinct (Baldwin et al. 2009).
Older records of Coryphopterus in the western Atlantic may need to be verified as the genus has recently been revised (Baldwin et al. 2009).
Older records of Coryphopterus in the western Atlantic may need to be verified as the genus has recently been revised (Baldwin et al. 2009).
This species has been confused with C. fasciatus (Gilbert and Randall in Gilbert and Kelso 1971).
This species has been confused with Ctenogobius pseudofasciatus in the past (Gilbert and Randall 1979).
Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera, Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus macrodon.
Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera: Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus saucrus.
Elacatinus lobeli was previously misidentified as E. oceanops (Randall and Colin 2009).

This species is found in three colour morphs, a yellow-blue, a yellow and a white form which may represent three separate species (Colin 2010). The very similar cryptic species E. cayman has been confused with this species (Victor 2014).

Unfortunately, members of the Eucinostomus genus are continually being misidentified. This species was once thought to occur in the eastern Pacific Ocean, but these specimens are now treated as E. dowii (Page et al. 2013). It may be conspecific with E. jonesi (Lee et al. 1980).
The name Eugerres awlae, which was once a synonym of E. plumieri, may be a different species. However, there is still some confusion on the validity and range of E. awlae.
The Atlantic and Pacific subpopulations are probably different species (M. Craig pers. comm. 2011).
This species is easily misidentified as Gobiosoma bosc.
Some references treat the genus Lipogramma as neuter.
Some references treat the genus Lipogramma as neuter.
Some references treat the genus Lipogramma as neuter.
This genus is currently being studied using molecular techniques and many  additional species are likely to be described and valid species may be  redefined.
This genus is currently being studied using molecular techniques and many  additional species are likely to be described and valid species may be  redefined.
This genus is currently being studied using molecular techniques and many  additional species are likely to be described and valid species may be  redefined.
This genus is currently being studied using molecular techniques and many  additional species are likely to be described and valid species may be  redefined.
This was formerly regarded as a species of Gobionellus. It is now know as the only species of Oxyurichthys in the Atlantic Ocean (Pezold and Larson 2015).
The species is valid. One of the paratypes (the cleared and stained one) may be a different species (J. Van Tassell pers. comm. 2011).

Taxonomic relations between P. helenae and P. randalli need further clarification with sampling and barcoding of specimens from a range of sites in the Greater Caribbean (R. Robertson and B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2015).

The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex, and under revision (Durand and Borsa 2015). This species is commonly referred to as Valamugil seheli in the literature. According to Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes, it is now valid as Crenimugil seheli.

Hoplias malabaricus undoubtedly comprises a species complex (Hauser and Benedito 2012, Aguirre et al. 2013, Marques et al. 2013, Mattox et al. 2014, Grassi et al. 2017). As cryptic diversity becomes more clear, formal descriptions at the species level may result in a non-genuine change in the distribution of the species.
The Brazilian population is genetically distinct and is being described as a different species by a Brazilian group (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010).
Stegastes partitus shows weak genetic differentiation across the entire Caribbean basin (Hogan et al. 2012).

Rivas (1960) considered Stegastes otophorus (Poey 1860) a junior synonym of S. leucostictus (Müller & Troschel 1848), but Topp (1970) redescribed S. otophorus as a valid species (Garrido and Varela 2011) and both species are considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer 2015).
The eastern Atlantic population is genetically distinct from that in the western Atlantic, but the distinction is below the species level (Rocha et al. 2008).

Other important synonyms include Unio zigzag (Lea, 1829).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species was incorrectly listed as Planorbella armigera in Turgeon et al. (1988) and corrected in the appendix of Turgeon et al. (1998). A phylogenetic  study by Jung (1992) found that Planorbula respresents a distinct clade. Genetic examination of the molecular phylogeny of global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American taxa within the subfamily Planorbinae form a well-supported clade, as yet unnamed, but termed C-Clade (Albrecht et al. 2007).

Clench and Turner (1956) recognized the subspecies Lampsilis anodontoides floridensis (Lea 1852) (= teres floridensis) in the east Gulf drainages, separating it from typical Lampsilis anodontoides (= teres) by its smaller size and thinner shell. However, specimens from the Hillsborough River, the southernmost record for Lampsilis, become very large (up to 13.7 cm long) and somewhat thickened. Johnson (1970) recognized L. anodontoides. Johnson (1972), Heard (1979), and Turgeon et al. (1998) recognized L. teres. Oesch (1984) recognized both as distinct species. This taxon is in need of taxonomic verification to determine if there are multiple forms. More recently, Turgeon et al. (1998) recognized only L. teres and Parmalee and Bogan (1998) synonymized L. teres anodontoides and L. teres fallaciosa under Lampsilis teres. L.  floridensis has been elevated from the synonymy of L. teres based on shell morphology and genetic analysis (Williams et al. 2008). As a result, occurrences of what were formerly attributed to L. teres from the Tampa Bay drainages of Florida west to the Escambia River drainage in Alabama and Florida are now considered L. floridensis. Because conchological differences exhibited by the putative three subspecies of L. teres (L. teres teres, L. teres anadontoides and L. teres fallasciosa) appear to represent ecophenotypic variation the subspecies are not recognised by Turgeon et al. (1998) or Williams et al. (2008).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site  (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Van der Schalie (1940) did not recognize this species from the Chipola River drainage. It appears his records of Carunculina vesicularis and some collections of Carunculina minor may be Villosa villosa, especially since one of his collections in the MCZ and several in the UMMZ were re-identified by Brim Box and Williams (2000) as V. villosa. Curiously, neither Clench and Turner (1956) nor Johnson (1970, 1972) noted that van der Schalie had overlooked this species from the Chipola River Basin. In addition, the series of historic lots from the Choctawhatchee River appear to be distinct from eastern populations. The entire genus is in need of thorough genetic studies to determine taxonomic validation of the many described and undescribed forms. Villosa villosa has also been confused with the conchologically similar Villosa vibex and Hamiota subangulata. This species is also known as Lampsilis (Villosa) wrightiana (Frierson, 1927).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

It has been suggested that multiple existing taxa (montanensis, idahoensis and apicina) are synonyms of Stagnicola catascopium. However, NatureServe and other recent authors consider them separate taxa (Stagliano et al. 2007).

There are two recognised subspecies of S. catascopium:
Stagnicola catascopium catascopium (Say, 1867) Across North America below the tree line and south in the US to about 40 degrees N.
Stagnicola catascopium preblei (Dall, 1905) from northern Saskatchewan, northern Manitoba, Nelson, and the churchill river systems in Canada.Stagnicola catascopium nasoni (Baker 1906) from the Great Lakes, from Lake Superior to western Lake Ontario, Lake Geneva, Wisconsin, Rainy River system and Lake of the Woods (Clark 1981).

This species was placed in the newly elevated genus Pyganodon by Hoeh (1990). Recently, Zanatta et al. (2007) supported the monophyly of both Pyganodon and Utterbackia using mutation coding of allozyme data, but also resolved the Eurasian Anodonta cygnea to Pyganodon, Utterbackia, and North American Anodonta; indicating futher phylogenetic analysis of the Anodontinae is required including both North American and Eurasian species.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species is not found in Graf and Cummings (2007), but is listed on the Mussel Project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species was considered by some a trinomial form (subspecies) (see Clarke 1981). Pyganodon fragilis, Pyganodon cataracta, and Pyganodon marginata have been found to intergrade which confuses identifications.  Hoeh (1990) split Anodonta cataracta cataracta and Anodonta cataracta fragilis into distinct species (elevating Pyganodon to genus level in the process). Also Hoeh and Burch (1989) separated Anodonta lacustris as a valid species from Anodonta grandis and Anodonta cataracta and Hoeh (1990) placed them in Pyganodon as Anodonta marginata sensu strictu, is considered a nomen dubium (see Hoeh and Burch 1989). Although Hoeh (1990) indicated both Pyganodon fragilis and Pyganodon cataracta are distinct species and are unlikely to hybridize, potential hybridization still remains a possibility as traditional methods of distinguishing the two species (stomach anatomy, shell morphology, beak sculpture- when present) have proven unreliable (Hanlon and Smith 1999). Both spring and fall-breeding populations exist in the Avalon River in Newfoundland, thus genetic testing is required to determine if these are morphs or sibling species (Metcalfe-Smith and Cudmore-Vokey 2004). Recently, Zanatta et al. (2007) supported the monophyly of both Pyganodon and Utterbackia using mutation coding of allozyme data, but also resolved the Eurasian Anodonta cygnea to Pyganodon, Utterbackia, and North American Anodonta; indicating further phylogenetic analysis of the Anodontinae is required including both North American and Eurasian species. Recently, Cyr et al. (2007) found male and female mitochondrial genomes as well as morphology support the distinction between Pyganodon fragilis and Pyganodon cataracta (with likely a recent and possibly incomplete separation) although separation of the species morphologically is difficult due to hybridization, plastic shell characters, and morphological features not always present (such as beak sculpture).
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site  (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Due to a lack of recent taxonomic work on North American Pleuroceridae, it is likely that many classifications are invalid. For example, this species is likely to be an ecophenotypic variant of Goniobasis clavaeformis (R. Dillon pers. comm. 2009).
This species does not appear to be valid as it is not mentioned in Hershler et al. (1990).

Recently, Zanatta et al. (2007) supported the monophyly of both Pyganodon and Utterbackia using mutation coding of allozyme data, but also resolved the Eurasian Anodonta cygnea to Pyganodon, Utterbackia, and North American Anodonta; indicating futher phylogenetic analysis of the Anodontinae is required including both North American and Eurasian species.
This species is also known under Anodonta imbecillis (Say, 1829) and Anodonta henryana (Lea, 1857). It is also often mispelt as imbecilis.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This may be part of a species complex and may be more than one species. Dillon et al. (2006) include Elimia symmetrica from South Carolina as a synonym of Elimia proxima. Dillon and Davis (1980) recognized three races of Goniobasis (= Elimia) proxima, which they included as senior synonym of Elimia symmetrica: Race A being the typical form found in the mountains and foothills, Race B inhabiting harder waters, and Race C inhabiting streams of lower flow in the eastern piedmont. All the South Carolina populations appear to be typical race-A (Dillon et al. 2006). Dawley (1965) notes similar confusion with Elimia symmetrica.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Proptera which was widely used in the 1950s and 1960s. A recent ruling published in the Bulletin of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN 1992) recommended retention of the older name Potamilus. In an analysis of systematic relationships of species in the genus Potamilus using DNA sequence data, Roe and Lydeard (1998) concluded that Potamilus is paraphyletic with Leptodea fragilis and Lampsilis ornata nested between Potamilus capax and the remaining Potamilus species (all of which appeared to be monophyletic).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species was previously known as Carunculina parva (White & White 1997), Lampsilis parva, (Vaughn et al. 1996) and Lampsilis (Carunculina) parva (Barnes 1823). Recent spelling change from Toxolasma parvus to T. parvum, following review by Lee (2006).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
Taxonomically this species may belong to another genus other than Erinna, as the lymnaeids of Hawaii are desperately in need of taxonomic revision and surveys (S. Clark pers. comm. 2011).
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site  (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The entire genus is in need of thorough genetic studies to determine taxonomic validation of the many described and undescribed forms.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

According to Clarke (1981), Alasmidonta triangulata is a synonym of Alasmidonta undulata. It is treated as a distinct species by Johnson (1970), Clench and Turner (1956), Brim Box and Williams (2000) and retained in the 1998 American Fisheries Society Publication (Turgeon et al. 1998); the species is in need of genetic determination.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The spelling Toxolasma lividus formerly followed Turgeon et al. (1998). When the genus name Toxolasma was proposed by Rafinesque (1831), he did not designate a gender nor was it clear from the species included in the genus. A recent review of Toxolasma (Lee 2006) determined the gender is neuter and endings of four species have changed: Toxolasma lividus to lividum; Toxolasma parvus to parvum; Toxolasma paulus to paulum; and Toxolasma texasensis to texasense. Through misinterpretations of species identities and synonomy, Toxolasma has been considered to contain two to eight species (e.g., Johnson 1970, Burch 1975, Turgeon et al. 1988, Turgeon et al. 1998). Examination of museum vouchers indicate that there may be as many as fifteen species. These recent publications have been little more than species lists and present no explanation for the synonomies. The last such work to do so was Ortmann and Walker (1922) which mistakenly synonymized Toxolasma lividus under Carunculina moesta (Lea, 1841). In recent works, C. moesta has been interpreted as a junior synonym of Carunculina glans (Lea, 1834). However, Pilsbry and Rhoads (1896), Ortmann (1918), and Ortmann and Walker (1922) indicate that lividus and glans are not the same shell and probably represent different species. Williams et al. (2008), however, noted that there appears to be little evidence to support recognition of two subspecies.

The species is now considered likely to be a synonym of Toxolasma glans, although this still requires verification (J. Cordeiro pers. comm. 2011). As such, we follow the current taxonomic standing of Toxolasma lividium for the purpose of this assessment, until further taxonomic work suggests otherwise.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The combination Lampsilis radiata luteola has been used incorrectly in place of Lampsilis siliquoidea and resulted in some confusion. For example, Lampsilis radiata luteola cited in Oesch (1984, 1995) is actually Lampsilis siliquoidea but the two names are not considered synonyms nor is siliquoidea considered a form or subspecies of radiata. Unio (= Lampsilis) luteola, previously confined to the Susquehanna and Mohawk Rivers (Johnson 1969), falls within the overall range of and is considered a junior synonym of Lampsilis radiata and not as a senior synonym of Lampsilis siliquoidea (see Turgeon et al. 1998).

Note that Watters et al. (2009) conclude that Unio siliquoidea Barnes, 1823, is a junior synonym of Unio luteola Lamarck, 1819, that intergraded with Lampsilis radiata radiata in northern New York in the Finger Lakes, Erie Canal, Mohawk, and upper Susquehanna Rivers; and therefore synonymize Lampsilis siliquoidea with Lampsilis radiata as a subspecies- Lampsilis radiata luteola.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The ICZN (1999, opinion 1896) fixed Buccinum truncatulum Muller, 1774 as the type species of the nominal genus Galba Schrank, 1803; it also placed Galba Schrank, 1803 on the Official List of Species Names in Zoology, thereby replacing the current usage of the name Fossaria Westerlund, 1885, which now a junior objective synonym. 

In Europe Falkner et al. (2001) use Galba based on ICZN opinion 1896, whereas in North American Fossaria was used for this genus (Turgeon et al., 1998).  The latest publication on the conservation status of the North America Gastropods (Johnson et al., 2013) used Galba for the genus in North America, thus the IUCN Red List is now following this convention and all species previously recognised as Fossaria are now in genus Galba.
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site  (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Phreatodrobia nugax was originally thought to be a subspecies of P. micra, but has now been described as a seperate species. There is still debate over the true taxonomy of this species (Fullington 1978). Two subspecies of this species exist - P. nugax nugax and P. nugax inclinata, the latter of which is only known from one locality at Longhorn Portland Cement Company Well (Hershler and Longley 1986).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. Johnson (1970) considered Elliptio roanokensis a synonym of Elliptio complanata. E. roanokensis is a distinct, large freshwater mussel with branched papillae. NC Wildlife Resources Commission (NCWRC) field experience indicates that what had been called Elliptio judithae from the Neuse drainage is a synonym of Elliptio roanokensis. This view has been tentatively supported by other malacologists (Art Bogan, North Carolina State Museum; John Alderman, North Carolina Resource Commission) based on conchological and soft-tissue features. Clarke (1986) described Elliptio judithae from the Neuse River, but his description of the species matched that of smaller individuals of Elliptio roanokensis (Adams et al. 1990).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
This species is also known as Unio genthii (Lea, 1857). A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Synonyms include: Unio pictus (Lea, 1834), Ligumia picta (Lea, 1834) and Ligumia menkiana (Lea, 1838).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The genus Marstonia formerly was relegated to synonymy with Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987). But Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia (J. Cordeiro pers. comm. 2010).
Pyruglopsis pilsbryana is possibly a composite of multiple taxa (J. Cordeiro pers. comm. 2011).

Burch (1989) considers Stagnicola reflexa a morph of Stagnicola elodes. The genus Stagnicola leach in Jeffreys (1830) is based on the European Buccinum palustre Muller (1774). Jackiewicz (1959) has shown that several distinct species have been erroneously listed under the name palustris. The anatomical type utilized by Muller for his species is not known and therefore, Burch (1989) and Turgeon et al. (1998) have chosen not to recognize Stagnicola palustris in North America but to utilize the first name applied specificially to a North American palustris-like snail, Say's Lymnaea elodes (Say, 1821).

Falkner et al. (2001) use Galba to maintain taxonomic stability between European and North American species of this genus.

Hubendick (1951) recognised several species in the genus in North America and linked this species to Fossaria humilis as a variety or form. Burch (1989) follows Baker listing this species as a form of the group Fossaria bulimoides. The Fossaria bulimoides group is in flux (Burch 1989; Hubendick, 1951) with species variably recognised as forms, varieties subspecies or full species.
There is some taxonomic confusion over whether Elimia plicatastriata is a distinct species, or just a spring or small creek morph of E. edgariana or E. curreyana (NatureServe 2010).

This species is classified on NatureServe as Global Heritage Status Rank of G5Q - The Q indicates questionable taxonomy that may reduce conservation priority (Distinctiveness of this entity as a taxon or ecosystem type at the current level is questionable; resolution of this uncertainty may result in change from a species to a subspecies or hybrid, or inclusion of this taxon or type in another taxon or type, with the resulting taxon having a lower-priority (numerically higher) conservation status rank.)

The ICZN (1999, opinion 1896) fixed Buccinum truncatulum Muller, 1774 as the type species of the nominal genus Galba Schrank, 1803; it also placed Galba Schrank, 1803 on the Official List of Species Names in Zoology, thereby replacing the current usage of the name Fossaria Westerlund, 1885, which now a junior objective synonym. 

In Europe Falkner et al. (2001) use Galba based on ICZN opinion 1896, whereas in North American Fossaria was used for this genus (Turgeon et al., 1998).  The latest publication on the conservation status of the North America Gastropods (Johnson et al., 2013) used Galba for the genus in North America, thus the IUCN Red List is now following this convention and all species previously recognised as Fossaria are now in genus Galba.

This species is part of the Fossaria obrussa complex.  Hubendick (1951) differs from Baker (1911), who recognized several species in this genus in North America, in linking this species to Fossaria humilis.  Burch (1989) follows Baker (1928) in recognizing Fossaria obrussa, Fossaria exigua, Fossaria modicella, Fossaria peninsulae and Fossaria rustica in the Fossaria obrussa group.  By contrast Dillon et al. (2006) list Fossaria peninsulae (as well as Fossaria cyclostoma, Fossaria dalli, Fossaria exigua, Fossaria galbana, Fossaria modicella, Fossaria obrussa, Fossaria parva, Fossaria rustica and Fossaria tazewelliana) as junior synonms of Fossaria humilis based on observational similarity (see Hubendick, 1951).

The species is still listed for the publication on the conservation status of the North America Gastropods (Johnson et al., 2013) and hence is considered as valid for the IUCN Red List pending further investigations.

Genetic examination of the molecular phylogeny of global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American ancylid taxa form a well-supported clade, the Bulinini; however, the genus Rhodacmea was not included in the analysis (Albrecht et al. 2007).
