The genus is listed as Rhodacmea in Turgeon et al. (1998) but Rhodacmea is a synonym.  Although both genera were named by Walker (1918), Rhodacmea was listed first and has seniority.

It is sometimes divided into subspecies arachnoidea from small streams of East Tennessee and subspecies spinella from small streams of Lee and Scott Cos., Virginia, and Claiborne Co., Tennessee (Goodrich 1940, Burch 1989).

This species' taxonomic validity is questionable (it is unknown whether it is separate from E. cochlaris). In an unpublished study of molecular systematics, Campbell and Harris (2006) found this species relatively close to two Elimia annettae used in the study and to Elimia bullula; however, it may be a distinct species.

Despite the long-standing recognition of this taxon as a valid species, it has been suggested that multiple existing taxa (montanensis, idahoensis and apicina) are synonyms of Stagnicola catascopium. In particular, this taxon appears to be closely allied with S. apicina (Stagliano et al. 2007). For the purpose of this assessment, we follow the general acceptance of S. idahoensis as a valid species.

Hubendick (1951, in NatureServe 2010) includes this species as a form of S. emarginata.
Burch (1982) states this species is likely to be a growth variant of Ancylus havanensis Pfeiffer, 1839, which is a synonym of Ancylus radiatus Guilding, 1829 (Harry and Gubendick 1964).

The taxonomic validity of this species is questionable. Genetic examination of molecular phylogeny of global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American taxa within the subfamily Planorbinae form a well-supported clade, as yet unnamed, but termed C-Clade (Albrecht et al. 2007). This species may not be distinct from Micromenetus brogiartianus, from which it cannot be separated morphologically, so that the systematics need re-examination (M. Gordon pers. comm. 1993, Burch 1982, 1989). It is included in the 1998 American Fisheries Society publication (Turgeon et al. 1998), however, without any explanation. Thompson (1999) lists this species as a junior synonym of Micromenetus brogniartianus, at least in Florida. This species is considered a synonym of dilatatus according to FWGNA 2011. Baker (1945) treated Micromenetus as a subgenus of Menetus.
The validity of this species is unclear, but this was not addressed in the latest taxonomic assessment of Juga (Strong and Frest, 2007).

The taxonomy of this species is complex and needs to be examined (C. Lydeard pers. comm. 2000). Thompson (2000) claims Elimia bentonensis is a junior synonym of Elimia caelatura from the Savannah River System (based on type specimens and personal observations, including a lectotype designation) and E. bentonensis collected in St. Clair Co., Alabama, by Goodrich is actually Elimia godwini.

Thompson (2000) claims the name Elimia caelatura was incorrectly applied to Coosa River snails (these he reattributed to Elimia lecontiana) and E. caelatura is actually the common large-river species in the Savannah River near Georgia, and its tributary, the Broad River. Thompson (2000) also proposes a common name change to Savannah Elimia. Dillon et al. (2006) suggest synonymy of several species, including Elimia caelatura, Elimia darwini, Elimia mutabilis, Elimia albanyensis, Elimia boykiniana, Elimia postelli, Elimia suturalis, and Elimia viennaensis with Elimia catenaria, based on observational data (morphological characters that are difficult to distinguish).

Genetic examination of molecular phylogeny of the global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American taxa within the subfamily Planorbinae form a well-supported clade, as yet unnamed, but termed C-Clade (Albrecht et al. 2007).
This species was placed in the genus Stenophysa by Taylor (2003), but subsequent molecular analyses included it within the family Physidae and genus Physa (Wethington and Lydeard 2007).

The genus Marstonia formerly was relegated to synonymy with Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987). But Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species and assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia (J. Cordiero pers. comm. 2010).

The genus Marstonia formerly was relegated to synonymy with Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987). But Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species and assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia (J. Cordeiro pers. comm. 2010).

Two subspecies are recognized: Strongylura notata notata (Poey, 1860) from Cuba, Jamaica, Mexico, Belize, and Honduras and Strongylura notata forsythia Breder, 1932 from the Bahamas, Florida Keys, and southern Florida (Collette 2002).

Three distinct lineages of this species have been identified through mitochondrial DNA analysis: 1) a northern type found from the Carolinas south to the Florida Keys, and off Panama City, Florida; 2) a southern form found in the Florida Keys, Yucatan, Belize and Puerto Rico; and 3) a third found exclusively in Trinidad (Chapman et al. 1999).

In a study focusing on Colomesus pufferfishes, Amaral et al. (2013) produced evidence suggesting that Sphoeroides pachygaster be excluded from Sphoeroides based on the few species of that genus that this study sampled; further comparative investigations on the molecular and morphological features of all Sphoeroides spp. is highly desirable.
The status of this species is not certain as it is known from three specimens collected in poor condition, and may be synonymous with the more widespread species, C. guineensis (McCosker 1998).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).
The taxonomy of H. bonariense requires review.
The possibility that a subspecies exists is likely as the population in the Gulf of Mexico has significantly fewer vertebrae than those in the Caribbean (D. Smith pers. comm. 2015).
Further study is needed to clarify the differences between this species and U. lepturus (Richardson) from the Indo-West Pacific.
Polydactylus oligodon is difficult to distinguish from P. virginicus (Feltes 2002, B. Smith-Vaniz and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
This species presents a superficial ressemblance to Facciolella oxyrhyncha.

This species is recorded here as Ariopsis felis (following Betancur et al. 2007, and Page et al. 2013). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
Fusconaia mitchelli is also known as Quadrula mitchelli (Simpson, 1895). This species is commonly known as the False Spike.

The paralarvae of the genus have a very distinctive appearance. The  paralarva has a very long, slender brachial pillar and a pointed tip to the gladius. Paralarvae of Leachia were originally placed in the genus Pyrgopsis and are now often referred to as pyrgopsis paralarvae (Young and Mangold 2007).  This species may be a species complex according to Voss et al. (1992).

This species was considered a junior synonym of Megalocranchia abyssicola, but given the considerable distance between the type localities (M. abyssicola from the Maldives, M. fisheri from Hawaii) they are unlikely to be synonymous.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and R. p. diegensis Berry, 1912.

This species can be distinguished from Lophogobius cristulatus by the lateralis (sensory pore) system (Bouchereau and Gros 2010). Lophogobius androsensis, currently considered a synonym of L. cyprinoides, should be further examined using the lateralis system and 18S RNA sequence (Bouchereau et al. 2010).
There are two subspecies recognized: A. l. lyolepis from Bermuda, the Antilles and Brazilian islands, and  A. l. continentalis from the continental shore (Robertson and Van Tassell 2015).

Recent phylogenetic analysis supports earlier hypotheses by Clements et al. (2012) that subpopulations restricted to the Conchos River, Santiago River, and Soto la Marina River each represent a unique undescribed form that may warrant species level recognition (Perez-Rodriguez et al. 2016). Formal description of these taxa would require reassessment of M. austrinum due to a non-genuine change in the overall range of this species.
This species was recently split into two with Floridichthys polyommus Hubbs 1936 retained along the Yucatan and F. carpio restricted to Florida (Page et al. 2013).

Elops saurus was recently split into two largely allopatric species, E. saurus and E. smithi (McBride et al. 2010). In Florida waters, E. saurus and E. smithi may occur sympatrically at early life stages, though this does not appear to persist into the adult stage (McBride and Horodysky 2004). Elops saurus and E. smithi can be differentiated by myomere or vertebral counts; the more northern E. saurus is characterized by a higher count while the more southern E. smithi exhibits a lower count (Smith 1989, McBride and Horodysky 2004, McBride et al. 2010). These phenotypic differences are corroborated by genetic data (McBride et al. 2010).

There are three known subspecies for this species, C. suturatus suturatus, C. suturatus kashiwajimensis and C. suturatus sandwichensis (Röckel et al 1995).

C. suturatus kashiwajimensis has been accepted as a synonym of Conus magus but may still be found in the literature under C. kashiwajimensis (marinespecies.org).

C. suturatus sandwichensis is endemic to the Sandwich Islands in Hawaii. It has a less solid shell with a narrower final whorl, and the dorsum of its foot is white with brown specks (Röckel et al 1995).
<span id="aphia_ct_source_151837">
There are two subspecies of this species; C. bullatus bullatus, and C. bullatus pongo (in Western Indian Ocean).

There are eight described subspecies of Conus textile: C. t. concatenatus Kiener, 1845; C. t.  dilectus Gould, 1850; C. t.  gloriamaris Perry, 1810; C. t.  panniculus Lamarck, 1810; C. t.  reteaureum Perry, 1811; C. t.  scriptus G. B. Sowerby II, 1858; C. t. tigrinus G. B. Sowerby II, 1858 and C. t. verriculum Reeve, 1843 (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.
There is one described subspecies of Conus coelinae (Crosse, 1858): Conus coelinae spiceri (Bartsch and Rehder, 1943) (Appeltans et al 2011) from the WoRMS database.
Conus flamingo is listed as a synonym of this species, however current research shows that it is a separate species restriced to Florida (Petuch and Sargent 2011).
As well as a typical form there are two other forms of this species: Form C. c. nigropunctatus and form C. c. morrisoni (Röckel et al. 1995) .
C. daucus is included in a complex of species along with C. goajra, C. norai and C. vikingorum.
Synonym Conus seychellensis may be a sub-species or local form (G. Raybaudi pers. comm. October 2011).
C. millepunctatus is considered to be a form by some experts.
Subspecies: C. r. tahitiensis
There are two subspecies of this species; C. circumactus circumactus and C. circumactus hammatus (Poppe and Poppe 2011).
There are two recognized subspecies of this species Conus pulicarius pulicarius and Conus pulicarius vautieri (Röckel et al. 1995).
Sub species - C. spurius atlanticus Clench, 1942.
Form: C. s. kurzi
Conus pseudoaustini and Conus tristensis once considered as synonyms are valid species (Petuch and Sargent 2011).
<span id="aphia_ct_tu_429313">

Two subspecies are recognised: C. anabathrum anabathrum Crosse, 1865 and C. anabathrum burryae Clench, 1942 (Tucker, 2010).

Petuch and Sargent (2011) consider C. burryae to be a separate full species. Conus anabathrum tranthami, previously considered a synonym, has also now been shown to be a valid sub-species from the coral reefs of the Florida Keys.

Note: This species has been assessed as C. anabathrum without the range of C. burryae which will have a separate later assessment as a valid species.
Forms: C. s. sophiae, granulate form of C. striatellus.

There are many subspecies of this species including; C. p. behlokensis, C. p. echo, C. p. bazarutensis, C. p. corbieri, C. p ganensis, C. p tsara, and C. p vezoi (Appeltans 2011) from the WoRMS database, and C.p. praelatus (S. Veldsman pers. comm. October 2011). Some specialists have sugested that there may be other currently unidentified subspecies (Rockel et al. 1995).

Although there are some taxonomic issues regarding this species, for the purpose of this assessment, detailed taxonomic discussion for this species has been omitted, as it has no bearing on the resulting conservation assessment.

There are 2 subspecies:

C. v. vexillum Gmelin, 1791
C. v. sumatrensis

Forms: C. v. sulphuratus (a juvenile vexillum)
Forms: C. p. chenui and C. p. vitulinus
Subspecies: C. l. detritus (Menke 1830).
C. wakayamensis may be a synonym.
This species is easily confused with Diapterus auratus.

The most recent revision of this species (Watson 1996) considers the species to occur on both sides of Central America, however, there is disagreement. For this assessment we consider only the Western Atlantic species to be Awaous banana. There has not been a genetic analysis that supports the synonomy of A. transandianus (Pacific) and A. banana (Atlantic). It should be noted that the common trend in gobioid fauna is that morphologically similar species that occur on opposite sides of the istmus of Panama have been recognized as distinct species based upon combined morphological and molecular analysis.
Oxyurichthys guibei and O. visayanus have recently been synonymized with O. lonchotus (Pezold and Larson 2015).
This species has been misidentified as Bathygobius fuscus in Hawaii (Randall et al. 1993).
This species may be synonymous with Eviota susanae (Randall 2005); however as these two species have very different morphology and depth ranges, more research is needed to confirm this.

An in depth analysis of the various populations of this species has not been undertaken, and it remains possible or even probable that more than one species are masquerading under this name (Winterbottom and Hoese 2015).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986). Arothron meleagris colour morphs are similar to those of A. nigropunctatus (Su and Tyler 1986).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Using a number of nuclear and mitochondrial markers, Alfaro et al. (2007) detected almost no difference between the Hawaiian C. jactator and the Indo-Pacific C. janthinoptera.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

This species has been occasionally misidentified as Arothron reticularis (Randall, in litt.). Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler, 1986).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Canthigaster coronata, formally ranging from Hawaii and Tonga to the east coast of Africa and the Red Sea, was recently split into three species (Randall et al. 2008). C. coronata is endemic to Hawaii.
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Due to morphological variation in colouration and prickles throughout its range, S. nephelus has been frequently misidentified (Shipp and Yerger 1969). The taxonomic status of populations from northern South America to Brazil remain uncertain. The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008)

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Genetic analysis revealed no difference between three similar Atlantic species, C. rostrata, C. figueiredoi, and C. supramacula (L.A. Rocha, unpublished data).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Some Brazilian specimens of Chilomycterus antillarum are intermediate in colour between the crisp, dark hexagonal pattern typical of the species and the dark background with vague lighter spots typical of C. spinosus spinosus. The significance of this is unknown, and further investigation is required (Leis 2006).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species. Randall and Bauchot (1999) make a compelling argument that A. neoguinaica is a junior synonym of A. forsteri. Colborn et al. (2001) do not list A. forsteri;  this species is referred to as A. neoguinaica. Eschmeyer currently lists A. forsteri and A. neoguinaica as synonyms of Albula argentea (Forster 1801).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species. The few treatments of fisheries in this region are assumed to be A. glossodonta. Albula glossodonta has been found to be the sister species of A. vulpes (Bowen et al. 2008).  Pacific and Indian Ocean populations are distinct (Colborn et al. 2001). Friedlander et al. (2008) found genetic differences between populations in the Line Islands and Hawaii.

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species.

This species is part of the Indo-Pacific species complex, comprised of two additional species, Albula argentea and Albula oligolepis (Hidaka et al. 2008).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species.

Elops machnata and E. hawaiensis occur sympatrically in the Western Pacific and possibly the Hawaiian Islands, so further research appears warranted. In Japan, for example, Sato and Yasuda (1980) claim that E. machnata historically reported in the region are misidentifications of E. hawaiensis.

Elops saurus was recently split into two largely allopatric species, E. saurus and E. smithi (McBride et al. 2010). In Florida waters, E. saurus and E. smithi may occur sympatrically at early life stages, though this does not appear to persist into the adult stage (McBride and Horodysky 2004).  E. saurus and E. smithi can be differentiated by myomere or vertebral counts;  the more northern E. saurus is characterized by a higher count while the more southern E. smithi exhibits a lower count (Smith 1989, McBride and Horodysky 2004, McBride et al. 2010). These phenotypic differences are corroborated by genetic data (McBride et al. 2010). The sequence divergence in mtDNA cytochrome b (d = 0.023-0.029) between E. smithi and E. saurus is similar to or greater than that measured between recognized species of Elops in different ocean basins (McBride et al. 2010). We recommend the vernacular name Malacho, which is already used for Elops in several countries bordering the Caribbean basin." (McBride et al. 2010; see 'etymology').
Some authors suggest this species should be classified in the genus Lutjanus.
The name Etelis carbunculus has been wrongly applied to this species by some previous authors, including Fischer and Bianchi (1989).

Current nomenclature within the genus Dipsosaurus is not supported with recent genetic data. Hypervariable markers (microsatellites), which are appropriate for identifying current population structure have revealed three distinct groups on the Baja Peninsula: one in North Baja and two in South Baja (Valdivia-Carrillo et al. 2017). Whereas, DNA sequence data (from mitochondrial and nuclear markers), which are appropriate for identifying long-term divergence, support the mid-peninsular divergence found with the microsatellite markers, with a single evolutionary significant unit in South Baja (Packer et al. 2015, M. Packer et al. unpublished data). This mid-peninsular divergence has also been shown in multiple other taxa that are distributed across Baja (Leaché et al. 2007, Dolby et al. 2015). Lastly, the DNA sequence data also reveals connectivity between the northern Baja populations and the mainland populations (Packer et al. 2015). Thus, there are likely two evolutionary significant units within the genus, neither of which correspond to current species or subspecies boundaries. The species currently known as Dipsosaurus catalinensis is included in this assessment.
This taxon has a curious, disjunct global distribution, recorded from the Mediterranean Sea, Florida and Hawaii. Taxonomic research is needed.

Amarasinghe et al. (2018) designated a neotype for E. multifasciata and examined the taxonomy of names associated with the Eutropis multifasciata group using both molecular and morphological data, and found that the subspecies E. m. balinensis and E. m. tjendikianensis represent junior synonyms of E. multifasciata. This species has long been considered a species complex, and deep divergence between several 16S clades identified by Mulcahy et al. (2018) supports this suggestion.

This widespread gecko may be a species complex (Rösler et al. 2011). Genetic data suggests that this species' occurrence at least in the Lesser Sunda Islands, where it is widespread, is a consequence of human-mediated dispersal, as subpopulations on these islands exhibit no genetic diversity compared with subpopulations from Java (J. McGuire unpubl. data). Rösler et al. (2011) revalidated the name Gekko reevesii for populations from northern Viet Nam and southern China long recognized as being morphologically distinct from, and broadly sympatric with, G. gecko. These authors identified two "relatively deeply divergent evolutionary lineages" within this species, and indicated that deeper sampling of G. gekko from across its range is necessary to resolve the systematics of this group.

North Pacific Spiny Dogfish Squalus suckleyi (Girard, 1854) has a rather long and convoluted taxonomic history. It was first described in 1854 as a separate species from the well-known Spiny Dogfish (Squalus acanthias) but was subsequently synonymyzed as the same species even though its life history parameters, meristics, morphometrics, and molecular data suggested otherwise. A comparative study of its morphometrics and meristics, as well as a molecular study on this species complex have revealed it to be distinctive from the North Atlantic and other S. acanthias forms elsewhere (Ebert et al. 2010).
This is a recently described species.

Kaupichthys hyoproroides was previously known as a highly variable, circumglobal species. Recent studies show that the western Pacific distribution is K. japonicus and K. diodontus is known from islands of the central Pacific. The western Atlantic and western Indian Ocean distributions are currently in place for K. hyoproroides, however, these distributions may represent a cryptic species pair. Studies are underway to resolve this taxonomic issue. Until this is published, we accept current taxonomy of this species (K. Tighe pers comm. 2011).
This species is part of a complex found in the Indo-West Pacific.
This species may be part of a species complex with A. leucurus (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011).
More than one species may be passing under the name Gymnothorax eurostus; further research is needed (Smith 2012).
Gymnothorax mindonoensis is valid as a synonym of Gymnothorax javanicus.
Muraena similis and Gymnothorax mucifer are valid synonyms of Gymnothorax kidako.
Gymnothorax leucostictus is a valid synonym of Gymnothorax meleagris.
Rabula davisi is a valid synonym of Gymnothorax mordax.

Muraena atomaria, Muraena elegantissima, Muraena erythroptera, Gymnothorax hilonis, Gymnothorax pictus kowanensis, Muraena lita, Muraenophis pantherina, Muraena pfeifferi, Muraena polyophthalmus, Muraena siderea, Gymnothorax thomsoni, and Muraena variegata are valid synonyms of Gymnothorax pictus
Muraena acutirostris, Muraena agassizi, Muraena blochii, Muraena cancellata, Thyrsoidea kaupii, and Muraena valenciennii are valid as Gymnothorax undulatus.
Gymnomuraena brevicauda, Uropterygius sealei, and Scuticaria unicolor are considered synonyms of Scuticaria okinawae.
Anarchias knighti, Uropterygius makatei, Gymnomuraena nectura, and Uropterygius reidi are synonyms of Uropterygius macrocephalus.

The Hawaiian population, described as Uropterygius dentatus (Schultz 1953), is morphologically distinct from U. supraforatus (Smith 2012). Although U. dentatus is currently treated as a junior synonym of U. supraforatus, following Bölke and Randall (2000), further taxonomic work may recognize it as a valid species in the future (D.G. Smith pers. comm. 2011, Smith 2012).

Spelling of Gymnothorax rueppellii has been changed to Gymnothorax rueppelliae. Muraena interrupta, Gymnothorax leucacme, Muraena petelli, Gymnothorax signifer, and Gymnothorax waialuae are synonyms of Gymnothorax rueppelliae.
This species has been recently resurrected. It was previously considered a synonym of Bathygobius soporator and may still be confused with this species in collections.
This species should be known as Heteroonops spinimanus (Simon, 1891)
This probably represents a species complex.
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).

According to the results of a morphological study by Wiley (1986), the sister group of Fundulus plus Lucania is a group composed of the genera Adinia and Leptolucania. The genus Adinia was synonomized with Fundulus by Ghedotti and Davis (2013).
Synonym = Rhodacme filosa (Conrad, 1834)

Bagre marinus is a species complex that includes two species, Bagre marinus sensu strictu and Bagre bahiensis (Betancur and Marceniuk pers. comm. 2011). This assessment refers to Bagre marinus sensu strictu. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Vences et al. (2004) confirmed the validity of Hemidactylus mercatorius as a species distinct from H. mabouia, with which it had previously been confused, considering that it represented mainland African and Madagascan members of this species complex. Uncertainty over the exact definitions of these two species, and potential confusion with additional species of Hemidactylus, remain, making it difficult to establish the global distribution of either H. mercatorius or H. mabouia. Vences et al. (2004) found that Madagascan H. mercatorius were genetically distinct from a sample from Mozambique. Within Madagascan H. mercatorius, at least three distinct lineages appear to exist (Vences et al. 2004, Boumans et al. 2007). Rocha et al. (2005) found that Gulf of Guinea "H. mabouia" identified by Jesus et al. (2005) belonged to the northern Madagascar lineage of H. mercatorius identified by Vences et al. (2004). This concept of H. mercatorius as a widespread island species appears to correspond to Clade A of the H. mabouia-mercatorius complex identified by Rocha et al. (2010), which is also found in Tanzania, South Africa (where three separate lineages have been identified), Uganda, the Seychelles, including a lineage endemic to the Aldabra archipelago, and Réunion (Sanchez et al. 2012). However, given the apparent basal relationships of mainland African members of this clade and continuing uncertainty over their taxonomic assignment, this assessment follows Rocha et al. (2010) in restricting the name H. mercatorius to island populations within this clade, with continental populations remaining under the name H. mabouia until the taxonomy of this species complex is resolved. This treatment is acknowledged as being "completely inadequate" (Rocha et al. 2010) as East African coastal populations alone exhibit substantial variation both between and within several recognized major lineages, and the taxonomy of this species complex, and clarification of the mainland African range of H. mercatorius, is in need of further resolution. Based on current understanding, Clade A of H. mercatorius also appears to represent introduced populations in South America and Cape Verde traditionally referred to H. mabouia (Carranza and Arnold 2006, S. Rocha pers, comm. April 2012). Research into the genetics of South American H. mabouia is however preliminary. Only one lineage has so far been identified from Brazil, however there is insufficient data to clarify whether this is the only introduced lineage in the Americas (D. Borges pers. comm. April 2012). Pending resolution of this issue, all Neotropical introductions of this species are referable to H. mabouia (D. Borges pers. comm. April 2012), and this treatment is followed here. Within mainland West Africa, populations of H. mabouia ranging from Senegal to Guinea, Ghana, Togo and Cameroon are genetically similar (J-F. Trape pers. comm. April 2012), but these have not been compared with East African samples and so the relationship between this widespread form and the present concept of H. mercatorius is unclear.

Butler et al. (2019) report that work is ongoing to revise the systematics of the H. mabouia complex, and that this will recognize Hemidactylus benguellensis, presently a junior synonym of H. mabouia (but tentatively recognized as distinct by Marques et al. 2018), as a genetically and morphologically distinct species. This account refrains from accepting this taxonomic change pending the completion of this wider-ranging revision.

The species Mugil gaimardianus was supressed. Many specimens misidentified as M. gaimardianus are actually M. rubrioculus (Harrison et al. 2007).

Mugil rubrioculus can easily be confused with Mugil curema. They are very similar morphologically, but separation is easier in fresh specimens due to coloration differences.  They are however clearly separated genetically both by karyotype and molecular analysis (Nirchio et al. 2005, Fraga et al. 2007, Gonzalez-Castro et al. 2009).

The only record from Mexico was of one specimen reportedly collected from Cozumel over 100 years ago and described as ANOLIS cozumelae. Closer inspection of the specimen found this to be a specimen of A. cristatellus, but it has not been reported again on the island and there is now significant doubt regards the validity of this record.

A historical record from Half Moon Cay in Belize attributed to the closely-related Anolis carolinensis probably represents this species (L. Mahler pers. comm. October 2011), and further surveys on this island have never recorded A. carolinensis here (Lee 2000). Further studies are needed into the populations on the islands of Belize which may warrant species status. This may also be true for the Mexican populations.
The status of Gonatodes fuscus is presently unresolved (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2017), and it is retained here as a subspecies of G. albogularis following recent literature.

This species exhibits considerable geographic variation in morphology, and it is suspected that this variation reflects the existence of multiple species (e.g. Savage 2002). Accordingly, Ruane et al. (2014) split Lampropeltis triangulum into seven species.

Collins (1991) proposed that subspecies taylori be recognized as a distinct species but presented no supporting data (see also Dowling 1993); taylori intergrades morphologically with two adjacent subspecies and does not appear to be a distinct entity (Williams 1988, Roth and Smith 1990).

Armstrong et al. (2001) examined populations of subspecies syspila and elapsoides in western Kentucky and adjacent Tennessee and concluded that the two taxa exist in sympatry with minimal, if any, gene flow between the populations.

The correct year of publication of the original description is 1789 (not 1788 as commonly cited).

Campbell (1998) considered Leptodeira septentrionalis polysticta (southern Mexico to Costa Rica) to be a distinct species, however considered that it may be conspecific with L. s. ornata of lower Central America and South America. Lee (2000) retained polysticta as a subspecies of  L. septentrionalis, and this scheme is followed here.

A recent molecular phylogenetic analysis covering northern populations of Oxybelis aeneus (from North America to Panama) found three distinct clades in this area, all of which differed from a fourth clade from Trinidad and Tobago (Jadin et al. 2019). These authors refrain from taking taxonomic action pending the results of ongoing research incorporating both molecular and morphological data across the full distribution of this species complex (Jadin et al. in preparation), and suspect that additional cryptic species will be recognized as a result of this work.

Based on patterns of multilocus isozyme variation, Mendoza-Quijano et al. (1998) recognized Sceloporus variabilis marmoratus as a distinct species (Sceloporus marmoratus), and they proposed that the remaining S. variabilis populations be split into multiple species. In commenting on the proposed split, Crother et al. (2000) pointed out that the sample of marmoratus was from a single locality more than 500 km from the closest sample of S. v. variabilis and concluded that more extensive sampling from intermediate localities is needed to determine if marmoratus and variabilis are separate lineages.

Sceloporus variabilis marmoratus is retained here following Crother et al. (2000) and Bell et al. (2003) pending further investigation of its taxonomic status.

This is thought to be a species complex (Mausfeld 2000, Böhme 1985). Populations attributed to this species in which adult males have unmarked throats have been attributed to Trachylepis langheldi (Trape et al. 2012).
The eastern and western Atlantic subpopulations may represent two separate species (D. Smith pers. comm. 2012).
This species was formerly referred to as Callechelys perryae.
Genetic work shows that there may be more than one species involved in this case (Smith pers. comm. 2012).

This species has had a complex taxonomic history with other Ambystomatids such as Ambystoma tigrinum, A. velasci and A. californiense (Frost 2011). There are 5 recognized subspecies of A. mavortium (Crother 2012), based mainly on colour patterns and geographic distribution; the validity of the subspecies has not been examined recently.
Uthicke et al. (2004) by genetic analysis differentiated Holothuria whitmaei, H. fuscogilva and H. nobilis that were previously confused.

This species has also been referred to as Saccostrea mordax in the literature. The taxonomy of species in the Saccostrea genus remains unclear due to their highly variable shell forms, and more DNA-based research is needed to resolve confusion (Sekino and Yamashita 2016).
This is a monotypic genus. Analysis of variation in meristic and morphometric characters does not support recognition of subspecies in this species (Cashner et al. 1989).
May hybridize with Ptychocheilus oregonensis (Lee et al. 1980).
Sole living representative of the order Amiiformes.
Formerly placed in genus Pomolobus (Lee et al. 1980).
Alosa mediocris was formerly placed in the genus Pomolobus. This species forms a geographically separated species pair with A. chrysochloris (Lee et al. 1980).

Regarded as a valid species by most workers since the 1970s (see Lee et al. 1980). Certain populations were included under the name C. anomalum by Lee et al. (1980); Campostoma nomenclature used by Lee et al. (1980) is out of date due to taxonomic reallocations and description of a new species; see instead Burr and Cashner (1983) and Page and Burr (1991). Hybridizes with C. paicuradii in the Chestatee River (Apalachicola drainage), Georgia, and possibly in Tennessee River tributaries in northern Georgia (or perhaps the latter apparent hybrids actually represent a cryptic form of Campostoma ); hybridization occurs in an area disturbed by reservoir construction (Burr and Cashner 1983). See Buth and Burr (1978) for information on isozyme variability in the genus Campostoma .

Included under the name C. anomalum by Lee et al. (1980); Campostoma nomenclature used by Lee et al. (1980) is out of date due to taxonomic reallocations and subsequent description of C. pauciradii; see instead Burr and Cashner (1983) and Page and Burr (1991). Hybridizes with C. oligolepis in the Chestatee River (Apalachicola drainage), Georgia, and possibly in Tennessee River tributaries in northern Georgia (or perhaps the latter apparent hybrids actually represent a cryptic form of Campostoma ); hybridization occurs in an area disturbed by reservoir construction (Burr and Cashner 1983). See Buth and Burr (1978) for information on isozyme variability in the genus Campostoma .
Populations representing this species formerly were assigned to Campostoma anomalum pullum. Campostoma spadiceum was recognized as a distinct species and redescribed by Cashner et al. (2010).

The holotype of Catostomus fecundus is a hybrid between Catostomus ardens and Chasmistes liorus. Because "Catostomus fecundus" is not a valid taxon it was dropped from the 1991 AFS checklist. Under nomenclatural rules, the name fecundus cannot be used as valid for either parental species (Robins et al. 1991). See Smith (1992) for a study of the phylogeny and biogeography of the Catostomidae.
The recently redescribed summer sucker (Catostomus utawana) of the Adirondack region of New York formerly was included in this species (see Morse and Daniels 2009).

This species was first diagnosed as a population of Catostomus arenaris, which was subsequently merged with C. tahoensis, its closest relative. It was described as a distinct species by Miller (1973). The introduced population in the Santa Clara River hybridizes with C. (Pantosteus) santaanae (Lee et al. 1980, Moyle 2002).

This sucker hybridizes with the razorback sucker (Xyrauchen texanus) and the white sucker (Catostomus commersoni), an introduced species. The sucker in the Little Colorado River is recognized as a distinct, undescribed species; it is under study by A. Hutchison and D. Buth (Starnes 1995). Range-wide study of genetic diversity is needed (Starnes 1995).
Formerly included in the genus Pantosteus, which now is regarded as a subgenus of Catostomus (Smith 1966). Includes P. lahontan and P. jordani, which formerly were regarded as separate species.

Buth et al. (1992) found that Chasmistes cujus and Catostomus tahoensis were diagnostically different for 20 genetic characters; they found no genetic evidence of hybridization in a sample suspected, on the basis of morphology, to be of hybrid origin.
This species formerly was included in Catostomus commersonii.

Ambloplites ariommus formerly was regarded as a subspecies of A. rupestris. The ariommus-rupestris intermediates reported from Missouri and Arkansas lowlands and northern Alabama could be referred to A. ariommus, based on morphological characters. The identity of Ambloplites in the Neosho River system and southeastern Missouri is "difficult to resolve, perhaps due to extensive introduction of mixed stocks of A. rupestris." See Lee et al. (1980) for primary literature citations.

Roe et al. (2008) noted that morphological, mitochondrial, and allozyme characters do not allow discrimination between A. rupestris and A. ariommus within the Interior Highlands; this may indicate that A. ariommus never occurred west of the Mississippi River, or it could indicate that if A. ariommus occurred in these drainages, it has now become introgressed with A. rupestris (Roe et al. 2008).

Roe et al. (2008) stated that the distinctiveness of Mobile Basin A. ariommus warrants further study using genetic evidence (that population might turn out to be a distinct species).
This species is closely related to (and was formerly included in) the rock bass, A. rupestris (Cashner and Suttkus 1977, Lee et al. 1980).

Ambloplites cavifrons and A. ariommus formerly were included in this species.

Roe et al. (2008) noted that morphological, mitochondrial, and allozyme characters do not allow discrimination between A. rupestris and A. ariommus within the Interior Highlands; this may indicate that A. ariommus never occurred west of the Mississippi River, or it could indicate that if A. ariommus occurred in these drainages, it has now become introgressed with A. rupestris (Roe et al. 2008).
Formerly included in Ammocrypta beani.

In a phylogenetic analysis based on morphology, Simons (1991) concluded that Ammocrypta asprella should be included in the genus Crystallaria (generally has been regarded as a subgenus of Ammocrypta) and that the genus Ammocrypta should be regarded as a subgenus of Etheostoma. Page and Burr (1991), Simons (1992), and Wiley (1992) adopted this change, but Etnier and Starnes (1993) and Jenkins and Burkhead (1994) retained Ammocrypta as a distinct genus and treated Crystallaria as a subgenus. Patterns of molecular variation are consistent with the recognition of Ammocrypta species as taxonomically distinct from Etheostoma (Wood and Mayden 1997, Faber and Stepien 1998, Near et al. 2000).
The only living member of the genus; the most "primitive" living member of the Centrarchidae (Lee et al. 1980).
This species was included in Ictalurus platycephalus until 1968.
Formerly considered conspecific with Ameiurus serracanthus.

In a phylogenetic analysis based on morphology, Simons (1991) concluded that Ammocryptaasprella should be included in the genus Crystallaria (generally has been regarded as a subgenus of Ammocrypta) and that the genus Ammocrypta should be regarded as a subgenus of Etheostoma. Page and Burr (1991), Simons (1992), and Wiley (1992) adopted this change, but Etnier and Starnes (1993) and Jenkins and Burkhead (1994) retained Ammocrypta as a distinct genus and treated Crystallaria as a subgenus. Patterns of molecular variation are consistent with the recognition of Ammocrypta species as taxonomically distinct from Etheostoma (Wood and Mayden 1997, Faber and Stepien 1998, Near et al. 2000).

Ameiva ameiva is a known species complex, but its taxonomy has never been investigated in detail and species boundaries are not clear. Ugueto and Harvey (2011) conducted a preliminary study of variation in this group, which strongly suggested that Lesser Antilles populations attributed to this species are specifically distinct from forms found in the mainland, Swan Island, and Trinidad & Tobago. These authors recognized two species, A. atrigularis and A. praesignis, from within Venezuelan populations attributed to this species, but indicated that additional species exist within the complex. Henderson and Powell informally recognize the Lesser Antilles populations under the name Ameiva aquilina, and this name has recently been used in grey literature (Sadjak et al. 2016); this form is retained here within Ameiva ameiva pending clarification of species boundaries within this complex.

Based on mtDNA data (Devitt 2006) and patterns of morphological variation, Devitt et al. (2008) recognized six species in the Trimorphodon biscutatus species complex: T. lyrophanes, T. lambda, and T. vilkinsonii in the United States and Mexico, and T. biscutatus, T. paucimaculatus, and T. quadruplex occurring to the south in Mexico/Central America. 

Trimorphodon lambda hybridizes with T. vilkinsonii in extreme southeastern Arizona (Cochise County) and southwestern New Mexico (Grant and Hidalgo counties) (Devitt et al. 2008). This species may also come into contact with T. lyrophanes in southeastern California and/or extreme southern Nevada, and with T. paucimaculatus near the Sonora-Sinaloa border (Devitt et al. 2008). Specimens from contact zones may be difficult to identify (Devitt et al. 2008).

Based on mtDNA data (Devitt 2006) and patterns of morphological variation, Devitt et al. (2008) recognized six species in the Trimorphodon biscutatus species complex: T. lyrophanes, T. lambda, and T. vilkinsonii in the United States and Mexico, and T. biscutatus, T. paucimaculatus, and T. quadruplex occurring to the south in Mexico/Central America.

authority: Crother, White, Savage, Eckstut, Graham & Gardner, 2011
taxonomicNotes: Based on a phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA data, Crother et al. (2011) determined that populations of Pantherophis vulpinus west of the Mississippi River should be recognized as a distinct species (Pantherophis ramscotti), whereas populations of P. vulpinus east of the Mississippi River represent a single species (P. vulpinus). The authors concluded that nominal P. gloydi of the eastern Great Lakes basin should be regarded as conspecific with P. vulpinus.

This species has three subspecies - P. campanulata campanulata (known from Saskatchewan, Canada), P. campanulata collinsi (known from Ontario, Canada), and P. campanulata smithi (known from the lower peninsula of Michigan, U.S.A.).

Genetically this species is nested within Anolis roquet from Martinique based on mtDNA results reported by Thorpe et al. (2005). If this result is supported by other genetic markers this would render A. roquet paraphyletic. Further research is needed to support this conclusion, as it is possible that the mtDNA results represent hybridization events. This research may reveal that A. extremus should be considered a junior synonym of A. roquet, or that some of the Martinique populations should be assigned to A. extremus.

Some confusion exists as to the boundary of this species with S. subvexus: Williams et al. (2008) confined S. subvexus to the Tombigbee and Black Warrior River drainages, and S. connasaugensis to eastern drainages of the Mobile Basin. However, individuals resembling S. subvexus can sometimes be found in eastern reaches of the Mobile basin and individuals resembling S. connasaugaensis can occasionally be found in the Black Warrior and Tombigbee River drainages.  The confusion exists due variable shell morphology (J. Cordeiro pers. comm. 2012).

The Dusky Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Galapagos Shark (Carcharhinus galapagensis). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).
This is the revised taxonomic concept of Centrophorus grandulosus, which includes C. lusitanucs as a junior synonym; C. lesliei and C. longipinnis are also now split out as newly recognised species.

A study using allozymes as a genetic marker (Eitner 1995) indicated that an unrecognized fourth species of Alopias may exist, however this claim was based on data from a single shark specimen likely to have been A. vulpinus. Recent work investigating population structure of all three Alopias species using mitochondrial DNA control region sequences (Trejo 2005) has found no evidence indicating that a fourth species of thresher sharks exists.

This species is comprised of two valid subspecies: Mustelus canis canis occurs on the continental shelf, whereas M. c. insularis occurs on insular shelves in the Caribbean (Heemstra 1997, Ebert et al. 2013).

The Whitespotted Eagle Ray (Aetobatus narinari) (Euphrasen 1790) was originally restricted to the Western Central and Southwest Atlantic (Sales et al. 2019) but the range now also extends to the eastern Atlantic (Fricke et al. 2020).
Synonymy of species previously thought as distinct has increased the range of this species (J. Cordeiro pers. comm. 2012).

The Galapagos Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Dusky Shark (Carcharhinus obscurus). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).

authority: Barbosa du Bocage & de Brito Capello, 1864

taxonomicNotes: Genetics studies have led some researchers to suspect that there may be an undescribed species of Echinorhinus off Oman and elsewhere in the Arabian Sea region (Henderson et al. 2016).
There is a single extant species in the family Mitsukurinidae.

Yano and Musick (1992) showed that morphometric characters used to separate Pacific Pseudotriakis acrales Jordan & Snyder, 1904 from Atlantic P. microdon de Brito Capello, 1868 did not differ significantly, and these authors confirmed P. acrales as a junior synonym of P. microdon. Pseudotriakis is thus a mono-specific genus.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera bonasus, which can only be distinguished by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).

Caiman crocodilus has four subspecies currently recognized:  C. c. crocodilus, C. c. fuscus, C. c. chiapasius, and C. c. apaporiensis. Caiman yacare previously was considered to be a fifth subspecies (i.e., C. c. yacare). However, it is now generally accepted as a full species (King and Burke 1989), and is no longer treated as a subspecies (Escobedo-Galván et al. 2011).

Busack and Pandya (2001), using morphological analysis, stated that there were no differences between subspecies. However, Venegas-Anaya et al. (2008), using mitochondrial DNA analysis, recognized three out of these four subspecies (no samples from C. c. apaporiensis used in this study) and delimited geographically distributions within the C. crocodilus complex. DNA analyses also suggest a geographic divergence in two groups: the Mesoamerican group including C. c. fuscus and C. c. chiapasius and the South American group, which includes C. c. crocodilus and C. yacare (Amato and Gatesby 1994; Venegas-Anaya et al. 2008).

Recent morphological analysis of the Apaporis River caiman (C. c. apaporiensis), based on holotype and paratypes skulls from the Chicago Field Museum (USA), corroborates a significant morphological differentiation with the rest of the C. crocodilus subspecies (Escobedo-Galván et al. 2015a) as reported by Frederico Medem in 1952. However, DNA analysis conducted with additional paratypes from Colombian collections showed that several of those skulls identified as C. c. apaporiensis in the Instituto de Ciencias Naturales, National University of Colombia collection fall into the C. c. crocodilus clade (Bloor 2013). Nevertheless, a more in-depth study is being initiated in late 2018, to collect less fragmented DNA (from live individuals rather than ancient bones) and larger sample sizes (for both morphological and genetic analyses), which will hopefully provide new evidence on the validity of this subspecies.
Thompson and Hershler (2002) propose the genus Floridobia to accommodate species from the eastern United States formerly placed in the genus Cincinnatia (J. Cordiero, pers. comm. 2010).
Thompson and Hershler (2002) propose the genus Floridobia to accommodate species from the eastern United States formerly placed in the genus Cincinnatia (J. Cordiero, pers. comm. 2010).

Studies addressing the taxonomic status of E. coqui (whether it is one nominal species or more than one species) are equivocal (e.g., Bird-Picó 1994, Gonser 1996, Rios-López 1999, and Veló-Anton et al. 2007). Due to the taxonomic confusion of this species and E. portoricensis in Puerto Rico, there may be some lowland records of E. portoricensis that actually belong to E. coqui (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Xenopus poweri (Furman et al. 2015). A previous subspecies of this species Xenopus laevis sudanensis was elevated to a distinct species, and then subsequently synonymised with X. poweri (Furman et al. 2015).
This taxon, originally known as Margaritifera monodonta, was removed from the 1996 Red List but kept on the Mollusc SG database as Not Evaluated.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera brasiliensis, which can only be distinguished from R. bonasus by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Until recently, the species name usually was spelled as sayi rather than say. This is not a synonymy, simply a change to conform to original spelling.

This Gulf of Mexico endemic species has sometimes been mistaken for the sympatric Dusky Smoothound (Mustelus canis) and Narrowfin Smoothhound (M. norrisi) in its limited offshore range (Heemstra 1997).
The western Atlantic and Pacific Ocean forms are thought to be different species (Ebert et al. 2013)
This species might be confused with the congener Cookiecutter Shark (Isistius brasiliensis).

Seigel et al. (1977) considered Squaliolus sarmenti and S. aliae as synonyms of S. laticaudus. Sasaki and Uyeno (1987) subsequently removed S. aliae from the synonymy as distinct and the genus now contains these two widely recognised species. Squaliolus laticaudus is sympatric with S. aliae in some regions.
The scientific name for this species is often misspelled as Carcharhinus perezii. Carcharhinus springeri Sadowsky & Amorim 1977 is considered a synonym (Soto 2001).
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from C. porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.

Nurse sharks occurring in the eastern Pacific were formerly considered part of this species concept, however the Pacific Nurse Shark (Ginglymostoma unami) has now been formally described as a separate species (Del Moral-Flores et al. 2015).
Previously confused with the similar but smaller Etmopterus pusillus until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).

Poecilia obscura was originally elevated as a distinct species based on molecular phylogenetic analysis utilizing mitochondrial DNA, and based on differences in gonopodial characteristics (Schories et al. 2009). The authors of this description were unable to describe this new species based on morphological characteristics alone, and therefore conclude that it comprises a cryptic species complex with P. reticulata (Schories et al. 2009). A  number of authors have expressed concern regarding the validity of P. obscura as a distinct species from P. reticulata, versus considerable intraspecific variation or sub-species status (Sievers 2011, Baillie 2012). Phillip et al. (2013) follows Baillie (2012) in rejecting P. obscura as a valid species, whose analysis indicates substantial gene flow between the Quare River (Oropouche watershed) and the Madamas River (situated on the north shore and known to harbour P. reticulata). Further evidence suggests the occurrence of individuals that display both Caroni and Oropouche genotypes, corresponding to P. reitculata and P. obscura, respectively (Baillie 2012). Further study failed to detect behavioural or life history differences between P. obscura and P. reticulata and rapid production of viable hybrids offspring is apparent (Sievers 2011).


Therefore, P. obscura is included within the existing assessment of P. reticulata as a junior synonym of the latter.
This species is sometimes confused with Squalus clarkae and may be confused with recently described or undescribed species in the South Atlantic (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).

Formerly included as a subspecies of Astyanax fasciatus. Although considered by recent authors (e.g. Miller et al. 2005) as the species present in northern Mexico and Texas, with several cave populations, Schmitter-Soto (2017) restricted A. mexicanus to the Balsas and adjacent Pacific drainages in Mexico.

Original population in Utah Lake may be extinct. When numbers were low, Chasmistes liorus hybridized with Catostomus ardens, which apparently led to introgression of new characters into the population; now this form (described as a new subspecies, Chasmistes liorus mictus), is abundant, according to Miller and Smith (1981). Ongoing research may reveal if any unhybridized Chasmistes liorus remain.

Catostomus fecundus is an invalid taxon because it was based on hybrids between Catostomus ardens and Chasmistes liorus.

Chasmistes and Deltistes are closely related to the older, more diverse, widespread genus Catostomus; Chasmistes species are distinctive in having branched gill rakers and a terminal mouth (Scoppettone and Vinyard 1991).

Harris and Mayden (2001) used molecular data to examine phylogenetic relationships of major clades of Catostomidae. In all trees, Scartomyzon was paraphyletic and embedded in Moxostoma, and Catostomus was never recovered as monophyletic (Xyrauchen was embedded within Catostomus). They concluded that the phylogenetic relationships and taxonomic composition of taxa presently included in Moxostoma and Scartomyzon are in need of further study, as are the relationships and composition of the genera Catostomus, Chasmistes, Deltistes , and Xyrauchen, and the phylogenetic affinites of Erimyzon and Minytrema.

See Smith (1992) for a study of the phylogeny and biogeography of the Catostomidae.

The species is here understood as encompassing all nominal subspecies described by Hubbs (1936, 1938) and other authors, and elevated to species status without a comprehensive analysis in some works (e.g. by Říčan et al. 2016). A recent morphological and genetic review found no support for more than one species (Barrientos-Villalobos et al. 2018). Several of the Hubbsian subspecies have been listed as vulnerable (e.g. by Jelks et al. 2008), but these assessments do not refer to Mayaheros urophthalmus proper.

This species is comprised of several recognized forms (torulosa, gubernaculum, rangiana, and cincinnatiensis), but it is not clear whether these forms represent ecophenotypic variation, true subspecies, or a species complex. The entire species group exhibits considerable ecophenotypic variation. Epioblasma was formerly placed in the genera Unio, Truncilla, and Dysnomia (Johnson 1978).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Based on geographical separation and differences in tooth row counts and coloration, Carvalho (1999) considered Narcine bancroftii and N. brasiliensis to be distinct species. However, intraspecific differences in tooth row counts among individuals of varying sizes were observed. Genetic analyses of Narcine specimens from throughout their range in the Western Atlantic Ocean are needed to confirm the presence of two species. Narcine bancrofti is a frequent misspelling of the species name.

Bathytoshia formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis, which is now recognised as a valid species (Last et al. 2016); hence Dasyatis (Bathytoshia) centroura is now Bathytoshia centroura. This western Atlantic species is not conspecific with Bathytoshia of the eastern Atlantic (Last et al. 2016); the eastern Atlantic population that was formerly included within Dasyatis centroura is now included within B. lata (Last et al. 2016). The status of the single record from India is unknown.

Western populations have been proposed to constitute a distinct species, Coluber mormon (Fitch et al. 1981), but this distinction has been demonstrated to be invalid (Corn and Bury 1986; see also Greene 1984).

Wüster et al. (2001) described a new species of Drymarchon from northwestern Venezuela, bringing the species total for the genus to four (five if couperi is recognized as a species). This taxonomic rearrangement treats D. corais and D. melanurus as distinct species. The species in the United States, Mexico, Central America, and South America west of the Andes and in Venezuela is D. melanurus. D. corais occurs in South America east of the Andes (Wüster et al. 2001).  Wüster et al. (2001) also recognized D. couperi and D. margaritae, previously considered subspecies, as full species but without examining specimens, based on previously published (but unspecified) morphological differences and application of the evolutionary species concept. Subsequent checklists (e.g. Crother et al. 2003, Collins and Taggart 2002) have adopted this taxonomy.
McCranie (2011) agreed with these taxonomic changes, but noted that these actions were taken on the basis of limited sampling and emphasized the need for further study to clarify the taxonomy of this group. The resulting concept of D. melanurus is likely to be a species complex; McCranie (2011) suggested that two species-level taxa may be included under the name D. melanurus in Honduras alone.
The subspecies victa of peninsular Florida is treated as a species by some authors.
Elimia showalteri, Elimia variata, and Elimia olivula may only be clinal variants of a single-species (Bogan and Pierson 1993).
This has been recognised as a subspecies of Elimia catonaria. But is in AFS list. A. Bogan comments that other subspecies are also present: E. pastelli (Lea, 1858).

A. Bogan notes that TNC lists this species of uncertain taxonomic status. In fact, it has been suggested that this species together with Elimia cahawbensis, Elimia annettae and Elimia pupoides may represent a single variable species with a cline from headwaters to large riverrs, instead of four distinct species (Bogan and Pierson 1993). In this assessment, however, we stick with the current published taxonomic status of a distinct species.
Based on morphological differences of the gonopod in this species, there is some uncertainity on the validity of this species (S. Adams pers. comm. 2009).
Was incorrectly listed on Red Lists prior to 2008 as Hobbseus valobushensis.

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

Based on mtDNA evidence, A. cingulatum (sensu stricto) inhabiting the eastern Gulf Coastal Plain and the Atlantic Coastal Plain in northern Florida are distinct lineages; the Suwannee River and a large distributional gap separate them (Pauly et al. 2007). Further data are needed to determine whether these two lineages warrant recognition as different species (Pauly et al. 2007).

Until recently Lasmigona etowaensis was considered conspecific with Lasmigona holstonia, but the two were distinguished using genetic analyses (A. Bogan, unpublished data). These two species cannot be reliably separated using conchological characters (Williams et al. 2008).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Six subspecies have been described (Ansell 1972; summarized in Cassinello 1998). However, the morphological differences between them are not well defined, and there are several apparent zones of hybridization, evidence of an urgent need for the reassessment of subspecies (Cassinello 1998).

Athearnia crassa was formerly placed as a subspecies of Leptoxis (= Athearnia) crassa (see Dillon and Ahlstedt 1997). Athearnia crassa crassa and Athearnia crassa anthonyi are distinct from one another and Athearnia anthonyi and Athearnia crassa are now recognized as distinct species (see Dillon and Ahlstedt 1997; Minton and Savarese 2005).

Appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the incorrectly spelt name Leptoxis crassa. Was also incorrectly listed as Vulnerable.

Formerly placed as a subspecies of Leptoxis (= Athearnia) crassa (see Dillon and Ahlstedt, 1997). Athearnia crassa crassa and Athearnia crassa anthonyi are distinct from one another and Athearnia anthonyi and Athearnia crassa are now recognized as distinct species (see Dillon and Ahlstedt 1997, Minton and Savarese 2005).

Appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the incorrectly spelt name Leptoxis anthonyix. Was also incorrectly listed as Extinct.

The genus Leptoxis was formerly called Anculosa (Goodrich, 1922). The genus Leptoxis is a difficult group. There is considerable disagreement in regard to the number of valid species (Goodrich 1922, Burch 1982). Dillon and Lydeard (1998) found high levels of genetic divergence among populations of Leptoxis praerosa and Leptoxis plicata and from all other populations of Leptoxis studied, indicating they are distinct species. In a preliminary analysis of molecular phylogeny of Mobile River basin pleurocerids, Lydeard et al. (1997) concluded that Leptoxis picta and Leptoxis plicata are quite distinct from one another and all other pleurocerids studied, while Leptoxis taeniata and Leptoxis ampla are sister taxa, and Leptoxis picta the most basal of the group.

Genus name Lithasia Haldeman, 1840 is actually a junior synonym of Ellipstoma Rafinesque, 1818, but Minton and Bogan (2003) have successfully suppressed Ellipstoma in favour of the better known Lithasia (ICZN 2005). Based on molecular and limited morphological phylogenenetics, Minton and Lydeard (2003) have determined that Lithasia fuliginosa is a composite of what were formerly Lithasia duttoniana, Lithasia geniculata fuligonosa, Lithasia geniculata geniculata, Lithasia geniculata pinguis, and possibly Lithasia jayana all from the Duck River, Tennessee, wherein L. jayana may be a synonym of Lithasia armigera.

Minton and Lydeard (2003) recorded one specimen from Duck River, and proposed synonymy with fuliginosa. Dillon and Johnson found no difference with duttoniana and proposed that it was synonymous. Further work is needed to ascertain taxonomy. In an unpublished review this species is synonymized with armigera (Minton unpublished).

In a recent molecular phylogenetic analysis, Minton and Lydeard (2003) proposed that populations of Lithasia salebrosa florentiana, L. salebrosa subglobosa, and L. verrucosa from the Elk and Tennessee River drainages should be included within the synonymy of this species. Following this, they recommended a downranking from G2 (imperiled) to a new rank of G3G4 (vulnerable to apparently secure) (NatureServe 2009).

Genus name Lithasia Haldeman, 1840 is actually a junior synonym of Ellipstoma Rafinesque, 1818, but Minton and Bogan (2003) have successfully suppressed Ellipstoma in favor of the better known Lithasia (ICZN 2005). Based on molecular and limited morphological phylogenetics, Minton and Lydeard (2003) have determined that Lithasia lima is likely a composite comprised of Lithasia lima and Lithasia verrucosa from the Elk and Tennessee Rivers as well as possibly Lithasia salebrosa salebrosa and Lithasia salebrosa florentina. White River drainage, Arkansas, specimens of Lithasia verrucosa may be a distinct undescribed species.

Identification at the species level has not posed problems, but determining its closest relatives and assignment to a genus has resulted in a few taxonomic changes. Hermes copper was originally described by Edwards (1870) as Chrysophanus hermes, then placed in the genus Tharsalea based by Scudder (1876). Wright (1905) described the species as Chrysophanus delsud, but this was a synonym (Wright 1908, Tilden 1975). Later work focused at the sub-generic level and a more complete summary can be found in Marschalek and Klein (2010).  Placement in the monotypic genus Hermelycaena is suggested based on recent morphological and ecological (Miller and Brown 1979), molecular (Pratt and Wright 2002), and larval (Ballmer and Pratt 1989) data. Pelham (2008) placed the Hermes copper in the genus Lycaena and subgenus Hermelycaena.

This taxon has been placed in six genera (Brim Box and Williams 2000). Anodontoides radiatus has been confused with Strophitus subvexus by some investigators. Clench and Turner (1956) reported Anodontoides elliottii from the Apalachicola, Chipola and Chattahoochee drainages. Although Clench and Turner's records of A. elliottii from the Chattahoochee River and Apalachicola River system (Mosquito Creek) are in fact A. radiatus, Johnson (1967) correctly re-identified their Chipola River records as S. subvexus.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
Should be placed under the genus Fumonelix.
Variously cited as a species, subspecies of Cryptomastix mullani, or synonym of Cryptomastix sanburni. The problem has not been effectively addressed in the literature.
Should possibly be placed under the genus Fumonelix.
Synonymized with Mussa angulosa (Fenner 1993), and Veron (2000) agreed.

Until recently, this species was included in M. annularis (Weil and Knowlton 1994) along with M. faveolata. Consequently, most studies prior to 1994 do not distinguish between the three species, and information on population is difficult to disaggregate for the three taxa.

Montastraea annularis (Weil and Knowlton 1994) has recently been split into three species including M. faveolata and M. franksi. Consequently, most studies prior to 1994 do not distinguish between the three species, and information on population is difficult to disaggregate for the three taxa.

Commonly confused with M. braziliensis. Smith (1972) recognized two species in the Caribbean, the sub-massive and platy form, M. meandrites, and a free-living form, M. danae, and a third species in Brazil, M. braziliensis. Most reports in the last 20 years refer to the free-living form in the Caribbean as M. braziliensis. Recent review of the genus in the Caribbean has confirmed the identity of M. danae as the free-living form distinct from M. braziliensis, the identity of M. meandrites as a sub-massive platy form and a new crustos species, yet to be described (Pinzon and Weil in review).

Until recently, this species was included in M. annularis (Weil and Knowlton 1994) along with M. franksi. Consequently, most studies prior to 1994 do not distinguish between the three species, and information on population is difficult to disaggregate for the three taxa.

In the western Atlantic, this coral was been divided into two species (D. stokesii and D. stellaris), although most researchers lump both corals in D. stokesii. Cairns et al. (1999) regard the two as distinct.
Veron (2000) synonymized Isophyllastrea with Isophyllia.

Species of the genus Scolymia may be misidentified and can be confused with newly recruited polyps of Mussa angulosa. The taxonomic validity of this species is unclear (E. Weil. pers. comm.). Scolymia wellsi has also been synonymized with S. cubensis in Fenner (1993) and Veron (2000) agreed.

In the 2008 Red List assessment, a total of 75 extant and five extinct 'subpopulations' were identified across the natural range of O. nerka. In the 2011 Red List assessment, several of these subpopulations were further subdivided based on additional input from salmon specialists (Pacific Salmon Commission, PSC, and Fisheries and Oceans Canada, DFO), resulting in a total of 98 subpopulations, of which 93 are extant. The subpopulations in this assessment are considered independent and reproductively isolated from each other.

The assessors used a combination of ecoregional (i.e., marine and freshwater habitat-based) classification and the degree of genetic divergence between known spawning 'locations', using an FST value of 0.04, representing a threshold level of gene flow between putative 'subpopulations' of less than or equal to one effective migrant per year. The five extinct subpopulations were based on Gustafson et al. 2007. While the assessors acknowledge that it is not straightforward to ascribe demographic or geographic distinctness to a subpopulation based on observed genetic distances, they feel it is the most appropriate methodology given the scale of the assessment and the paucity of observations of stray rates among the spawning locations considered in this assessment.
Previously recognized as Pleuronectes glacialis (Kells et al. 2016).
This species is restricted to Europe and Siberia and absent from North America, where it is replaced by Thymallus signifer.

Earlier treated as subspecies or synonym of O. mordax but morphological and genetic data indicate they are distinct species, O. mordax being restricted to the East coast of Canada and the North American Great Lakes.
In need of critical taxonomic revision; several species seem to be confused under the name P. flesus.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now described as P. fouquettei; Lemmon et al. 2008).

Taricha sierrae was formerly recognized as a subspecies of Taricha torosa.

Phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA data (Tan and Wake 1995) revealed the following clusters in T. torosa: (1) northern Sierra Nevada (Shasta to Nevada counties); (2) central Sierra Nevada (El Dorado to Fresno counties); (3) southern Sierra Nevada (Tulare to Kern counties) (independently derived relative to 1 and 2, above); (4) southern coastal California (San Diego and Orange counties); (5) central coastal California (Los Angeles to central and northern California). This study and additional allozyme data (Kuchta and Tan 2006) provided the basis for a phylogeographical history of T. torosa. Among other things, the data are consistent in indicating that populations in the southern Sierra Nevada are more closely related to T. torosa torosa than to T. t. sierrae.

In the interests of taxonomic stability, Kuchta and Tan (2006) refrained from advocating changes in the taxonomic status of Taricha torosa torosa and Taricha torosa sierrae, pending completion and publication of ongoing studies.

Kuchta (2007) examined genetic and morphological variation in Taricha torosa and concluded that T. torosa and T. sierrae are distinct evolutionary lineages that should be recognized as distinct species.

Significant morphological and behavioral differences between Rana draytonii and R. aurora suggest that they represent two species in secondary contact (Hayes and Krempels 1986, cited by USFWS 1994). Shaffer et al. (2004) presented genetic evidence supporting the recognition of Rana aurora and R. draytonii as distinct species.

Yellow-legged frog populations now recognized as Rana sierrae were formerly included in Rana muscosa. Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined the phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south, and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum, and found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species.

Neotoma magister previously was regarded as a subspecies of Neotoma floridana. Evidence from analyses of variation in mtDNA, allozymes, and morphology indicates that N. magister is a highly distinct lineage (Hayes and Harrison 1992, Hayes and Richmond 1993, Edwards and Bradley 2001). Baker et al. (2003) and Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) recognized N. magister and N. floridana as distinct species. Baker et al. (2003) used the name "Appalachian Woodrat."

Densmore et al. (1992) elevated Nerodia harteri paucimaculata to species status after Rose and Selcer had suggested that already in 1989. Other authors have pointed out that there is no single character that will allow separation of individuals from the two populations 100% of the time. Treated here as a good species.
The taxonomic position of this species is currently under review, and it may be transferred to Fusconaria as F. rotulata (Wright, 1899).

This species and Cherax tenuimanus were formerly thought to be the same species (C.M. Austin pers. comm. 2008). It has recently been proposed to re-combine these species, for functional clarity but not taxonomic similarity (Molony et al. 2006)

Sub species:
leniusculus (Signal crayfish): Astacus leniusculus was placed on the Official List of Specific Names in Zoology, name number 2244, in Opinion 855 of the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature. (See Melville, 1968: 84).
klamathensis (Klamath Signal Crayfish)
trowbridgii: (Columbia River Signal Crayfish)

Recent genetic studies (Crandall lab) suggest that these different subspecies are in fact distinct.  Thus the P. klamathensis and P. trowbridgii might themselves be endangered whereas the P. leniusculus is more broad spread and indeed an invasive.
