Cambarus robustus is a species complex. Southern populations that are found to be undescribed species will likely require elevated conservation status (R. Thoma pers. comm.2010).

Cambarus monongalensis is a species complex that contains at least 3 species. Once taxonomic issues are resolved some of the populations will require elevated conservation status (R. Thoma pers. comm. 2010).
This species is a species complex   (R. Thoma, T. Jones, J. Cordeiro, pers. comm. 2009).
This is a species complex, that includes Fallicambarus hedgpethi (Hobbs 1948) and F. uhleri (Faxon 1884), which were synonomized by Hobbs and Robison (1989).
Two subspecies of this species are recognised, Cambarus bartonii bartonii Fabricius 1798 (Common Crayfish) and C. b. cavatus Hay 1902 (Appalachian Brook Crayfish).
This species is part of a species complex consisting of Procambarus pubischlae publischalae (Hobbs 1942) and Procambarus pubischelae deficiens (Hobbs 1942).
Although this is a distinct species, the exact relationships between Fallicambarus burrisi, F. byersi, F. danielae, F. gordoni and this species needs to be determined (K. Crandall pers. comm. 2009).

This species was synonymized with Procambarus enoplosternum Hobbs by Hobbs (1981:388); the reasons cited were presented on page 398. On the basis of additional materials from South Carolina, there is reason to question this action; therefore, P. chacei was retained by Hobbs (1989) tentatively.

This is a species complex currently under investigation by Dr. J.E. Cooper at the North Carolina State Museum as some confusion exists as to the synonymy of several species of Cambarus (Lieb et al. 2008), in addition to subpopulations of this species. A genetic assessment is currently underway by Dr James W. Fetzner of all known populations of this species (R. Thoma pers. comm. 2010). Dr J.E. Cooper is currently preparing new species manuscripts (R. Thoma pers. comm. 2010).

This species has three recognized subspecies, namely the Creole Painted Crayfish Orconectes palmeri creolanus (Creaser 1933), the Western Painted Crayfish Orconectes palmeri longimanus (Faxon 1898) and the Gray-Speckled Crayfish Orconectes palmeri palmeri (Faxon 1884). 

It is very difficult to distinguish this species from O. hobbsi in southwestern Mississippi and the Ponchartrain drainages of Louisiana.  However, clarification of this taxonomic issue will not change the status of this species.

This species is recognised as two subspecies; namely the Gapped Ringed Crayfish Orconectes neglectus chaenodactylus Williams, 1952 and the Ringed Crayfish Orconectes neglectus neglectus (Faxon, 1885).
This species is contained within a species complex that requires considerable attention (Hobbs 1989).

This species is a regarded as a distinct species within its taxonomically confused subgenus. Other new species within the subgenus Tubericambarus are in the process of being described (R. Thoma pers. comm. 2010).

This species used to be a species complex comprised of four subspecies: O. difficilis difficilis, O. d. maletae, O. d. hathawayi and O. d. blacki (Walls 1985) but each subspecies has since been upgraded to species level (Fitzpatrick 1987).

Originally reported (1958) as intergrade populations between P. "pearsei pearsei" and P. "pearsei plumimanus", but Hobbs (1975) elevated plumimanus to full species and designated the "intergrade" populations as P. medialis after collection of additional specimens from additional localities.
Walls (2009) states that it is difficult to sperate O. palmeri from O. hobbsi at a species level.   Therefore, it is hard to definitively assign museum specimens to either species.
This species was formerly part of the Orconectes juvenilis complex (Taylor 2000).

The taxonomy of this species has been uncertain since it was first discovered by Erichson in 1846 (Hobbs and Bouchard 1973), although it is now better separated from Cambarus dubius taxonomically, and faces limited or no immediate threats.

Kentucky populations of Cambarus parvoculus may actually be this species according to preliminary genetic data from Roger Thoma (Taylor and Schuster 2004, C. Taylor, pers. comm. 2008). Recent genetic analysis has revealed that this species and C. parvoculus are separate species with Virginia populations of this species showing considerable genetic difference from Kentucky populations and rostral morphology also indicating the species are separate (Thoma and Fetzner 2008).  Other previously mentioned character states (Thoma 2000) and potential new character states were investigated and were found to not be significantly different for the two nominal species. A third, genetically identical species has been discovered, currently retained as C. jezerinaci, in an area between the ranges of C. jezerinaci and C. parvoculus in Tennessee between Pine and Cumberland Mountains (Thoma and Fetzner 2008).

Hayes (1973) reported what he interpreted to be intergrade populations between O. nana and O. macrus in Delaware and Ottawa Counties, Oklahoma, but in his recent revision of the genus, Fitzpatrick (1987) maintained specific status for these crayfishes.

There is some question as to whether populations from Anderson, Clairborne, Campbell, and Scott counties, Tennessee (Williams et al. 2007) and the North Fork Powell River and Guest River in Virginia (Winston et al. 1997), might be another undescribed species.

Hayes (1973) reported what he interpreted to be intergrade populations between O. nana and O. macrus in Delaware and Ottawa counties, Oklahoma, but in his recent revision of the genus, Fitzpatrick (1987) maintained specific status for these crayfishes
This species was previously assigned to P. lepidodactylus (Cooper, 1998).
Fallicambarus spectrum appears to represent only a distinctive color morph of this species and is therefore placed herein in the synonomy of it by Hobbs and Robison (1989).
This species is comprised of two subspecies: Procambarus vioscai vioscai (Penn 1946) and P. v. paynei (Fitzpatrick 1990).

Following Ortmann (1931), this species has been largely relegated to synonymy with Orconectes juvenilis (Hagen). Even Rhoades, in using the combination Orconectes putnami for the first time, considered it a synonym of O. juvenilis. Not until 1972 was it proposed that it again be accorded specific status, but its range and that of the closely allied O. spinosus have not been adequately invsetigated.

This species is no longer considered to be made up of the two subspecies commonly discussed in the literature. Jezerinac et al. (1995) reported that they are not considered true subspecies as they are not geographically restricted.
There is some difficulty in seperating  this species and P. penni as they are morphologically similar (Taylor and Adams pers. comm.2009).

This is a species complex comprising of Procambarus simulans regionmontanus (Villalobos, 1954) and Procambarus simulans simulans (Faxon, 1884). The range of this crayfish is by no means clearly defined.

The taxonomy of the subgenus Trisellescens is poorly understood, with further information the range of this species may be dramatically reduced, from that assessed here (S. Adams, G. Schuster and C. Taylor pers. comm. 2009).
This species may in fact be synonymous with P. steigmani (D. Johnson pers. comm. 2010).
Although differing populations are somewhat distinct genetically, the species is valid taxonomically (Fetzner and Crandall 1999).
This species was formerly part of a complex but is now recognized as a distinct species by Taylor (2000).

Two new species, Cambarus speleocoopi and Cambarus laconensis, have been described from Marshall County, Alabama that were formerly attributed to this species (Buhay et al. 2007, Buhay and Crandall 2009).
In 1972 Bouchard elevated this species from the genus Cambarus to Barbicambarus due to its unique characteristics (Bouchard 1972, Hobbs 1974).
This species was formerly subsumed under Cambarus acuminatus Faxon, 1884, but questioned by Hobbs and Peters (1977) and Cooper and Braswell (1995) was and subsequently resurrected by Cooper (2001).
This species is likely a species complex which potentially includes some undescribed species   (R. Thoma, T. Jones, J. Cordeiro, pers. comm. 2009).

Genetic analyses reveal that Procambarus ferrugineus is a junior synonym of this species.  In addition, nested clade phylogeographic analysis and population genetic analysis suggest this species has had three rounds of range expansion throughout inferred evolutionary history and that three potentially new cryptic species from southwestern Arkansas are currently inappropriately nested within the confines of the current description of the species (Crandall et al. 2009).  New species descriptions may be warranted (G. Schuster and C. Taylor pers. comm. 2009).
Walls (2009) considered this species to have two subspecies, O. h. hathawayi to the east, O. h. blacki to the west, with an intergrade zone between the two.

Specimens of the genus from eastern Arkansas and southeastern Missouri may represent only a local variant of Faxonella clypeata. Studies of populations in eastern Arkansas and southern Missouri are badly needed (C. Taylor, G. Schuster, pers. comm. 2009).

Procambarus hagenianus is a species complex consisting of two sub species: Procambarus hagenianus hagenianus: Southern Prairie Crayfish (Faxon, 1884) and Procambarus hagenianus vesticeps: Egyptian Crayfish Fitzpatrick 1978.

There have been problems finding the reference Fitzpatrick 1983b: 198, Figure 193.
This species is related to the Procambarus acutus species complex; these are in need of taxonomic revision (K. Crandall pers. comm. 2009).

The type of LeConte's Astacus penicillatus is no longer extant. In as much as Hagen (1870) and Faxon (1884, 1885a, 1890, and 1914) confused other species with it, and, in the latter work, Faxon included members of two species in his type series of C. barbatus (=A. penicillatus), his "Type" was designated the neotype fo LeConte's A. penicillatus to establish the identity of the latter's species (A. Eversole pers. comm. 2009).

The syntypes in the National Museum of Natural History are specimens collected by W.S. Newlon from the type locality and were received from the Kansas Museum of Natural History; presumably they represent a part of the lot that was said by Faxon (1914:420) to have been at Washburn College   (S. Adams, G. Schuster, C. Taylor, pers. comm. 2009).

This species appears to be indistinguishable from Orconectes virilis (Hagen). Further work needs to be done to distinguish between this species, O. virilis and O. nais (Hobbs 1974). In 1978, Unger presented evidence to suggest these were in fact distinct species.

Joe Fitzpatrick Jr. was working on a taxonomic revision of this species in which he believed this species was comprised of 3 other species. Through the work of Hobbs Jr, Hobbs III, and Fitzpatrick Jr., Procambarus zonagulus (Hobbs and Hobbs 1990) has already been split off; and the Mexican species Procambarus blandingii cuevachicae has been designated as a subspecies of this species (Hobbs 1967).
This species was formerly part of the Orconectes juvenilis complex (Taylor 2000).

This species has a range that overlaps that of Cambarus diogenes. Recently, recognition of  this species as a subspecies of C. diogenes is rejected, and specific rank has been afforded to it (Fetzner 2008).

The species was split into two taxa by Hobbs (1981), and Florida records are now considered to be for Procambarus talpoides. As pointed out by Faxon (1884:140), the descriptions of P. advena and C. carolinus were transposed in Hagen's monograph, and pl. 1:figs. 51-54 and pl. 3:fig. 165 are actually of P. advena. (see. Hobbs, 1981:311 for a detailed bibliography and explanation).
This species was originally described as a subspecies of Orconectes propinquus, but was elevated to a full species by Fitzpatrick (1967).
Fitzpatrick (1972) has stated that some taxonomic uncertainty exists regarding species classification, particularly with some subpopulations in this species range.

The freshwater crayfish, Orconectes difficilis, formerly had four subspecies (O. difficilis blacki, O. difficilis maletae, O. difficilis hathawayi, O. difficilis difficilis) (Walls 1985), all of which were elevated to full species status (Fitzpatrick 1987, Hobbs 1989). As such, the species currently occurs in Pittsburg and Latimer Counties, Oklahoma, into Washington County, Arkansas.  Texas records are O. maletae and Louisiana records are O. hathawayi.

This is a species complex which is currently under investigation by Dr. Chris Taylor and Professor Guenter Schuster (C. Taylor pers. comm. 2009) as there is uncertainty around whether it is a valid species, or if it is just a regional variation of Orconectes chickasawae.
This subspecies was raised to species status by Buhay and Crandall (2008).
Synonymous with Coelorinchus labiatus, however C. occa may be the separate species found in the western Atlantic (Marshall 1973)
Thalassobathia pelagica was moved from family Bythitidae to the family Ophiidae by Nielsen et al. (2010).
In the tropical Eastern Pacific, Caranx crysos is replaced by Caranx caballus (Günther 1869)

This name used to be applied to a species widely distributed in the central-west Pacific. Recently, genetic evidence indicates that this name should only be used for the Hawaiian Islands population, with the remaining populations now considered part of H. claudia (Randall & Rocha, 2009).
The taxonomy and key characteristics of Brama spp. are in need of review (FAO ECA guide in prep RL Haedrich).
There are multiple undescribed species in this group which may have been confused with this species (Moore, Polanco, Russell, McEachran pers. comm. 2013).
There is some genetic differentiation between samples from the Atlantic and those from the Mediterranean, but not at the species level (Vinas et al. 2010).

This species also seems to be sympatric with Macroramphosus gracilis around the world (Dyer and Westneat 2010). However, there is still some debate about the taxonomic separation of the two species (Granadeiro and Silva 2000). The latest research suggests that M. gracilis represents a different ontological stage of M. scolopax rather than a separate species (Robalo et al. 2009, Noguchi et al. 2015), and this approach is followed here.

However, Noguchi et al. (2016) have foreshadowed that it is likely two different species in the Atlantic and Pacific. Noting that M. scolopax was described from the Mediterranean and that M. gracilis was described from Madeira in the eastern Atlantic, there is probably an undescribed species from the Pacific. The description of this Pacific species of Macroramphosus may be forthcoming from Noguchi et al., but this needs to be confirmed with those authors.

This species has been divided into several subspecies (Shakhovskoy 2007): Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus pinnatibarbus (Bennett 1831), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus altipennis (Valenciennes 1847), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus californicus (Cooper 1863), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus japonicus (Franz 1910), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus melanocercus (Ogilby 1885).

The temporal and spatial genetic structure of this species, or species complex, is still under debate, and presents challenges for fisheries management. Clupea harengus stocks have traditionally been delineated on the basis of differences in spawning behavior and meristic or morphological characters. However, there is little concordance between these characters and genetic differentiation (André et al. 2011, Ruzzante et al. 2006, Ryman et al. 1984, Clausen et al. 2007). Morphological differences may be expressions of phenotypic plasticity resulting from early ontogentic exposure to differing environmental regimes (Anokina 1971, Aneer 1985, Rajasilta 1992). The extent to which there is genetic differentiation between NW and NE Atlantic is unresolved. 

In the NE Atlantic, there is some structuring between the population in the English Channel and that found in the remainder of the North Sea (Mariani et al. 2005). Concordant structuring has been found between the North Sea and Baltic spawning populations, and it is hypothesized that the relatively low salinity in the Baltic Sea is driving this divergence (Ruzzante et al. 2006; Bekkevold et al. 2005; Mariani et al. 2005; Larsson et al. 2007, 2010). Spring-spawning populations and autumn spawning populations within the Baltic Sea appear to differ from each other morphologically (Heincke 1898) and genetically (Jøgensen et al. 2005); however, genetic variation within the Baltic Sea is generally low (Johannesson and André 2006). Additionally, there is structuring between the northern and southern populations within the largest, most commercially important stock, the Norwegian Spring spawning stock, which is found in the Barents and Norwegian Sea (Shaw et al. 1999, Reiss et al. 2009). 

The Baltic herring Clupea harengus membras is widely regarded as subspecies of the Atlantic herring Clupea harengus. Baltic herring as a subspecies includes populations of autumn-spawning herrings mainly in the western and southern Baltic Sea and spring-spawning herring mainly in the eastern and northern parts of the sea basin. There is wide overlap in the distribution of the different forms (HELCOM Red List Project). Differences between the two forms (spatial distribution, meristic and morphometric, temporal spawning) are not supported by genetic differentiation when using either allozyme or microsatellite markers. However, some studies employing high-throughput sequencing revealed high levels of genetic differentiation at loci which may under selection, which may suggest the existence of locally adapted populations within the Baltic Sea which are connected by some gene flow (Corander et al. 2013).
Previously in Remorina, but is currently placed in Remora (Gray et al. 2009).
Specimens from the Marquesas Island lack the vertical black bars (Pyle 2001).

This species has been placed in the family Sphaeriidae, although some authors regard the Pisidium as worthy of listing as a distinct family, Pisiidae; traditionally, it is still placed as a subfamily of the Sphaeriidae.

The species has been placed in the family Sphaeriidae, although some authors regard the Pisidium as worthy of listing as a distinct family, Pisiidae; traditionally, it is still placed as a subfamily of the Sphaeriidae.

The species has been placed in the family Sphaeriidae, although some authors regard the Pisidium as worthy of listing as a distinct family Pisiidae; traditionally, however, it is still placed as a subfamily of the Sphaeriidae.

This species has been placed in the family Sphaeriidae, although some authors regard the Pisidium as worthy of listing as a distinct family, Pisiidae; however, traditionally it is still placed as a subfamily of the Sphaeriidae. Synonyms include Pisidium obtusalastrum (Woodward 1921); Pisidium scholtzi (Clessin 1973).

Kuiper et al (1989) suggests that this species occurs over all of North America, and considers that P. rotundatum (Prime) is a synonyms of P. obtusale, whereas P. ventricosum is a distinct species.  Mussel-P (viewed 2017), does not recognise P. obtusale as a North American species.
Specimens from India, Pakistan, Arabian Peninsula, Iran, Sudan, Somalia and Kenya are now referable to H. robustus (S. Baha El Din 2006; Bauer et al. 2006).
Should possibly be listed as O. haydeni kanabensis.

Interspecific hybridization of the Pacific Sleeper Shark (S. pacificus) with the Greenland Shark (S. microcephalus) has likely been ongoing at the edges of their distributions since initial divergence (Walter et al. 2017).

The name as allocated to the southern African material is provisional. Work underway suggests that there may be a tropical species from off southern Mozambique that is more similar to true T. nobiliana from the North Atlantic than to specimens from Namibia and the Cape. Work is underway to clarify the taxonomy of the Indian Ocean species.

The Red Sea population generally lacks the dark spot on the soft dorsal fin. This population has been described as the sub-species C. auriga setifer Ahl 1923. However most recent authors regard it a conspecific with C. auriga.
This species has formerly been included within Chaetodon modestus (now Roa modestus).
This species is frequently confused with Heniochus acuminatus.

Chaetodon tinkeri is here defined as comprising the Hawaiian, Johnston Atoll and Raratonga populations. The taxonomic status of populations recorded from areas in the western parts of the range needs further taxonomic research.

Very similar to Prognathus carlhubbsi, which is found in the southern part of the eastern tropical Pacific region. Genetic and morphological studies are needed to confirm whether specifically distinct from P. carlhubbsi.
Widely cited in the literature as Chaetodon trifasciatus, a species now regarded as being restricted to the Indian Ocean and Coral Triangle.
Indian Ocean records west of Coco-Keeling, Christmas Island and Java are based on the sister species Chaetodon interruptus.

The entire population in Bermuda, Florida Keys, and the east coast of Florida may consist of hybrids between this species and Holacanthus ciliaris (L. Rocha pers. comm. 2009).

H. bermudensis and H. passer may, in fact, be sister species (thus potentially breaking up the subgenera Plitops and Angelichthys) (Alva-Campbell et al. 2010)
Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean populations may represent separate species.
Holacanthus ciliaris are closely related to blue angelfish Holacanthus bermudensis Goode, and colouration is the only reliable character to separate these species (Feeley et al. 2009).
This species has recently been differentiated from its sister species Orconectes virilis based on recent molecular studies and minor gonadal morphology (Mathews and Warren 2008, Mathews et al. 2008).

It was described from Java, Indonesia (type locality). What is currently recognized as Monopterus albus is almost certainly a species complex, and the taxonomic identity of the eastern Himalayan subpopulation needs to be validated.

Anodonta japonica (Von Martens 1874) is part of this species complex, however, there is no available information for this synonym. Anodonta lauta and A. calipygos were treated as separate species by Kondo (2008). A large number (103 at present) of synonyms of this species have been described (see MUSSELp; Graf and Cummings 2011).

There are two recognized subspecies for the species. Panulirus argus argus is found north of the equator and Panulirus argus westonii is found south of the equator in Brazil, however this is an invalid name (Sarver, Silberman and Walsh, 1998).

In Hawaii this species has many common names including: Royal Slipper Lobster, King's Hawaiian Lobster, Shovel-nosed Lobster, Spanish Lobster and Ula-papapa (Holthuis 1991).

This species very closely resembles A. guineensis, and at one time they were believed to be conspecific (Holthuis 2006).
Justitia mauritiana is now a synonym of this species.

The Pacific Chub Mackerel (Scomber japonicus) has a Pacific distribution,and is replaced in the Atlantic by Scomber colias (Scoles et al. 1998, Collette 1999). Microsatellite and mitochondrial cyt b confirm that Scomber australasicus and S. japonicus are also separate species (Tzeng et al. 2009). Scomber japonicus is apparently absent from Indonesia and Australia, where it is replaced by Scomber australasicus (Collette 2001). The population from the Red Sea and northern Indian Ocean (the Gulf of Aden and Oman) is Scomber australasicus (Baker and Collette 1998).
Confused with the eastern Atlantic T. belone until described as a distinct species by Robins and de Sylva (1963).
Previously, this species was included in the genus Tetrapturus (Collette et al. 2006).
This species previously was included in the genus Makaira (Collette et al. 2006).

Blue Marlin (Makaira nigricans) of the Indo-Pacific and the Atlantic are conspecific (Buonaccorsi et al. 1999, 2001; Collette et al. 2006). The Indo-Pacific Blue Marlin previously was known as Makaira mazara (Jordan and Snyder).

This species was previously known as Tetrapturus albidus (Collette et al. 2006). There is a question as to whether this species is distinct from the Pacific Striped Marlin, Kajikia audax (Graves 1998, Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011).

Three species have often been confused with S. maculatus, namely: Scomberomorus tritor in the eastern Atlantic; S. sierra in the eastern Pacific; and S. brasiliensis in the Caribbean and along the Atlantic coast of South America.
Sometimes this species has been erroneously considered a synonym of the western Atlantic Scomberomorus maculatus.
Recent genetic information suggests that this species is one highly connected population worldwide (Garber et al. 2005, Theisen et al. 2008).
Although the most distinct genetically of the four species of spearfishes (Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011), this species was only recently confirmed as a valid species (Shivji et al. 2006).

There is no genetic evidence in the mtDNA control region to indicate that the Atlantic (Istiophorus albicans) and Indo-Pacific (Istiophorus platypterus) Sailfishes are separate species (Collette et al. 2006). However, there are two distinct mtDNA clades, both evident in the Atlantic while only one is found in the Indo-Pacific (McDowell 2002). There is also no difference in pectoral fin length or in any other morphometric or meristic characters between Atlantic and Indo-Pacific populations of sailfish (Morrow and Harbo 1969, McDowell 2002). There is no evidence that the Atlantic and Mediterranean populations are separate species (B. Collette pers. comm 2014).
Prior to 1960, many authors have used the name Auxis thazard as including Auxis rochei in the belief that there was only a single worldwide species of Auxis.
Auxis rochei rochei (Risso, 1810) is worldwide except for the eastern tropical Pacific where it is replaced by A. r. eudorax Collette and Aadland, 1996.

This species is frequently misidentified as juvenile or female of Coryphaena hippurus.

The specific name is sometimes misspelled as equisetis instead of equiselis (Gibbs and Collette 1959).

Two subspecies are recognized: Sarda chiliensis lineolata occurs from Alaska to the tip of Baja California and the southwest Gulf of California, and the Revillagigedo Islands. Sarda chiliensis chiliensis occurs from Ecuador to Chile (Collette and Chao 1975).

Before 1960, many researchers thought that there was only one world-wide species in the genus Auxis, which was recorded as Auxis thazard (Collette and Aaland, 1996).

The species contains two subspecies;  A. rochei rochei (Risso, 1810) worldwide except for the eastern tropical Pacific where it is replaced by A. r. eudorax Collette and Aadland, 1996.
This species is now recognized as distinct from the Indo-Pacific Scomber japonicus (Collette 1999, Infante et al. 2007).

Megalonaias boykiniana was synonymized under this species by Mulvey et al. (1997).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Hemidactylus frenatus was first described by Dumeril and Bibron in 1836 based on specimens from Java (Brygoo 1991). Fitzinger (1826) used the name Hemidactylus javanicus but as no description or diagnosis was provided, the nomen is considered as nomen nudum (Bauer 1994).

Thomas Say originally described Unio cicatricosus in 1829. Isaac Lea described Unio varicosus later the same year. Both names were widely used in the literature; however, varicosus Lea was pre-occupied by varicosus Lamarck, 1819. Frierson (1911) synonomized Unio cicatricosus Say with Unio aesopus Green, 1827 (= Plethobasus cyphyus Rafinesque, 1820) and renamed Lea's shell as Unio detectus Frierson, 1911. He also named two additional species Unio cicatricoides and Unio comptertus as being part of this complex. In 1919, Ortmann synonomized all of Frierson's names under cicatricosus Say. Three years later Ortmann and Walker (1922) sunk cicatricosus into cyphyus. Recent authors have not followed Ortmann and Walker (1922) and recognize Plethobasus cicatricosus as distinct (Parmalee 1967, Bogan and Parmalee 1983, Cummings and Mayer 1992, Turgeon et al. 1998, Williams et al. 2008).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
Plethodon hubrichti and P. shenandoah formerly were included in this species.
This species is morphologically somewhat similar to Plethodon elongatus, however they are genetically distinct (Mahoney 2001, Mead et al. 2005).
This species is sometimes considered to be conspecific with Plethodon ouachitae, with which it integrades freely in its narrow zone of contact.
Petranka (1998) included Plethodon fourchensis in this species. The two species integrade freely in their narrow zone of contact.
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site  (Graf and Cummings 2011).
In an unpublished study of molecular systematics, Campbell and Harris (2006) found this species seems to fall genetically within the range of variation of Pleurocera canaliculata.

Attention RLU: This species is now valid as Myzopsetta ferruginea, and this should be reflected in SIS.  This species was previously referred to as Pleuronectes ferrugineus, then Limanda ferruginea, and is now placed in the genus Myzopsetta (Vinnikov et al. 2018).

Robertson and Allen (2006) treat the Eastern Pacific population as a separate species. However, the taxonomy of this group is in need of revision and the Eastern Pacific population may in fact belong to the circumglobal species Lobotes surinamensis.

Frequently misidentified as Albula vulpes, an Atlantic species. It has also been previously identified as A. neoguinaica (a synonym of the Indo-central Pacific species A. forsteri). However, genetic data indicate the eastern Pacific form is a separate species (Colborn et al. 2001), for which A. esuncula is the oldest name. There is recent genetic evidence that this species may in fact represent two species: Albula esuncula from south of Mazatlan, Mexico, and a yet to be named Albula species from Southern California to Mazatlan (Pfeiler et al. 2008).

Largest museum collection of this species is held at the University of Michigan under the supervision of Dr Theodore Cohn (tcohn@sunstroke.sdsu.edu). Still undescribed, but genus is currently under revision.
The NatureServe NatureExplorer database lists this as Procambarus conus.

This species is one of several troglobitic species in the subgenus Ortmannicus. It is highly distinctive, and its closest affinities are with Procambarus delicatus, which appears to be on a line leading to Troglocambarus (J. Cordeiro, T. Jones and R. Thoma pers. comm. 2009).
Additional taxonomic study is needed to better differentiate this species from the similar Procambarus spiculifer, which occurs in the drainage immediately adjacent (GA DNR, pers. comm., 2009).

From a study conducted by Buhay and Crandall (2009) Procambarus pecki has been transferred from the subgenus Remoticambarus of the genus Procambarus, to the subgenus Aviticambarus of the genus Cambarus. This has been based on genetic studies which more accurately reflect its evolutionary history.

This crayfish is very closely related to Procambarus regalis and the two may be synonymous. The only differences noted by Hobbs are slight differences in the symmetry of the gonopods and differences in tuberculation of the annulus ventralis (D. Johnson pers. comm. 2010).
This species was previously considered as Eucinostomus argenteus.

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species in Kyphosidae, as well as one Neoscorpis, which is considered a distinct genus within Kyphosidae. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix. Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis. K. pacificus/sandwicensis is a synonym of K. elegans. Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there are in fact four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis/incisor, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens.
Previously this species has sometimes been referred to as Caranx hippos.

This species may represent two species given that no records known between them. Proposed names are Xenistius californiensis from southern California to the Gulf of California, and Xenistius peruanus from Lobos Islands Peru to central Peru (Roberston pers. comm.).
Separate species for Scorpaena mystes and S. plumieri is more commonly accepted.
This species was at once placed in the genus Hypsopsetta, and is still treated as such by some authors. However, the genus was changed back to Pleuronichthys by Cooper and Chapleau (1998).
This species is also known as Eucinostomus californiensis, but E. gracilis is apparently the senior synonym.
This species is also more commonly known as Caranx caballus. This species is probably a junior synonym of Caranx crysos.
Specimens from central Mexico have been assigned to this species, but require confirmation and are not included here.
Trachurus murphyi which occurs in the southern part of this region is the sister species of T. symmetricus.
More information should be obtained from Pietch and Grobecker (1987).
This species was previously considered to be a subspecies of the Atlantic species Fodiator acutus (Parin and Belyanina 2002).

The H. rondeletii superspecies complex of the subgenus Danichthys is now recognized as containing four allopatric species: H. volador (western Atlantic), H. rondeletii (Mediterranean), H. gilberti (northern Pacific), and H. rufipinnis (Southern Hemisphere). The other two species, Hirundichthys marginatus (eastern tropical Pacific) and H. albimaculatus(west & central Pacific) are both distinct species in the subgenus, but are not part of the rondeletii superspecies complex (Parin and Belyanina 2002, B. Collette pers. comm. 2014).
This species seems to have two forms or subspecies: Harengula thrissina thrissina from the Gulf of California to Panama and Harengula thrissina peruana from Panama to Peru (Watson and Sandknop 1996).
One form from California has been recognized as a distinct subspecies (Bohlke 1952).
References to this species prior to 2001 are to Hyporhamphus unifasciatus which is a western Atlantic species (Banford and Collette 2001).
Genetic studies indicate difference between Gulf of California and coastal Californian populations.
Also known as Encheliophis dubius.

Some specimens of this species were incorrectly labelled as Scyllarus martensii (Holthuis 2002).

This species is referred to as Scyllarus modestus in Holthuis (1991).

From morphological analyses the two subspecies, Chelarctus cultrifer cultrifer and C. cultrifer meridionalis (Holthuis, 1960) have been abandoned in favour of a single species (Chan 1997, Holthuis 2002).
Synonyms: Arctus depressus (S.I. Smith, 1881); S. nearctus (Holthuis, 1960).
Synonyms: Arctus americanus (S.I. Smith, 1869), Scyllarus gundlachi (Von Martens, 1872).
This species includes Scyllarides tumidus of Colin & Arneson (1995).
This species was split by Holthuis 1960 into S. chacei and S. americanus, as previous specimens have had some confusion between these two species.

authority: Camp, Peterman, Milanovich, Lamb, Maerz & Wake, 2009
taxonomicNotes: This is a monotypic genus (Camp et al. 2009).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Gomon and Randall (1978) recognized B. albotaeniatus as a subspecies of B. bilunulatus but Gomon (2006) regarded it as a separate species (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species is replaced by Coris cuvieri in most parts of the Indian Ocean (D. Pollard pers. comm.. 2009).
Tautogolabrus brandaonis is a synonym of T. adspersus. The record from Brazil is erroneous (P. Parenti pers. Comm. In Eschmeyer 2007, R. Moura pers. comm. 2008).
For taxonomic treatment see Russell (1985). Record of this species from NW Australia may be Suezichthys cyanolaemus (Kuiter 2002).
This species was thought to occur South to Brazil, but genetic research revealed that Brazilian populations belong to a different species (Rocha 2004).
A hybrid between Gomphosus varius x T. Lunare was found in Solomon Islands (Allen 2006).

This species was thought to occur along the Brazilian coast, but recent genetic research revealed that coastal Brazilian populations belong to a different species (Rocha 2004).

Several endemic species of the Brazilian province have been taxonomically revised and are now validated as Halichoeres penrosei (previously recorded as H. maculipinna) (Pinherio et al. 2009).

H. maculipinna  is closer to Thalassoma than to any other Halichoeres (Rocha et al. 2010)
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006). Previously identified as Verreo oxycephalus (B. Russell pers. comm.. 2008).

For taxonomic treatment see Ayling and Russell (1977) and Randall and Randall (1981). Kuiter (2002) suggests W. Indian Ocean specimens may be distinct (B. Russell pers. comm. 2008). This species previously appeared on the Red List under the mis-spelling Pseudojuloides ceracinus.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).
This species is replaced by Thalassoma grammaticum in the tropical Eastern Pacific.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002).

Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus and I. verrens.

Halichoeres sazimai, n. sp. is described from the Western South Atlantic. During many years it was misidentified as H. bathyphilus from the Northwestern Atlantic, but it can be distinguished from the latter by striking color differences between the two species, with H. sazimai being characterized by a white body with a midline, zigzag patterned stripe on body, black and brownish in terminal males and yellow or golden in females and juveniles (Luiz et al. 2009).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

The latent slingjaw wrasse, Epibulus brevis, was recently described from Palau, Philippines, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia (Carlson et al. 2008). E. brevis is extremely similar to E. insidiator and any past record and data of E. insidiator likely includes the former species.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
This species was thought to occur along the Brazilian coast, but genetic research revealed that coastal Brazilian populations belong to a different species (Rocha 2004).
Thompson (2000) lists Elimia gerhardti as a junior synonym of the resurrected Elimia modesta (Lea, 1845).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of confusion. Johnson (1970) lumped many named taxa under a single name. Current research is finding many of these synonomized taxa to be valid species. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

There are numerous synonyms of Elliptio buckleyi (see Johnson 1972), some of which, given genetic studies, might prove distinct. Possibly large genetic differences exist between populations in same habitats in different drainages (Kat and Davis 1984). There are two morphological forms of this species that appear distinct if only a limited number of samples are examined. There is a dark, thick morph with the umbo far forward and a pronounced dorsal ridge. By contrast there is a polished, thinner morph with more central umbos and a less pronounced ridge - this morph is often brightly rayed. The former was given the names Unio cunninghami (Wright 1883), and Unio tenuisculus (Frierson 1911). But Lea's Unio buckleyi is a large eroded specimen of this morph from the northern part of the range and is the earliest name for this species. The polished morph has recieved several names as well: fryanus, orcuttii, and dorei (Wright 1888), and hartii and sanctorumjohanium (Wright 1933). The two morphs intergrade completely with each other and are not sympatric. The dark morph tends to occur in the larger lakes and impounded portions of large rivers: Lake Okeechobee, Tiger Lake, Lake Monroe, etc. The polished, rayed morph is common in the numerous small lakes and small rivers scattered throughout central Florida. At this time, all morphological forms are subsumed under the single species, Elliptio buckleyi.

Other synonyms also include Unio hinkleyi (Wright, 1888), Unio ferrissii (Marsh, 1891), Unio subluridus (Simpson, 1892), Unio caloosaensis (Dall, 1898) and Unio (Elliptio) webbianus (Wright, 1934).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The species-level taxonomic history of the genus Amblema is complicated because numerous nominal species and varieties of Amblema plicata were described from the upper Mississippi and Ohio rivers (Mulvey et al. 1997), and Conrad (1841) described an additional species, A. perplicata, from streams in Louisiana (Mississippi River drainage). For decades the name perplicata has been applied as a subspecies name to A. plicata from Gulf Coast drainages from Florida west to Texas. Previously A. elliottii also was referred to as A. plicata perplicata. Based on DNA sequence data, Mulvey et al. (1997) distinguished A. elliottii from both A. plicata and A. neisleri and gave it species-level status.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Clench and Turner (1956) considered E. crassidens incrassatus (Lea, 1840) to be distinct from E. crassidens crassidens. All subsequent authors have synonomyzed incrassatus with crassidens.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

A recent Dreissenid molecular phylogeny using COI and 16S sequences (Therriault et al. 2004) concluded that Dreissena bugensis and D. rostriformis actually represent distinct races of a single species (sequence divergence was 0.23 - 0.54%, comparable to intraspecific variability in other species). The authors recommended the ancestral name D. rostriformis be used, with two races, bugensis and distincta (Therriault et al. 2004, Orlova et al. 2005). However, there is still confusion over this.

This species is also regarded by some as a subspecies of the invasive Zebra Mussel D. polymorpha (M. Seddon pers. comm. 2009).

The ICZN (1999, opinion 1896) fixed Buccinum truncatulum Muller, 1774 as the type species of the nominal genus Galba Schrank, 1803; it also placed Galba Schrank, 1803 on the Official List of Species Names in Zoology, thereby replacing the current usage of the name Fossaria Westerlund, 1885, which now a junior objective synonym. 

In Europe Falkner et al. (2001) use Galba based on ICZN opinion 1896, whereas in North American Fossaria was used for this genus (Turgeon et al., 1998).  The latest publication on the conservation status of the North America Gastropods (Johnson et al., 2013) used Galba for the genus in North America, thus the IUCN Red List is now following this convention and all species previously recognised as Fossaria are now in genus Galba.

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. Johnson (1970) grouped many named taxa under a single name. Current research is finding many of these synonomized taxa to be valid species. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. Johnson (1970) synonymized this species under Elliptio complanata, but Turgeon et al. (1998) and Graf and Cummings (2007) include both as distinct species. Recently seven sites were located throughout the Pee Dee River drainage in South Carolina (Catena Group 2006) where it was clearly distinguishable from other forms of Elliptio complanata. At some sites within the Lynches River, the box spike was lumped into Elliptio spp. as gradation between forms, and time constraints made separation difficult.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species taxonomic classification is uncertain. This species is likely to be a synonyn of Campeloma decisum (Burch and Jung 1992, Johnson 1992) although Turgeon et al. (1998) list it as questionably valid.

This species was considered a subspecies of Villosa vibex by Clench and Turner (1956). Despite its limited distribution, several nominal forms exist, a trait that is consistent for other species occupying peninsular Florida (e.g., Elliptio buckleyi and Uniomerus caroliniana).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Baker (1945) listed this species as a subspecies of Micromenetus dilatatus. However, Thompson (1999) believed the two were separate species due to sympatric coexistence without interbreeding. A molecular phylogeny (using COI and 18S markers) of global Planorboidea indicated that all North American Planorbinae fall within a monophyletic clade (Albrecht et al. 2007).
This species was formerly regarded as a synomym of Fluminicola turbiniformis (Taylor, 1966), but is considered a valid species by Hershler and Frest (1996).

Recently, Zanatta et al. (2007) supported the monophyly of both Pyganodon and Utterbackia using mutation coding of allozyme data, but also resolved the Eurasian Anodonta cygnea to Pyganodon, Utterbackia, and North American Anodonta; this indicates further phylogenetic analysis of the Anodontinae is required, including both North American and Eurasian species. 

In a phylogenetic analysis of western North American Anodonta using topotypic material as was available, Chong et al. (2008) found three deeply divided lineages: one clade including Anodonta oregonensis and Anodonta kennerlyi, one clade including Anodonta californiensis and Anodonta nuttalliana, and one clade including Anodonta beringiana. Chong et al. (2008) further found that A. beringiana is more closely allied with the Asian Anodonta woodiana than either of the other two western North American clades. The Russian authors place this species into the genus Beringiana (Strabogatov and Zatrawkin 1983) as its type species (Zatrawkin and Bogatov 1987, Kantor et al. 2009). Perhaps this is in accordance with the results of Chong et al. (2008). Anodonta youkonensis (Lea, 1867) is an important synonym to note (M. Vinarski pers. comm. 2011).

Based on analysis of the gene sequences, Bogan et al. (2008) argue for the elevation of the subgenus Pressodonta (Simpson, 1900) to create the new combination Pressodonta viridis. However, this work is awaiting publication in a peer-reviewed journal.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. Johnson (1970) lumped many named taxa under a single name. Current research is finding many of these synonomized taxa to be valid species. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. Elliptio errans was synonymized under Elliptio complanata by Johnson (1970, 1972) and Britton and Fuller (1979). Based on genetic data, Davis and Mulvey (1993) recognized E. errans as a species distinct from Elliptio icterina, a taxonomic status consistent with Turgeon et al. (1998).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Dillon et al. (2006) believe Campeloma regulare, Campeloma geniculatum, and Campeloma limum are synonymous with Campeloma decisum because there appear to be no reliable distinguishable morphological characters between them (see Johnson 2000).

Taxonomic confusion surrounds two morphologically similar species: Alasmidonta undulata and Alasmidonta triangulata. Historically, specimens assigned to A. undulata were identified as A. triangulata. Graf and Cummings (2007) classify them as separate species and A. undulata is considered the sister species to Alasmidonta arcula (Bogan et al. 2008).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Genetic examination of the molecular phylogeny of the global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American ancylid taxa form a well-supported clade, the Bulinini (Albrecht et al. 2007). The species name Ferrissia californica precedes Ferrissia fragilis (Taylor 1981), but the American Fisheries Society (Turgeon et al. 1998) publication lists fragilis; hopefully this will be rectified in the next edition. Ferrissia hendersoni is considered by some to be a junior synonym of Ferrissia fragilis (see Basch 1963, Dillon et al. 2006).

This species was previously recorded as Quadrula nodulata, but is now known as Amphinaias nodulata (Graf and Cummings 2007).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Chambers (1990) synonymized Elimia albanyensis, Elimia athearni, and Elimia catanoides with Elimia boykiniana based on the constancy of the shape of the outer lip of the aperture and old museum lots consisting of shells exhibiting a range of variation.

The ICZN (1999, opinion 1896) fixed Buccinum truncatulum Muller, 1774 as the type species of the nominal genus Galba Schrank, 1803; it also placed Galba Schrank, 1803 on the Official List of Species Names in Zoology, thereby replacing the current usage of the name Fossaria Westerlund, 1885, which now a junior objective synonym. 

In Europe Falkner et al. (2001) use Galba based on ICZN opinion 1896, whereas in North American Fossaria was used for this genus (Turgeon et al., 1998).  The latest publication on the conservation status of the North America Gastropods (Johnson et al., 2013) used Galba for the genus in North America, thus the IUCN Red List is now following this convention and all species previously recognised as Fossaria are now in genus Galba.

The Galba bulimoides group is in flux (Burch 1989; Hubendick, 1951) with species variably recognised as forms, varieties subspecies or full species.

Dillon et al. (2006) follows Hubendick (1951) in placing this species in the genus Lymnaea, with Fossaria as a subspecies.  The analysis of the prostate surface, preputium and penis sheath lengths and the anterior and posterior width of the penis sheath allow a clear separation between Galba cubensis and Galba truncatula (Samadi et al. 2000), so G. cubensis is a distinct species, not a synonym of G. truncatula.

This species was originally described in the genus Alasmidonta by Say in 1829, from the Fox River - an arm of the Wabash in southern Illinois. It has also previously been placed in the genera Margaritana, Complanaria, Baphia and Unio. The morphology of the shell suggests a relationship to Arcidens wheeleri, both of which where placed in Arcidens by Graf and Cummings (2007). Similar species include Amblema plicata and Megalonaias nervosa (NatureServe 2009).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. Johnson (1970) grouped many named taxa under a single name. Based on genetic data, Davis and Mulvey (1993) recognized E. lugubris as a species distinct from Elliptio icterina, a taxonomic status consistent with Turgeon et al. (1998). The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain at this time (A. Bogan pers. comm. 2010).

This species name has changed from Elliptio lugubris (I. Lea 1834) [preoccupied name].

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Genetic examination of the molecular phylogeny of global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American taxa within the subfamily Planorbinae form a well-supported clade, which is as yet unnamed but referred to as the C-Clade (Albrecht et al. 2007). This species is sometimes referred to as Biomphalaria obstructa (Morelet 1849), a likely synonym.

In Europe Falkner et al. (2001) use Galba whereas in North American Fossaria was used for this genus (Turgeon et al., 1998).  The latest publication on the conservation status of the North America Gastropods (Johnson et al., 2013) used Galba for the genus in North America, thus the IUCN Red List is now following this convention and all species previously recognised as Fossaria are now in genus Galba.

The Galba bulimoides group is in flux (Burch 1989; Hubendick, 1951) with species variably recognised as forms, varieties subspecies or full species.
This species was formerly in the genus Lampsilis (Roe and Hartfield 2005).

Corbicula is a notoriously variable taxon, therefore this species' taxonomy is in need of revision (T. V. Rintelen pers. comm. 2011). This species is possibly a form of Corbicula japonica (D.V Damme pers. comm. 2011).

Sequence analysis of mitochondrial DNA revealed two divergent clades, one consisting of specimens located throughout the upper and lower Mississippi River drainages and the Red River (Canada) and Lake Erie drainages as well as all Fusconaia cerina specimens (the study utilised material from the Sipsey River, Alabama, and Yellow Creek, Mississippi); and one consisting of specimens located in the far western portion of the range that may comprise an undescribed species, although the authors admit more morphological and genetic studies are needed to determine the precise taxonomic status of this latter clade (Burdick and White 2007).

Synonyms include Unio undatus (Barnes, 1823), Unio rubiginosus (Lea, 1829) and Unio trigonus (Lea, 1831). A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species was formerly listed as Fontigens obtusa (Lea, 1841), a preoccupied name by Paludina obtusa Troschel, 1837; but was renamed (Morrison, 1947). There is some question as to whether it is actually a misidentification for Probythinella lacustris (Hershler et al. 1990).

There is some confusion as to whether Planorbella hornii is a valid species or in fact a subspecies. Kantor et al. (2009) is the only reference found to mention Planorbella hornii. Dall (1905) discusses Planorbis hornii, but it is not clear as to whether he is referring to it as a species or as a variety of P. trivolvis. Dall (1905) goes on to mention the similarity between P. hornii and P. subcrenatus which he lists as a synonym of P. trivolvis. Henderson and Daniels (1917) discuss the subspecies Planorbis trivolvis hornii, found in Newton Town Reservoir, Clarkston, Utah. Oliver and Bosworth (1999) make reference to P. trivolvis hornii but only in the context of referring to Henderson and Daniels' (1917) work. For the purpose of this assessment, we follow the taxonomy as set out by Kantor et al. (2009) and are treating the species as currently valid.

Genetic examination of the molecular phylogeny of global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American taxa within the subfamily Planorbinae form a well-supported clade, as yet unnamed, but termed C-Clade (Albrecht et al. 2007).
Clarke (1981) lists Valvata sincera as Valvata sincera helicoidea and Valvata lewisi as Valvata sincera sincera (see Burch 1989).

Two populations of Elimia simplex were included in the allozyme study of Dillon and Davis (1980) - the Reed Creek population mentioned above and a population from a tributary of the Middle Fork Holston River perhaps 10 km west. These populations were nearly identical at ten loci. Five additional populations were surveyed by Dillon and Robinson (2007), including a sample from the type locality of the species in the North Fork Holston River at Saltville, Virginia.

This species can be confused with Elimia herhardti, Elimia carinifera, and what was formerly Elimia bentoniensis in the Coosa River basin and Elimia bellacrenata and Elimia cahawbensis in the Cahaba River basin if shells are old or obscured with algal growth, but otherwise easily separated (Bogan and Pierson 1993). Support exists for separation of this species into one or more species (see Thompson 2000).

Three subspecies have been described: Elimia potosiensis crandalli (Pilsbry 1890), restricted to Mammoth Springs, AR; E.p. ozarkensis (Call 1886), known from springs in several MO counties; and E. p. plebeius (Gould 1851), the most widespread, occurring in the Ozarkian region of MO, AR, and OK (Christian 2007).
This species appears to intergrade with Pleurocera canaliculata in middle/upper reaches of the Tennessee River.

This species was originally described as Unio pullus (Conrad 1838). The Savannah River population was once described as a separate species, Carunculina patrickae (Bates 1966), due to different shell morphology.

Carunculina patrickae was synonymized with C. pullus by Johnson (1970), and is now known as Toxolasma pullus.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species was known as Quadrula pustulosa, but was changed to Amphinaias pustulosa (Graf and Cummings 2007). Other synonyms include Unio schoolcraftensis Lea, 1831, and Unio nodiferus Conrad, 1841.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The genus Marstonia formerly was relegated to synonymy with Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987). But Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species and assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia (J. Cordiero pers. comm. 2010).

This species was formerly regarded as a subspecies of Viviparus georgianus. The taxonomic debates have been ongoing, and the allozyme study of Katoh and Foltz (1994) has suggested that populations referred to Viviparus georgianus in Florida may represent three cryptic species: two species from the panhandle Viviparus goodrichi and Viviparus limi and Viviparus georgianus (s.s.) further east. 
As Johnson et al (2013) and Thompson (2004) both list V. limi as a valid species, the species is assessed here.
There may also be a nomenclatural issue, as Pilsbry described Viviparus limi from the Flint River, a tributary of the Apalachicola, near Albany, Georgia (Thompson 1999), whereas the current study limits the species range to the Ochloconee River.

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. Johnson (1970) lumped many named taxa under a single name. Current research is finding many of these synonomized taxa to be valid species. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. Johnson (1970) listed this species as a synonym of Elliptio lanceolata but Turgeon et al. (1998) included both as distinct species.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
Falkner et al. (2001) use Galba to maintain taxonomic stability between European and North American species of this genus.

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of confusion. Johnson (1970) lumped many named taxa under a single name. Current research is finding many of these synonomized taxa to be valid species. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. In an unpublished study of molecular systematics, Campbell and Harris (2006) found high genetic distance from other Elliptio species.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The genus Marstonia was formerly relegated to the synonomy of Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987), but Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia. Dillon et al. (2006) tentatively synonymize Marstonia castor with Marstonia halcyon claiming the two are "strikingly similar".
This species has an undetermined conservation status in Alberta due to "lack of taxonomic clarity" and the possibility that it is a variant of S. elodes (Prescott and Curteanu 2004).

Recent surveys of this species across western USA found no morphologically similar specimens to the holotype, which is from Mexico. This suggests that individuals thought to be Valvata humeralis from the US may be a different species, and V. humeralis may actually be restricted to Mexico (Hovingh 2004, Miller et al. 2006). Hovingh (2004) proposed that US specimens be renamed V. californica. However, this assessment follows the previously established view of a US/Mexican distribution until further confirmation of the taxonomic status.

Chambers (1990) synonymizes this taxon under Elimia floridensis based on electrophoretic data and on the existence of a population in the Econfina River, Bay Co., Florida, that is intermediate in shell features between Clench and Turner's (1956) description of Goniobasis floridensis and Goniobasis clenchi.

The type description of this species is in Baker (1928). Taylor (2003) changed to the genus to Physella, but this is not widely accepted. Wethington and Lydeard (2007) included Archiphysa and two other genera within the Physa gyrina group in a 16S and COI molecular phylogeny.
This species is possibly a synonym of another thiarid species (Cowie 1998).

Despite the long-standing recognition of this taxon as a valid species, it has been suggested that multiple existing taxa (montanensis, idahoensis and apicina) are synonyms of Stagnicola catascopium (Stagliano et al. 2007). S. montanensis is difficult to distinguish from some related species, especially S. caperata, with which it is sympatric in Utah (Stagliano et al. 2007).

There is uncertainty as to the classification of this species and other members of the genus Juga. Only anatomical and morphological systematics have been conducted on this group (Strong and Frest 2007); further molecular studies are needed to resolve these uncertainties.

Thompson and Hershler (1991) elevated Lyogyrus from the status of a subgenus of Amnicola to full generic rank. There is some question as to whether Lyogyrus retromargo is a junior synonym of Lyogyrus granum (Dillon et al. 2006).

Shared phenotypes and lack of significant differences in gene frequencies at two polymorphic allozyme-encoding loci from populations of Elimia clavaeformis and Pleurocera unciale at Indian Creek and the Powell River, Claiborne Co., Tennessee, indicating Pleurocera unciale (Haldeman, [October] 1841)may be a junior synonym of Elimia clavaeformis (Lea, [February] 1841), the heavier shell of the former a possible result of environmental influence (Dillon and Robinson, 2007).
This is likely a composite species, according to a recent unpublished DNA phylogeny (NatureServe 2009).
Various subspecies exist, although they may need revision (Frest 1999, cited in NatureServe 2009).
This species is possibly a synonym of another thiarid species (Cowie 1998).

Jackiewicz (1998), states that there are several problems concerning the nomenclature of the family Lymnaeidae, and that there is probably no other snail group in such taxonomical disarray. Stagnicola has been used as a synonym for Lymnaea by various authors, and as a subgenus of Lymnaea by others (Ponder and Waterhouse 1997, Vinarski 2003, NatureServe 2009). Mozley (1928) lists this species as Lymnaea traskii, but NatureServe (2009) lists this species as Stagnicola traski.

In Taylor (1981) this species is listed as part of the Lymnaea (Stagnicola) palustris species complex. In addition to Lymnaea traski, Taylor includes Lymnaea proxima (Lea, 1856), Limnophysa tryoni (Tryon, 1865), Lymnaea tryoniana (Lea, 1867), Lymnaea gabbi (Tryon, 1865), Lymnaea rowelli (Tryon, 1865), Lymnaea californica (Sowerby, 1872), Lymnaea interstriata (Sowerby, 1872), Lymnaea leai (Baker, 1907) and Stagnicola palustris magister (Baker, 1934) within the complex.
Somatogyrus are difficult to be positively identified, due to the morphological similarities between the currently described species. Therefore classification of this species is uncertain.
This species has not been synonymized and appears to be a valid species.

The classification of this species is uncertain. Genetic examination of molecular phylogeny of global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American taxa within the subfamily Planorbinae form a well-supported clade, as yet unnamed, but termed C-Clade (Albrecht et al. 2007).
This species' taxonomic authority is listed as Taylor, 2003. A.G. Smith collected the species in 1967, but did not describe it.

This species was formerly known as Anodonta lacustris and was described by Lea in 1852. Although this species does not occur in Graf and Cummings 2007, Hoeh distinguished this as Pyganodon lacustris in 1990.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Sibirenauta pictus is regarded as a junior synonym of S. sibirica by Starabogatov et al. (1989, cited in Kantor et al. 2009) which is “distributed in subarctic and arctic areas of Asia, from Yenissei mouth to Chukotka.” There is also some question as to whether this is a form or subspecies of Aplexa (=Sibirenauta) elongata (NatureServe 2009).
This species was placed in the genus Stenophysa by Taylor (2003), but subsequent molecular analyses included it within the family Physidae and genus Physa (Wethington and Lydeard 2007).

The genus Marstonia was formerly relegated to the synonomy of Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987), but Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia.

The genus Marstonia formerly was relegated to synonymy with Pyrgulopsis by Hershler and Thompson (1987). But Thompson and Hershler (2002) later re-evaluated eastern North American species and assigned to Pyrgulopsis and recognized them as distinct species of the genus Marstonia (J. Cordiero pers. comm. 2010).

Morphological analyses support the view that L. fisheri represents a distinct species (Jennings et al. 1995). Subpopulations from central Arizona and western New Mexico previously attributed to L. chiricahuensis are now allocated to this species on the basis of mtDNA analysis, thus resurrecting the species from extinction (Hekkala et al. 2011).

Yellow-legged frog populations previously recognized as this species have now been reallocate to Rana sierrare. Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined the phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

There has been historical confusion and controversy regarding the taxonomic status of various leopard frog populations in the region occupied by Lithobates onca (Jaeger et al. 2001). The Vegas Valley leopard frog, R. fisheri, (now considered extinct) previously was regarded as a subspecies of R. onca. Jennings et al. (1995) conducted morphological comparisons and concluded that R. fisheri and R. onca are distinct species. Jaeger et al. (2001) examined variation in mtDNA and morphology and concluded that certain leopard frog populations in the Virgin River/Black Canyon (Colorado River) region represent a species (R. onca) distinct from the lowland leopard frog (R. yavapaiensis). This species was moved from the genus Rana to Lithobates by Frost et al. (2006).
Rana luteiventris was previously included in this species before being elevated to species status by Green et al. (1996, 1997).
Some systematists doubt that Lithobates subaquavocalis is distinct from L. chiricahuensis.

According to Fernholm and Wheeler (1983), four specimens in the Naturhistoriska Riksmuseet (Swedish Museum of Natural History) are probably the original material examined by Linnaeus (1758) to describe the species and they should be accorded type status.

The western North Atlantic population was at one time assigned to a separate species, Myxine limosa Girard (1859), and Wisner and McMillan (1995) suggested a return to this practice based on differences in size at maturity (eastern North Atlantic are smaller) and colour differences in preserved specimens. In the absence of other supporting morphological data, these features seem insufficient to justify dividing the eastern and western Atlantic populations into separate species (Martini et al. 1998, Martini and Flescher 2002). More conclusive studies involving morphological and molecular data are necessary to resolve this taxonomic question.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.
The 338 mm female USNM 161513 (paratype of Paramyxine springeri) is in fact an E. minor, as previously reported by Fernholm and Hubbs (1981) and confirmed by recent examination.
This species was recently reviewed by O'Foigal et al, 2011, who found that there were two cryptic lineages, and separated R. cawahabensis for the other river system lineage.

Anadromous, semi-anadromous, lacustrine, fluviatile-lacustrine and dwarf stocks are known, sometimes in sympatry. For most of them, detailed data are not available. Once available they are likely to show that several species are involved, whose identity is presently masked by unclear species definitions. If Alpine and northern European populations are considered conspecific as still asserted by numerous authors, then the name S. alpinus is not available for the present species but must be replaced by S. umbla, as required by the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature.

Salvelinus alpinus was earlier included in the IUCN Red List (assessed as LR/lc in 1996), but has since been split into 20 separate species: S. alpinus, S. colii, S. evasus, S. fimbriatus, S. gracillimus, S. grayi, S. inframundus, S. killinensis, S. lepechini, S. lonsdalii, S. mallochi, S. maxillaris, S. murta, S. obtusus, S. perisii, S. struanensis, S. thingvallensis, S. umbla, S. willoughbii, and S. youngeri.

Dillon et al. (2006) synonymize Somatogyrus alcoviensis and Somatogyrus tenax, as well as possibly Somatogyrus georgianus, Somatogyrus pennsylvanicus, and Somatogyrus rheophilus, with Somatogyrus virginicus, with little explanation except observed morphological similarity. Examination of Somatogyrus (S. alcoviensis, S. rheophilus, S. tenax) from known sites in Georgia in 1995 indicated the supposed diagnostic characters given in the literature for separating these species appear to be subject to variation and a revision is needed to better define species limits within the genus (Watson 2000).

Recents collections of Somatogyrus cannot be positively identified due to the morpholgical similarities between the currently described species. If each of the currently described Somatogyrus species is found to be valid then they would all likely be assessed as threatened (see Burch 1989). If S. aureus was classified as a valid species, it could be assessed as Critically Endangered (possibly extinct) under B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii), as habitat quality is still declining, which could be used as a proxy for population declines.

Recent collections of Somatogyrus cannot be positively identified, due to the morphological similarities between the currently described species. If each of the currently described Somatogyrus species is found to be valid then they would all likely be assessed as threatened (see Burch 1989). Examination of holotypes reveals this species may be more closely related to Marstonia than Somatogyrus based on shell characters (Clark 2007).

Recent collections of Somatogyrus cannot be positively identified, due to the morphological similarities between the currently described species. If each of the currently described Somatogyrus species is found to be valid then they would all likely be assessed as threatened (see Burch 1989). Examination of holotypes reveals this species may represent an aberration of another species (Clark 2007).

Recent collections of Somatogyrus cannot be positively identified as species due to the morphological similarities between the currently described species. If each of the currently described Somatogyrus species is found to be valid then they would all likely be assessed as threatened (see Burch 1989). Further taxonomic clarification is recommended.

Recent collections of Somatogyrus cannot be positively identified as species due to the morphological similarities between the currently described species. If each of the currently described Somatogyrus species is found to be valid then they would all likely be assessed as threatened (see Burch 1989). Further taxonomic clarification is recommended.

Recent collections of Somatogyrus cannot be positively identified as species due to the morphological similarities between the currently described species. If each of the currently described Somatogyrus species is found to be valid then they would all likely be assessed as threatened (see Burch 1989). Further taxonomic clarification is recommended.
Giant sea bass was originally assigned to the grouper family, Serranidae, but was later placed in a new family called the Percichthyidae (Domeier 2001).
Incorrectly spelt in Red Lists prior to 2008 as S. mundaus.

This species was previously known as Arkansia wheeleri, but changed to Arcidens wheeleri in Clarke (1981) and Graf and Cummings (2007).
