Trepanier and Murphy (2001) concluded that for the northern species of Uma existing data support either a two-species arrangement (Uma scoparia, Uma notata) or five-species classification (Uma scoparia, Uma notata, Uma inornata, and Uma rufopunctata, plus an undescribed species from Mohawk Dunes, Arizona). Trepanier and Murphy prefered the latter arrangement and stated that a description of the Mohawk Dunes species is in progress. Crother et al. (2003) adopted the taxonomy preferred by Trepanier and Murphy.

Based on patterns of morphological variation, Aguirre-L. et al. (1999) and Grismer (1999) concluded that Urosaurus microscutatus is a junior synonym of U. nigricaudus. Crother et al. (2003) adopted this taxonomy and applied the name Baja California Brush Lizard to the single species. Grismer (2002) and Stebbins (2003) called it the Black-tailed Brush Lizard.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species is a parthenogenetic allotriploid of hybrid origin. Allozyme and mDNA data indicate that C. exsanguis probably arose by the hybridization of C. septemvittatus or C. scalaris with an allodiploid intermediate form (or forms) created by one or more earlier hybridization events involving a male C. inornatus and a female C. costatus or C. burti stictogrammus (see Stuart 1991). Putative similarity to C. flagellicaudus and C. sonorae is overrated according to Frost and Wright (1988). This species formerly was included in other species of the sexlineatus species group. See Stuart (1991) for a review of the nomenclatural history of this species.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species was previously confused with C. exsanguis and C. sonorae (Behler and King 1979). It appears to comprise a complex of groups having different origins through hybridization (Frost and Wright 1988).

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species is a parthenogen, derived through hybridization between A. (tigris) marmorata and A. inornata (Frost and Wright 1988, Cole et al. 1988). It exhibits low clonal diversity (Parker and Selander 1984). See Cole et al. (1988) for a discussion of the origin of two atypical electrophoretically distinct clones.

Cnemidophorus perplexus is a senior synonym of A. neomexicana (the lectotype of perplexus evidently is not a hybrid (Taylor and Walker, 1996). To promote nomenclatural stability, Smith et al. (1997), including Walker, proposed to the ICZN that C. neomexicanus be conserved and that Cnemidophorus perplexus be suppressed. This proposal was approved.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

Walker et al. (1997) recognized this triploid parthenogen as a distinct species; formerly it was included in C. tesselatus (A. tesselata).

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

Taxonomy is unstable with respect to whether septemvittata is a species (Forstner et al. 1998) or a subspecies of A. gularis (Walker 1981, Walker et al. 2001) or A. scalaris (Smith et al. 1996, if septemvittata is not included in A. gularis). See Walker et al. (2001) for a detailed discussion of taxonomic uncertainties. Crother et al. (2000, 2003) listed A. septemvittatus as a distinct species that includes scalaris. See Crother et al. (2000) for discussion of their selection of C. septemvittatus (= A. septemvittata) as the proper name when septemvittata, scalaris, and semifasciata are all considered synonyms.

Aspidoscelis septemvittata hybridizes with A. gularis in several areas (Walker 1986, Forstner et al. 1998).

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

See Walker et al. (1990) for information on continuing hybridization between A. sexlineata and A. tesselata in Colorado.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus. This species hybridizes (rarely) with A. tigris in southern Arizona (Stebbins 1985). It appears to comprise a complex of groups with different origins through hybridization (Frost and Wright 1988).

MtDNA data suggest an ancient divergence between populations in the north-central Florida peninsula and populations in the south-central peninsula; high genetic distances exist within south-central populations, whereas genetic structure within northern populations is less discrete and characterized by much shallower divergences (Mulvaney et al. 2005). These findings suggest that south-central populations may be candidates for taxonomic recognition (or recognition as distinct management units) if confirmed by additional genetic and morphological data (Mulvaney et al. 2005).

This species formerly was included in the family Amphisbaenidae. Most recent studies recognize four families within Amphisbaenia, with Rhineura floridana as the sole living member of the family Rhineuridae (Kearney 2003). A molecular phylogenetic analysis supports this arrangement (Macey et al. 2004).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).
The subspecies marmoratus is regarded as a distinct species by some authorities, but is retained here as a subspecies following Reeder et al. (2002).

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

E. brevilineatus and E. callicephalus were treated as subspecies of E. tetragrammus by Lieb (1985, 1990). Tanner (1987) maintained that callicephalus should be retained as a distinct species. Lieb (1990) noted that additional sampling and study of material from Chihuahua is needed to clarify the status of callicephalus. Meanwhile, Crother et al. (2003) listed E. callicephalus as a species, based on allopatry and morphological diagnosability relative to E. brevilineatus and E. callicephalus.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The change has thus been extended to the Mexican species.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species may comprise two or three historical groups of independent origin (Frost and Wright 1988, Cuellar 1977). Further research is needed to determine if A. velox comprises multiple species of different ploidy levels.

Aspidoscelis velox arose through hybridization; parental species were A. inornata and either A. costata or A. burti stictogramma (Moritz et al. 1989).

Subspecies insularis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991), but no supporting data were presented, and other authors have not adopted this proposal.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

Recent phylogenetic analyses using DNA data indicate that the Plestiodon (Eumeces) gilberti morphotype (generally large-bodied and uniformly colored, versus the small-bodied and striped P. skiltonianus morphotype) has arisen independently at least three times (three clades) and that two of the three clades are nested within the geographically more widespread P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). Plestiodon lagunensis of southern Baja California is also nested phylogenetically within P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). A taxonomic revision is therefore warranted, but further study is needed before the species limits within this group can be definitively determined (Richmond and Reeder 2002).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

There has been disagreement over whether the southern subspecies should be called P. m. epipleurotus or P. m. gaigeae (see Hammerson 1999). The name eplipleurotus went long unused but has priority, and a recent informal ICZN evaluation concluded that epipleurotus is the name that should be used (Axtell and Smith 2004). Hammerson (1999) suggested that the variable skink (subspecies epipleurotus) might be a distinct species; genetic study is needed to resolve the question.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

MtDNA data suggest that colonization of P. septentrionalis into previously glaciated areas was from a single source with restricted gene flow (Fuerst and Austin 2004). Parsimony and maximum likelihood phylogenetic analyses showed reciprocal monophyly between the allopatric northern (P. s. septentrionalis) and southern (P. s. obtusirostris) subspecies (Fuerst and Austin 2004). These results, combined with the morphological differences found in previous studies (Taylor 1935), suggest that these allopatric populations are on separate evolutionary trajectories (Fuerst and Austin 2004). Further sampling of southern populations is needed to elucidate the taxonomic status of the various populations.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

Recent phylogenetic analyses using DNA data indicate that the Plestiodon gilberti morphotype (generally large-bodied and uniformly colored, versus the small-bodied and striped P. skiltonianus morphotype) has arisen independently at least three times (three clades) and that two of the three clades are nested within the geographically more widespread P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). Plestiodon lagunensis of southern Baja California is also nested phylogenetically within P. skiltonianus (Richmond and Reeder 2002). A taxonomic revision is therefore warranted, but further study is needed before the species limits within this group can be definitively determined (Richmond and Reeder 2002).

Stebbins (2003) treated P. lagunensis of southern Baja California as a subspecies of P. skiltonianus whereas Grismer (2002) recognized P. lagunensis as a distinct species (following Grismer 1994).

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009).

Plestiodon brevilineatus and P. callicephalus were treated as subspecies of P. tetragrammus by Lieb (1985, 1990). Lieb (1990) indicated intergradation between tetragrammus and brevilineatus in southern Texas and northeastern Mexico. Dixon (1987) and Conant and Collins (1991) accepted the conspecific relationship between tetragrammus and brevilineatus. Tanner (1987) maintained that callicephalus should be retained as a full species. Lieb (1990) noted that additional sampling and study of material from Chihuahua is needed to clarify the status of callicephalus. Crother et al. (2000) listed P. callicephalus and P. tetragrammus as distinct species, with brevilineatus as a subspecies of P. tetragrammus.

In a phylogenetic analysis of Eumeces based on morphology, Griffith et al. (2000) proposed splitting Eumeces into multiple genera, based on the apparent paraphyly of Eumeces. Smith (2005) and Brandley et al. (2005) formally proposed that all North American species (north of Mexico) be placed in the genus Plestiodon. This was accepted by Crother (2008) and Collins and Taggart (2009). The name is thus also used for Mexican species.

The enigmatic taxon Hombronia fasciolaris was described from material nominally collected from New Zealand by the US Exploring Expedition, which has resulted in continuing confusion regarding its true provenance, the appropriate generic name (the species has most often been included in Leiolopisma), and the identity of the type specimen (Zug 1985). Shea (in prep.) has recently re-examined the known specimen and traced its likely history, finding that it is likely to have been correctly identified as the H. fasciolaris holotype but that it does not correspond to any genus found in regions visited by the US Exploring Expedition but instead falls within the known range of variation of the widespread New World species Scincella lateralis. This author formally synonymized H. fasciolaris within S. lateralis.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

The subspecies xanthonota - generally treated as a subspecies of A. burti (e.g., Wright and Lowe 1993) - was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991). No supporting data were presented; the proposed split was based on presumed allopatry and diagnosability. Crother et al. (2000) followed Collins and listed xanthonota as a species distinct from A. burti. Under the genus Cnemidophorus, Stebbins (2003) retained xanthonota as a subspecies of A. burti. We also retain xanthonota within burti, pending clarification of its status. It is unclear whether or not the populations of this species around Guaymas (A. burti burti) are conspecific with A. burti stictogrammus (D. Frost pers. comm.). The populations in the south of the range are A. burti griseocaphalus.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

Not all authors agree on which populations should be assigned to this species. Aspidoscelis septemvittata is regarded as a species by some (Wright et al. 1983), as a subspecies of A. gularis by others; septemvittata and gularis hybridize in southwestern Texas (Forstner et al. 1998). Crother et al. (2003) listed A. gularis and A. septemvittata as separate species. See Walker (1981, 1986) for discussion of systematic issues. See Walker et al. (1991) for information on hybridization between A. gularis and A. laredoensis.

Reeder et al. (2002) examined phylogenetic relationships of the whiptail lizards of the genus Cnemidophorus based on a combined analysis of mitochondrial DNA, morphology, and allozymes. They determined that Cnemidophorus in the traditional sense is paraphyletic and thus in need of nomenclatural revision. Rather than subsume all cnemidophorine species (including Kentropyx) in a single large genus (Ameiva), they proposed a split that placed the North American "Cnemidophorus" clade in the monophyletic genus Aspidoscelis; under this arrangement, South American taxa remain in the genus Cnemidophorus.

This species is a diploid, parthenogenetic species derived from hybridization between A. sexlineata viridis and A. gularis gularis (Wright et al. 1983, Frost and Wright 1988, Abuhteba et al. 2000). It includes two morphotypes (Walker 1986, Frost and Wright 1988, Paulissen et al. 1988); electrophoretic data indicate that the LAR-A morphotype comprises two electromorphs (cryptic clones); the other morphotype (LAR-B) apparently is genetically uniform over its entire range; LAR-A and LAR-B apparently arose from separate hybidization events (Abuhteba et al. 2001), whereas the cryptic clones of LAR-A arose via mutational or recombinational divergence (see Paulissen et al. 1988). See Walker et al. (1989, 1991) for information on hybridization between laredoensis and A. gularis.

Papenfuss et al. (2001) examined genetic and morphological variation of Xantusia and reviewed allozyme data from Bezy and Sites (1987). They concluded that three species are represented in Arizona: Xantusia vigilis, a yucca-dwelling species; X. arizonae, a granite-adapted species; and X. bezyi (newly described), another granite-associated species. Crother et al. (2003) listed X. bezyi and X. vigilis as distinct species but included arizonae as a subspecies of X. vigilis. Stebbins (2003) mentioned the taxonomic changes proposed by Papenfuss et al. but did not adopt them. Sinclair et al. (2004) examined phylogeographic patterns in Xantusia and concluded that X. bezyi is a valid species (but more widely distributed than previously known) and that X. arizonae has a smaller range than previously understood.

The taxonomic concept of Crotalus mitchellii assessed here, excludes the subspecies angelensis Klauber, 1963 and subspecies muertensis Klauber, 1949; these are both assessed separately as good species.

Analysis of historical biogeography based on mtDNA data (Pook et al. 2000) revealed two main clades, one including populations from east and south of the Rocky Mountains and the other consisting of populations west of the Rocky Mountains. The conventionally recognized subspecies do not fully correspond to the phylogenetic pattern, and a review of the systematic status of several populations is needed (Pook et al. 2000).

Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) examined mtDNA variation among 26 populations of C. viridis and also identified two main clades: eastern, including subspecies viridis and nuntius (low levels of genetic divergence), and western, including all other subspecies. However, Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) differed from Pook et al. (2000) with respect to the relationships among members of the western clade, although Ashton and de Queiroz studied only a few individuals from each member of the western clade and stated that the relationships within the western clade are largely unresolved and that none (except possibly cerberus) appeared to deserve recognition as separate evolutionary species. Ashton and de Queiroz suggested that the two main clades be regarded as distinct species, C. viridis (eastern clade) and C. oreganus (western clade). The historical biogeographic scenario described by Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) suggests secondary contact between C. viridis and C. oreganus in northern Arizona, southwestern and northwestern Colorado, and southeastern Utah.

Douglas et al. (2002) examined mtDNA variation in C. viridis, with emphasis on the populations on the Colorado Plateau. As did Pook et al. (2000) and Ashton and de Queiroz (2001), they identified eastern and western clades, with the former including the nominal subspecies viridis and nuntius and the latter encompassing all of the other subspecies. Douglas et al. (2002) argued that all of the western subspecies should be recognized as species, but they did not effectively indicate details of distributional relationships in the contact zones among the proposed species. Douglas et al. (2002) concluded that the taxon nuntius should be regarded as a synonym of viridis.

Crother et al. (2003) considered all of the foregoing evidence and adopted the two-species taxonomy (Crotalus oreganus, Crotalus viridis) that is supported by the congruence among all three studies cited above. Campbell and Lamar (2004) also recognized only the two species. However, further clarification of the distributions of C. viridis and C. oreganus is needed, particularly in the contact zones in northern Arizona, southwestern and northwestern Colorado, and southeastern Utah. For example, populations in northwestern Colorado (Moffat County) identified by Douglas et al. (2002) as C. viridis were mapped as C. oreganus concolor by Campbell and Lamar (2004).

We follow Crother et al. (2003) and Campbell and Lamar (2004) in recognizing C. oreganus and C. viridis as separate species. In addition subspecies caliginis Klauber, 1949 is also treated separately as a good species.
The taxonomic status of the two subspecies (widely separated populations in the Sierra Madre Occidental and Sierra Madre Oriental) needs to be evaluated (Crother et al. 2000).

Murphy et al. (1995) examined variation in mtDNA, allozymes, and morphology of red diamond rattlesnakes and concluded that Crotalus ruber and C. exsul should be considered a single species (C. exsul) with three subspecies (C. e. exsul, C. e. ruber, and C. e. lorenzoensis. Smith et al. (1998) applied to the ICZN to conserve the name Crotalus ruber for the red diamond rattlesnake by giving the name Crotalus ruber precedence over the name C. exsul. ICZN (2000) gave Crotalus ruber precedence over C. exsul whenever the two names are considered to be synonyms.

Analysis of historical biogeography based on mtDNA data (Pook et al. 2000) revealed two main clades, one including populations from east and south of the Rocky Mountains and the other consisting of populations west of the Rocky Mountains. The conventionally recognized subspecies do not fully correspond to the phylogenetic pattern, and a review of the systematic status of several populations is needed (Pook et al. 2000).

Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) examined mtDNA variation among 26 populations of C. viridis and also identified two main clades: eastern, including subspecies viridis and nuntius (low levels of genetic divergence), and western, including all other subspecies. However, Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) differed from Pook et al. (2000) with respect to the relationships among members of the western clade, although Ashton and de Queiroz studied only a few individuals from each member of the western clade and stated that the relationships within the western clade are largely unresolved and that none (except possibly cerberus) appeared to deserve recognition as separate evolutionary species. Ashton and de Queiroz suggested that the two main clades be regarded as distinct species, C. viridis (eastern clade) and C. oreganus (western clade). The historical biogeographic scenario described by Ashton and de Queiroz (2001) suggests secondary contact between C. viridis and C. oreganus in northern Arizona, southwestern and northwestern Colorado, and southeastern Utah.

Douglas et al. (2002) examined mtDNA variation in C. viridis, with emphasis on the populations on the Colorado Plateau. As did Pook et al. (2000) and Ashton and de Queiroz (2001), they identified eastern and western clades, with the former including the nominal subspecies viridis and nuntius and the latter encompassing all of the other subspecies. Douglas et al. (2002) argued that all of the western subspecies should be recognized as species, but they did not effectively indicate details of distributional relationships in the contact zones among the proposed species. Douglas et al. (2002) concluded that the taxon nuntius should be regarded as a synonym of viridis.

Crother et al. (2003) considered all of the foregoing evidence and adopted the two-species taxonomy (Crotalus oreganus, Crotalus viridis) that is supported by the congruence among all three studies cited above. Campbell and Lamar (2004) also recognized only the two species. However, further clarification of the distributions of C. viridis and C. oreganus is needed, particularly in the contact zones in northern Arizona, southwestern and northwestern Colorado, and southeastern Utah. For example, populations in northwestern Colorado (Moffat County) identified by Douglas et al. (2002) as C. viridis were mapped as C. oreganus concolor by Campbell and Lamar (2004). We follow Crother et al. (2003) and Campbell and Lamar (2004) in recognizing C. oreganus and C. viridis as separate species.

Papenfuss et al. (2001) examined genetic and morphological variation of Xantusia and reviewed allozyme data from Bezy and Sites (1987). They concluded that three species are represented in Arizona: Xantusia vigilis, a yucca-dwelling species; X. arizonae, a granite-adapted species; and X. bezyi (newly described), another granite-associated species. Crother et al. (2003) listed X. bezyi and X. vigilis as distinct species but included arizonae as a subspecies of X. vigilis. Stebbins (2003) mentioned the taxonomic changes proposed by Papenfuss et al. but did not adopt them. Sinclair et al. (2004) examined phylogeographic patterns in Xantusia and concluded that X. bezyi is a valid species (but more widely distributed than previously known) and that X. arizonae has a smaller range than previously understood.

Grismer and Galvan (1986) described Xantusia henshawi gracilis on the basis of morphological, electrophoretic, and ecological differences from other subspecies. Lovich (2001) used mtDNA data to examine the phylogeography of X. henshawi populations in southern California and concluded that the allopatric subspecies Xantusia henshawi gracilis should be recognized as a distinct species, Xantusia gracilis. This conclusion is supported by previously published allozyme data (showing fixed allelic differences) and a compatible historical biogeographical scenario.
This species formerly included Xantusia gracilis (Lovich 2001).

Papenfuss et al. (2001) examined genetic and morphological variation of Xantusia and reviewed allozyme data from Bezy and Sites (1987). They concluded that three species are represented in Arizona: Xantusia vigilis, a yucca-dwelling species; X. arizonae, a granite-adapted species; and X. bezyi (newly described), another granite-associated species. Crother et al. (2003) listed X. bezyi and X. vigilis as distinct species but included arizonae as a subspecies of X. vigilis. Stebbins (2003) mentioned the taxonomic changes proposed by Papenfuss et al. but did not adopt them.

Subspecies utahensis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991), but no supporting data were presented. Collins and Taggart (2002) listed utahensis as a subspecies of X. vigilis.
This species was originally placed in the genus Procambarus, subgenus Distocambarus (Hobbs 1981). However, in 1983 Distocambarus was elevated to a generic rank (Hobbs and Carlson 1983).
This species incorrectly spelled yongineri in Wilson (1989).

Chambers (1990) synonymized Elimia albanyensis, Elimia athearni, and Elimia catanoides with Elimia boykiniana based on the constancy of the shape of the outer lip of the aperture and old museum lots consisting of shells exhibiting a range of variation. Mihalcik and Thompson (2002) synonymize Elimia boykiniana (in part) and several of its subspecies under Elimia viennaensis and Elima abanyensis. Mihalcik and Thompson (2002) also claim Chambers (1990) description of Elimia boykiniana is a composite of several species. Dillon et al. (2006) synonymize Elimia caelatura, Elimia darwini, Elimia mutabilis, Elimia albanyensis, Elimia boykiniana, Elimia postelli, Elimia suturalis, and Elimia viennaensis with Elimia catenaria, based on observational data (morphological characters that are difficult to distinguish).

This species is closely related to Elimia gerhardti based on similar shell shapes and the relationships of these two species needs to be explored biochemically (Bogan and Pierson 1993). Elimia cahawbensis, Elimia annettae, Elimia varians, and Elimipa pupoides appear to represent a cline from headwaters to large river and this group needs further study to determine if there are four species or a single variable species (Bogan and Pierson 1993). It has been suggested that ssp. fraterna is not distinct. According to Mark Gordon, examination of Lea's original descriptions found that specimens of fraterna were smaller, had fewer whorls, and a carina across the middle of each whorl. Gordon also comments, in many species, that similar carina may be apparent in young individuals but obscured in old snails. Lea's figure of a shell of cahawbensis older than the figured fraterna displays carina in early whorls, but these are fused into the suture in later whorls and missing in the body whorl. Thus, Gordon concludes the use of fraterna without further evidence does not appear justified. Bogan and Pierson (1993) also did not distinguish fraterna from cahawbensis during field surveys and found the degree of development of the carina variable between streams.
Also treated under the genus Goniobasis.

Davis (1984) and Stiven (1994) provide conflicting results relative to the uniqueness of Elliptio waccamawensis. Questions have been raised concerning its genetic relationship with Elliptio icterina and Elliptio congarea.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Johnson (1972) synonymized both Elliptio ahenea and Elliptio waltoni under Elliptio jayensis, but both species were subsequently recognized by Turgeon et al. (1998). The entire group needs further molecular work to confirm taxonomic uncertainty.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio, including Elliptio angustata, is currently in a state of confusion. Johnson (1970) grouped many named taxa under a single name and synonymized Elliptio angustata under Elliptio lanceolata. However, Turgeon et al. (1998) and Graf and Cummings (2007) include them as distinct species.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. Johnson (1970) grouped many named taxa under a single name. Current research is finding many of these synonomized taxa to be valid species. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. This species is often confused with Elliptio crassidens. Johnson (1970) recognized Elliptio downiei as a subspecies of Elliptio crassidens, although subsequent authors have given downiei species-level status (e.g., Turgeon et al. 1998, Graf and Cummings 2007).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. Johnson (1970) grouped many named taxa under a single name. Current research is finding many of these synonomized taxa to be valid species. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. Johnson (1970) listed this species as a synonym of Elliptio lanceolata but Turgeon et al. (1998) included both as distinct species.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site  (Graf and Cummings 2011).

There is some uncertainty regarding the range and validity of this species (Brim Box and Williams 2000). Johnson (1970) did not recognize E. mcmichaeli and considered it a synonym of E. fraterna. Based on anatomical differences in the mantle margins, Fuller (1974) recognized both species. Brim Box and Williams (2000) agreed with Fuller (1974) and consider E. fraterna to be a species distinct from E. mcmichaeli, based on these anatomical differences as well as zoogeographical patterns. Records for E. fraterna from the Choctawhatchee River by Johnson (1970) represent this species.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The classification of the Atlantic Slope species of Elliptio is currently in a state of uncertainty. Johnson (1970) lumped many named taxa under a single name. Current research is finding many of these synonomized taxa to be valid species. This research is in progress and will result in the recognition of numerous additional taxa in this genus. Johnson (1970) placed this species in synonymy with Elliptio lanceolata, however Turgeon et al. (1998) list both as distinct species. No agreement has been reached on what this taxon is, therefore further study is needed.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species is in need of genetic validation; it is considered distinct by Turgeon et al. (1998), but not by Johnson (1972), who lists it as a synonym of Elliptio jayensis, and Heard (1979).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
Was listed in the 1996 IUCN Red List under the name Dysnomia arcaeformis?.
Was listed in the 1996 IUCN Red List under the name Dysnomia biemarginata?.
Was listed in the 1996 IUCN Red List under the name Dysnomia flexuosa.
Was listed in the 1996 IUCN Red List under the name Dysnomia haysiana.
Was listed in the 1996 IUCN Red List under the name Dysnomia lenior.

This species was historically placed in the genera Dysnomia and Plagiola (Johnson 1978) and is now placed in genus Epioblasma (Williams et al. 2008).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species was historically placed in the genera Dysnomia and Plagiola (Johnson 1978). This species is currently place in the genus Epioblasma (Williams et al. 2008).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
Was listed in the 1996 IUCN Red List under the name Dysnomia sampsoni.
Was listed in the 1996 IUCN Red List under the name Dysnomia lewisii?.
Was listed in the 1996 IUCN Red List under the name Dysnomia stewardsoni.

Genetic analyses in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific indicate that nesting populations comprise separate and identifiable stocks that should be treated as separate management units (Bass et al. 1996, Bowen et al. 1996, Bowen and Karl 2007). Hawksbill aggregations on foraging grounds comprise animals from multiple nesting populations and often include animals from distant rookeries (Broderick et al. 1994, Bowen et al. 2007).
This species was previously placed in the genus Cambarus (K. Crandall pers. comm. 2009).

Genetic examination of the molecular phylogeny of the global Planorboidea at the COI and 18S molecular markers indicates that all North American ancylid taxa form a well-supported clade, the Bulinini (Albrecht et al. 2007).
The NatureServe NatureExplorer database notes this as Pyrgulopsis avernalis (Pilsbry, 1935).

Important synonyms include Pleurobema argenteum pannosa (Simpson,1900), Pleurobema brevis var. subelliptica (Simpson, 1900) and Pleurobema utterbackii (Frierson in Utterback, 1916).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

This species has been placed in the genus Quadrula from Fusconaia (Williams et al. 2008). Lydeard et al. (2000), in a discussion of molecular phylogeny, indicated this species is not a member of the genus Fusconaia. Recent mitochondrial DNA evidence suggests this species is closely related to, and may possibly require placement in, the genus Quadrula as a member of the pustulosa group (Serb et al. 2003).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Synonyms = A. medirostris mikadoi Hilgendorf, 1892 (although this is now probably best treated as a distinct species); A. acutirostris Ayres, 1854.

The Green Sturgeon was once considered conspecific with the Sakhalin Sturgeon (A. mikadoi) and the two forms were synonymized (Berg 1948). However, recent molecular data on three mitochondrial genes and morphometric studies show large differences between North American and Asian forms (Birstein and DeSalle 1998, North et al. 2002). Sakhalin Sturgeon is now believed extinct in Japan, Korea and China and the species sustains only a remnant population in Russia's Tumnin River where there is a hatchery (Adams et al. 2002).

Warren (1912) suggested this species may be a form of Agrotis lucicolens, which was subsequently synonymized with A. photophila, but Zimmerman (1958) disagrees with this assertion. It is therefore treated as a separate species.
This species was listed as a synonym of Agrotis cremata by Warren (1912), but Zimmermann (1958) does not agree with that assessment.

It is possible that genetic analyses will split this species into more than one taxon (Bogan 2000). Based on the analysis of the gene sequences, Bogan et al. (2008) have placed Alasmidonta heterodon in a clade separate from the type species of Alasmidonta, A. undulata. They argue for the elevation of the subgenus Prolasmidonta (Ortmann, 1914) with the type species Alasmidonta heterdon, to create Prolasmidonta heterodon.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

The current spelling of the specific name is correct. Clarke's (1985) spelling change, Alasmidonta maccordi, was unjustified and constituted a recommendation only (Turgeon et al. 1998).

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).

Graf and Cummings (2007) lists this species as Theliderma cylindrica, however Williams et al. (2008) continue to use the genus Quadrula for this species.

Two subspecies are currently recognised. Quadrula cylindrica strigillata is listed by US Fish and Wildlife Service as endangered.

A list of synonyms for this species can be found on The MUSSEL project web site (Graf and Cummings 2011).
This species exhibits substantial biochemical and morphological variation; as many as three forms may soon receive formal taxonomic recognition (see Boschung and Mayden 2004).
Species of the Acropomatidae family are ill-defined (FAO ECA guide in prep PC Heemstra).

Phipps (1774) first described the Polar Bear as a distinct species and named it Ursus maritimus. Other names were suggested including Thalassarctos, Thalarctos, and Thalatarctos. Erdbrink (1953) and Thenius (1953) ultimately settled on Ursus (Thalarctos) maritimus because of interbreeding between Brown Bears (Ursus arctos) and Polar Bears in zoos. Based on the fossil record, Kurtén (1964) recommended the Phipps (1774) name Ursus maritimus, which was promoted by Harington (1966), Manning (1971) and Wilson (1976) and is used today (see DeMaster and Stirling 1981, Amstrup 2003, Wilson and Reeder 2005).

Kristmundsdottir and Gold (1996) used mtDNA restriction site analysis to study systematics and biogeography and identified four major mtDNA-based phylogeographic clades: Chocktawatchee, Apalachicola, Mobile, and Western (four lineages, Texas to Mississippi). They found that mtDNA phylogeographic subdivision within C. venusta is not strictly concordant with geographic subdivisions (ranges) of the three nominal subspecies (venusta, cercostigma, and stigmatura). Taxonomic revision may be warranted, but further study is needed. This species was removed from the genus Notropis and placed in the genus (formerly subgenus) Cyprinella by Mayden (1989). This change was adopted in the 1991 AFS checklist (Robins et al. 1991). See Mayden (1989) for synonymy.

This species was formerly known as Cottus pygmaeus (and appeared in IUCN Red Lists up to 2006 under that name), but that specific name is preoccupied in the genus Cottus, so Williams (2000) proposed the substitute name C. paulus.

Three subspecies (oblongatus, claviformis, and connectens) have been recognized, but the validity of connectens is questionable (see Lee et al. 1980). Page and Burr (1991) recognized only oblongatus and claviformis as valid subspecies. Bailey et al. (2004) recognized E. oblongatus and E. claviformis as distinct species; Nelson et al. (2004) noted this treatment but did not adopt it. Page and Burr (2011) recognized E. oblongatus and E. claviformis as distinct species.

This species formerly was referred to as C. vandoisulus. It is one of two species of Clinostomus. Sometimes it has been placed in genus Richardsonius. Duebler (1955, Ph.D. diss., Cornell Univ.) recognized three subspecies (two described, funduloides and estor), with the undescribed form close to species status (Lee et al. 1980).

Taxonomy of the genus Dionda is currently in flux. It is likely that acceptance of taxonomic revisions suggested by Schonuth et al. (2012), in which the D. episcopa complex is split into three putative species, would restrict the range of D. episcopa to the middle Pecos River drainage basin. Formal description of these putative species would warrant reassessment of D. episcopa to account for a more restricted distribution.

This species hybridizes with Phoxinus eos (Bailey and Oliver 1939). Hybrids between P. neogaeus and P. eos comprise diploid, triploid, and diploid-triploid mosaic unisexuals. Diploids are products of clonal reproduction. Hybrids may coexist with P. eos in the absence of P. neogaeus (Hubbs and Brown 1929; Dawley et al. 1987). Aclonal reproduction by polyploids also occurs.

Four subspecies are recognised:
  • T. a. acus (Lacepède, 1803) in the western Atlantic (Massachusetts, USA to Brazil) and east Atlantic (off Morocco and the western Mediterranean Sea);
  • T. a. imperialis (Rafinesque, 1810) in the Mediterranean Sea and Cape Verde Islands);
  • T. a. rafale Collette and Parin 1970 from the Gulf of Guinea; and
  • T. a melanotus (Bleeker, 1850) in the the Indo-West Pacific and oceanic islands in the eastern tropical Pacific (Revillagigedos, Clipperton, and Cocos).

Exocoetus obtusirostris is endemic to the Atlantic Ocean and showed no significant differences from different parts of this ocean. It was thought to occur circumglobally before it was split into three other closely related species (Parin and Shakhovskoy 2000).

This may represent a species complex (Tomio pers. comm. 2012).
Coelorinchus caelorhincus was formerly considered as having a number of subspecies, but those are here recognized as full species. Eschmeyer and Bailey in Eschmeyer (1990:70) changed the spelling of the name from Coelorinchus coelorhincus (or Coelorhynchus coelorhynchus) to Caelorinchus caelorhincus, based on their interpretation. Iwamoto (2008: xi) agreed with the “ae” spelling of the species name (i.e., caelorhincus) but disagreed with the use of that dipthong in the generic name. He considered “Coelorinchus” to be the correct spelling, but accepted that there is room for doubt and agreed that the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature should be petitioned to fix the spellings of the generic and specific names (Iwamoto 2016).
Subpopulations south of Mauritania may represent another species; further taxonomic research is warranted (T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2012).
This species is often confused with Nezumia aequlis.

Two subspecies are recognized, Scomberesox saurus saurus (Walbaum, 1792) from the Northern Hemisphere and S. saurus scombroides (Richardson, 1843) from the Southern Hemisphere (Hubbs and Wisner 1980, Collette 2004).

Two subspecies are recognized by Collette (2003), T. crocodilus crocodilus (Peron and Lesueur 1821) from the Atlantic and Indo-West Pacific and T. crocodilus fodiator (Jordan and Gilbert 1882) in the eastern tropical Pacific.

This species has two subspecies, T. cristulata cristulata in the Western Atlantic, and T. cristulata echinata in the Eastern Atlantic. Specimens from Peru and Australia/New Zealand likely represent a different, distinct species or subspecies of a different species (Poss in press).
Subpopulations of this species should be further investigated as they may represent separate species (Tomio pers. comm. 2012).

Cheilopogon melanurus has been reported from the eastern Atlantic, from Senegal to Angola (Parin 1999). The eastern tropical Atlantic population was studied earlier by Gibbs and Staiger (1970). They discovered significant differences in pectoral-fin pigmentation and barbel structure between juvenile specimens of this population and similar-sized western Atlantic specimens and suspected, even not finding any distinctions between adults of both populations, the presence of yet undescribed species near the shores of West Africa. Parin and Belyanina (2000) reexamined three of these smaller eastern Atlantic specimens (USNM 203903, 203905 and 218912) and re-identified them as C. milleri (Gibbs and Staiger 1970). However, the western and eastern populations are so different in predorsal-scale number (25-33, mean 28.4, by 8 specimens, vs. 31-36, mean 33.7) that recognition of another species is highly probable (Parin in prep).

Parin and Belyanina (1998) separated the subspecies Cheilopogon furcatus furcatus from two new subspecies in the Indian and Pacific oceans. Another subspecies, C. furcatus neimani Parin & Belyanina occurs in the Indian Ocean and the third subspecies C. furcatus fisunovi Parin & Belyanina is widely distributed in the Pacific Ocean from western to eastern Pacific.
This species has been previously recorded as Gigantura vorax but this is now regarded as a synonym of G. chuni.
Within the Mediterranean, this species has also been reported as Bathypterois mediterraneus, a junior synonym of B. dubius (Quéro and Ribes 1999).
The correct spelling for this species is Omosudis lowii (Günther, 1887), though other spellings are in use (Eschmeyer 2014). This species is also referred to as Omosudis loweii by FAO.

The name S. brasiliensis (type locality: Cape Frio, Brazil) has been generally used for this species.  However, genetic evidence indicates approximately 5-6% divergence in CO1 between eastern and western Atlantic populations, which suggests the populations on either side of the Atlantic are distinct species [Baldwin et al. in press]. Thus, the name S. parri Norman 1935 (type locality: Angola) should be applied to this species.
Hemiramphus balao is frequently misidentified as Hemiramphus brasiliensis.

Oxyporhamphus micropterus similis is replaced in the Indo-Pacific by the nominal species Oxyporhamphus micropterus micropterus.  It is considered to be Exocoetidae by some authors (Collette 2002). The recent acceptance of Oxyporhamphus similis as a species by Eschmeyer should be reviewed (B. Collette pers. comm. 2012).

This nominal species, Etrumeus teres (DeKay 1842), was described based on specimens collected off New York. Whitehead (1985) included all populations of round herrings that were identified as this species in a single species, which was thought to be  globally distributed. However, in a recent taxonomic revision (Randall and DiBattista 2012), this nominal species, Etrumeus teres (sensu Whitehead 1985) was split into four distinct species: E. makiawa Randall and DiBattista 2012, restricted to the Hawaiian Islands; E. micropus (Temminck and Schlegel 1846), from Japan, and perhaps south to Indonesia; E. acuminatus Gilbert 1890 from the eastern tropical Pacific; and E. sadina (Mitchill 1814) from the northwestern Atlantic (with Etrumeus teres (DeKay 1842) as a junior synonym).

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).
Ophidion josephi is a senior synonym of O. welshi. The O. marginatum/josephi complex is in need of review (Lea and Robins 2003).
The genus of this species was recently changed from Carangoides to Caranx (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2012, Page et al. 2012).
Khidir et al. (2004) note due to the observed variations in morphomertic patterns more specimens are needed to determine if these patterns warrant the description of a new species.
Synodus bondi was recently resurrected from synonymy under S. foetens and both were redescribed by Frable et al. (2013).
Dornburg et al. (2012) proposed changing the genus of this species to Flammeo, however, this has not yet been generally accepted.
The genus of this species was previously Hypoatherina, but is now Atherina.
This species can be commonly misidentified as B. maculiferus (Weigt et al. 2012).

Many specimens historically identified as A. maculatus that have been found off the coast of Brazil around St. Paul's Rocks may have been misidentifications of A. strigosus, which has been recorded there based on molecular evidence (Bowen et al. 2001).
Dornburg et al. (2012) proposed changing the genus of this species to Neoniphon, however, this has not yet been generally accepted.
Dornburg et al. (2012) proposed changing the genus of this species to Neoniphon, however, this has not yet been generally accepted.
Lepophidium profundorum reported from the Southern Caribbean are referable to as L. cultratum (R. Robins pers. comm. 2013).
There are multiple undescribed species in this group which may have been confused with this species.
Page et al. (in press) accept the present taxonomic standing of Foetorepus agassizii.
In Brazilian waters, this species has been previously misidentified as Saurida suspicio (Carvalho-Filho et al. 2010).
There are multiple undescribed species in this group which may have been confused with this species.
In the Gulf of Mexico, this species is known as the subspecies C. striata melana. In the Atlantic, it is known as C. striata striata (Roy et al. 2012).
The West Pacific population may represent another species.
The O. marginatum/josephi complex is in need of review (Lea and Robins 2003).

Böhlke and Thomas (1961) discussed geographic variation in Opistognathus aurifrons, especially with regard to color pattern. Although they noted that specimens from the Bahamas and Florida can be consistently distinguished from each other by the presence or absence of black markings on the head, their observation that these markings are inconsistent in Virgin Island specimens led them to synonymize Gnathypops bermudezi. Subsequently, Ho et al. (2012) examined population genetics and color pattern of four Caribbean populations of O. aurifrons; although each population exhibited high levels of genetic differentiation, phenotype variation and genetics were not congruent.

Specimens from Brazil, including Trinidade Island and Fernando de Noronha, possibly represent a geminate species of O. aurifrons. They cannot be distinguished genetically and have virtually identical color patterns, but differ in vertebral counts. The taxonomic status of the Brazilian population is presently unresolved.

There is some uncertainty surrounding the taxonomic status of this species. There are two recognized species: Bathyanthias mexicanus and B. cubensis. A third, not yet described species occurs in the southern part of the Caribbean, and it is unknown if this confuses the distribution of B. cubensis. However, specimens examined from Colombia by A. Polanco pers. comm. (2018) are recognized as B. cubensis. The genus Bathyanthias requires further taxonomic study and it is not known how the ranges of B. mexicanus and B. cubensis overlap in the Gulf of Mexico (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2018).
Some workers consider the genus of this species to be valid as Serranus, not Centropristis.

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.

This species should be regarded as valid as Ancyclopsetta quadrocellata, not as A. ommata (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).
Lonchopisthus meadi (Menezes and Figueiredo 1971) is a junior synonym of L. lemur (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2012).
Lonchopisthus linderi Ginsburg, 1942 is a junior synonym of L. micrognathus.
Common names and scientific names for non-Atlantic and non-South African localities are probably missapplied (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2013).

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species of Kyphosus in Kyphosidae, and the monotypic Neoscorpis. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix (Knudsen and Clements 2013). Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis (Knudsen and Clements 2013). Kyphosus sandwicensis is a junior synonym of K. elegans (Knudsen and Clements 2013). 

Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there may in fact be four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens. However, Sakai and Nakbo (2014) have presented an alternative view on the kyphosids occurring in the Atlantic.

The 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists included Hippocampus horai, H. novaehebudorum, H. raji, and H. taeniops. These are now all considered to be synonyms of H. kuda. According to Vincent (1996) and Lourie et al. (1999), there may be as many as ten distinct species that are included under the name Hippocampus kuda. Further research into the literature on this species is needed to determine whether H. kuda is the correct name for populations occurring within the Persian Gulf (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2014).
The genus of this species was recently changed from Hemanthias to Baldwinella (Anderson and Heemstra 2012)

They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them. This species also shows the greatest amount of variation of the hamlets (Thresher 1978).

The eastern Atlantic and Brazilian subpopulations may represent variations of R. subbifrenatus or an undescribed species (Baldwin and Weigt 2012).
There are likely two well-defined sub-species that differ in coloration and meristics: a northern one and a southern one (Bullock and Smith 1991).
There is ongoing debate as to the taxonomic status of M. antillarum; Munroe (2002) considered it a junior synonym of M. sessilicauda.
Currently, this species is valid as S. civitatum, based on "of the states" rather than "of the citizenry" (see Munroe 1991 and etyfish to flesh this out).

Etropus crossotus was originally described from specimens collected in the eastern Pacific Ocean. Populations identified as this species from the western Atlantic, though morphologically similiar, have not been examined from a genetic perspective to determine if they are conspecific with the eastern Pacific populations (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015). For now, we continue to use E. crossotus for Atlantic populations.

The generic assignment of Pleuronectes oblongus Mitchill 1815 has been questioned. Some authors consider the appropriate placement to be in the genus Hippoglossina, while others consider this species to be a member of the genus Paralichthys. A comprehensive revision of these genera is necessary to resolve this conundrum.

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).
Polydactylus oligodon is difficult to distinguish from P. virginicus (Feltes 2002, B. Smith-Vaniz and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
There should be some investigation into the taxonomic standing of this species (i.e., whether it it belongs in the Syngnathiformes or Gasterosteiformes).
In the field, this species is difficult to distinguish from Stephanolepis hispidus (R. Robertson and J. Tyler pers. comm. 2015).
This species can be confused with its congener, R. subbifrenatus (Smith-Vaniz and Collette 2013).
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

Molecular sequence data indicates continuous species distribution with no break between Pacific and Indian Oceans (Winters et al. 2010).
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

The east and west Atlantic populations of N. usta were designated as separate subspecies by Schultz (1968) on the basis of minor morphometric divergences in preserved fishes (Nicholsina usta usta and Nicholsina usta collettei ).

Recent data show that these two forms are highly divergent genetically, more so than many of the Sparisoma species are from each other (Robertson et al. 2006). Hence, the east and west Atlantic forms represent a sister pair of species, N. collettei and N. usta, respectively (Parenti and Randall unpublished).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

There is strong evidence of genetic break between Pacific and Indian ocean populations. However, there is no clear evidence of morphological differentiation (J.H. Choat pers comm. 2009).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).

The widespread species Chlorurus sordidus is now partitioned into C. sordidus (Forsskål 1775), in the Red Sea and Indian Ocean and Chlorurus spilurus (Valenciennes 1840), in the Pacific and Eastern Indian Ocean based on mitochondrial sequence and morphology data (Bay et al.2004, Randall 2010, Beck 2010). It is likely that the Red Sea population will also be distinct (J.H. Choat pers comm. 2009).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).

The population in the eastern Atlantic is a distinct species known as Sparisoma choati (Rocha et al. 2012). add thiss reference:Rocha, L. A. , A. Brito and D. R. Robertson  2012 (6 Jan.) Records of this species in Brazil are to be treated as Scarus trispinosus.

The population in Fernando de Noronha are genetically distinct and probably represents a separate species (R. Robertson pers comm. 2008). Juveniles of this species are easily misidentified in Brazil as other species of Sparisoma and Nicholsina.

This species has been revised by Fooden (2000), who regards Macaca mulatta as monotypic. The molecular differences identified among M. mulatta populations (Melnick et al. 1993; Morales and Melnick 1998; Tosi 2000; Tosi et al. 2000, 2002, 2003; Zhang and Shi 1993) are alone not consistent enough to conclusively define any subspecies.

Three subpopulation designated by molecular studies: Indian, Chinese, Indochinese (Indochinese being an introgression with M. fascicularis). Considerable hybridization with M. fascicularis in Laos, Thailand and Viet Nam and the both share an interspecific boundary of ca 2,000 km across the Indochinese peninsula in the south-east. Both M. fascicularis and M. mulatta share a range between 17°N and 14°N in Viet Nam, Laos and probably Thailand.
Earlier known as Lethenteron japonicum.
The genus Lota is in a need of critical revision. Populations from eastern Siberia and North America represent a distinct species, L. maculosa.

Whilst the Catalogue of Fishes (April 2013) follows Scott and Crossman 1998, B. Delling pers. comm. 2013 to J. Freyhof) prefers Triglopsis as the correct genus following Neyelov (latest revision?), with qudricornis and thompsonii  differering strongly from Myoxocephalus  in: 1) Cephalic lateral line system.2) Only fresh and brackish water occurrence (i.e. they are freshwater fishes tolerating brackish water like other freshwater fishes , e.g, pike, perch, roach etc).

Lythrurus alegnotus formerly was regarded as a subspecies of Lythrurus bellus. Nelson et al. (2004) listed Lythrurus alegnotus as a distinct species, based on Gilbert (1998). Boschung and Mayden (2004) treated the two taxa as distinct species but mapped some records as "Lythrurus bellus x L. alegnotus."
Previously considered to be a population of Gila alvordensis (prior to 1980), which is listed separately.
Recently known as Entosphenus hubbsi.
As presently circumscribed, Etheostoma tuscumbia may represent multiple species (Boschung and Mayden 2004). Further study is needed.

Fundulus bifax formerly was included in F. stellifer; bifax is separable from stellifer by complete allelic differences at several loci and by details of pigmentation and breeding coloration (Rogers and Cashner 1987, Cashner et al. 1988). Allozyme data indicate that F. bifax is the sister to F. catenatus and that F. stellifer forms the sister group to the F. bifax-F. catenatus clade (Cashner et al. 1992).

Nussbaum and Hoyer (1974) showed that subspecies utahensis is indistiguishable from subspecies bottae, and they regarded the concept "umbratica" as meaningless; Collins (1990) apparently agreed with this view and did not recognize any subspecies. In contrast, Erwin (1974) proposed that subspecies umbratica warrants species status; this suggestion did not gain the support of other herpetologists. Stewart (1977) recognized two subspecies (bottae andumbratica) and, pending further study, regarded populations from Mt. Pinos and the Tehachapi Mountains, California, as intergrades between these two subspecies. Stebbins (1985) continued to recognize three subspecies (bottae, utahensis, and umbratica). Rodriguez-Robles et al. (2001) used mtDNA data to examine phylogeography of Charina bottae and concluded that "C. b. umbratica is a genetically cohesive, allopatric taxon that is morphologically diagnosable" [using a suite of traits] and that "it is an independent evolutionary unit that should be recognized as a distinct species, Charina umbratica". The authors acknowledged that a mixture of bottae and umbratica traits exists in populations in the Tehachapi Mountains and Mount Pinos, but they interpreted this as persistent ancestral polymorphisms. They also found no support for recognizing utahensis as a valid taxon. Crother et al. (2003) and Crother (2012) listed C. umbratica as a species. The consensus supports treating bottae and umbratica as two separate species and that treatment is followed here.
Formerly included in Percina copelandi (see Suttkus et al. 1994).
Following Eschmeyer (2004) Lagochila lacera was transferred to Moxostoma lacerum.

In their field guide, Page and Burr (2011) listed to Lythrurus alegnotus as a subspecies of L. bellus. However, Boschung and Mayden (2004) discussed the question of whether L. alegnotus is a valid species or a subspecies of L. bellus and justified their treatment of the two taxa as separate species. Since L. alegnotus occurs only in Alabama, where Boschung and Mayden have specific expertise, it is treated here as a separate species.

Plethobasus cyphyus (Rafinesque, 1820), the "Sheepnose", was placed in the genus Plethobasus by Ortmann (1919) having previously been assigned to other genera such as Unio, Pleurobema, Margarita, and Margaron. There are various spellings of the epithet of this species such as cyphya, scyphius, cyphius, cyphia, cyphyum and cyphyus. 
A subspecies, Plethobasus cyphyus compertus (Frierson, 1911), has been noted in the upper Tennessee river basin by Ortmann (1918) and has been considered a headwaters form. This form is described as having weak development of the medial row of knobs and sulcus, an elongated shell and pale coloured tissues. It is recommended that a systematic examination of the two forms should be undertaken in order to determine any taxonomic significance. It is also recommended to examine all species in the genus Plethobasus to confirm relatedness.
The taxonomy and key characteristics of Brama species are in need of review (Haedrich in press).

The western Pacific/Indo-Pacific populations of this species were previously considered a subspecies Lagocephalus lagocephalus oceanicus, while those in the Atlantic were previously considered the subspecies Lagocephalus lagocephalus lagocephalus.
Ariomma melanum and Ariomma bondi were historically considered the same species.
There has been some uncertainty surrounding the family and genus placement of this species (Prokofiev 2007).
Benthodesmus tenuis may represent a group of closely related species (Parin and Nakamura 2002).
The taxonomy of this species needs review.
This species almost certainly belongs to Haemulidae (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2010 in Catalog of Fishes).
This species was redescribed by Ho et al. (2017).

Fundulus majalis is in the subgenus Fontinus (E.O. Wiley 1986). The Gulf of Mexico population of this form has often been referred to a separate species, F. similis. Ross (2001) and Relyea (1983) consider the Atlantic and Gulf populations to be conspecific. According to McEachran and Fechhelm (1998), there is an allopatric population of F. majalis in the Florida Keys and Florida Bay which may represent a distinct species. If F. similis is valid, then all Gulf of Mexico F. majalis should be considered F. similis (Duggins et al. 1995).
A recent taxonomic revision of this genus was conducted by Ho et al. (2010).
A subspecies, Hoplostethus mediterraneus trunovi, has been reported off of Namibia (Moore in press).
Howella atlantica is considered by some a subspecies of Howella brodiei Ogilby, 1899, although accepted by Eschmeyer (2015).

Lepophidium entomelan and L. zophochir are similar, disjunctly distributed species. Further sampling in the Southern Caribbean may reveal an adjacency or overlap in distribution that will clarify relationships between the species (R. Robins pers. comm. 2012).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.
Records in the northwestern Gulf of Mexico are suspected to be O. pantostictus due to taxonomic issues within the genus (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
Populations of this species in the Western Atlantic versus the Pacific may represent two separate species (Kotlyar 2001).
This species was previously known as Parexocoetus brachypterus or Parexocoetus brachypterus hillianus, but the Atlantic population was raised to species level by Parin (2003).
Before its description by Parin in 1999, it was usually misidentified as Prognichthys gibbifrons (Valenciennes 1846).

Previously known as Prognichthys gibbifrons throughout the Atlantic, but Parin (1999) described P. occidentalis for the western Atlantic population and P. glaphyrae for open waters of the tropical Atlantic, leaving the eastern Atlantic population to retain the name of Prognichthys gibbifrons.

This species is synonymous with B. californicus, based on the lack of differentiation in DNA barcodes between individuals with this color pattern and those with the B. fervidus s. str. color pattern (Williams et al. 2014).

Williams (1998) and Williams et al. (2014) consider that Bombus intrudens, B. variabilis, B. sololensis, B. guatemalensis, and B. mysticus might all be parts of one species based on morphological evidence, noting the lack of any documented reason (other than differences in colour pattern) why these five taxa should not be considered conspecific. Further study is hampered by a lack of fresh material of North American B. variabilis for analysis of genetic relationships. Although B. intrudens is the oldest available name for this species, the name B. variabilis has been in common use for the species since 1950, and it could be argued that the latter name be used in the interest of stability (Williams 1998).

Williams (2014) provides a detailed review of the taxonomic status of this species. In short, a number of authors have regarded this species as conspecific with B. auricomus, while other authors have treated them as separate. Williams (2014) and Williams et al. (2014) considers them separate based on morphological and colour patterns (Williams 1998), allozymes (Scholl et al. 1992), and DNA sequence data (Cameron et al. 2007, and more recent unpublished work).

Recent DNA barcodes support that Bombus sonorus is conspecific with B. pensylvanicus (Williams et al. 2014). A population from the south of Mexico (state of Chiapas) is morphologically and genetically distinct from the rest of North America, and could be a separate undescribed species. Further sampling is needed to clarify the situation.
This species had a genus change in 2016 according to Poulsen et al., and should now be considered as Monacoa grimaldii. need to request change in SIS
The species was named in honor of its collector, F. M. McElfresh.
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney in press).
This species may be a misidentification of C. suttkus.
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney in press).
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney in press).
This species is sometimes referred to as Argyropelecus olfersi.
Preliminary molecular studies suggest that the genus Schedophilus is not monophyletic (Milana et al. 2011)

The taxonomy of C. niger does not appear to be resolved; while Melo (2009) recognizes seven species in the genus, Prokofiev and Kukuev (2009) placed many of these species in synonymy with C. niger, only recognizing two species in genus.
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney and Hartel 2016).

The scientific name North American river otter was formerly Lutra canadensis.  Although Lutra may still occasionally be used in some common literature, Lontra is now the accepted genus name for the species (Van Zyll de Jong 1972, 1987; Kellnhauser 1983, Wozencraft 2005).

Three regional subspecies originally described by Wilson et al. (1991) have been confirmed by Cronin et al. (1996): E. l. lutris (Linnaeus, 1758) from Japan in the southwest Pacific throughout the Asian range of the Kuril Islands to the Kamchatka Peninsula and the Commander Islands, E. l. kenyoni from the western Aleutian Islands to Prince William Sound, Alaska, USA, along the Pacific coast of Canada and into Oregon state in the continental USA, and E. l. nereis (Merriam, 1904) from central to southern California, USA.

This bat was referred to as Corynorhinus macrotis in older literature, and Corynorhinus townsendii was known as C. rafinesquii. Bogdanowicz et al. (1998) examined morphological and chromosomal variation and found that Corynorhinus is strongly supported as a distinct genus, with Plecotus limited to Palaearctic species. The mammal list by Simmons (2005) also accepted Corynorhinus as the appropriate genus for New World big-eared bats.

Eger (1977) revised the genus and recognized E. g. floridanus (Allen 1932) in Florida and E. g. glaucinus in Cuba, Jamaica, Central America, and South America.
