Akialoa ellisiana, A. stejnegeri and A. lanaiensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Hemignathus and lumped as H. ellisianus following AOU (1998 and supplements).
Himatione sanguinea and H. fraithii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. sanguinea following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Argia plana Calvert, 1902 is considered a junior synonym of Argia funebris (Hagen, 1861), so the A. funebris before considered a tropical species now reaches Oklahoma and northern Texas in the middle of the USA (Rosser W. Garrison pers. comn.).

The species name is sometimes spelled Melanoides tuberculatus (see Madhyastha 2012), but this is incorrect because Melanoides Olivier, 1804 was clearly intended to be feminine as it was combined with the feminine specific epithet fasciolata in the original description.
The genus Gyrinomimus is being revised by John Paxton (Moore et al. 2003).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.
This species was previously referred to as Lophotus lacepede on the west coast of North America (Craig et al. 2004, Kells et al. 2016).

Historically, a few authors have argued that European (Anguilla anguilla) and American Eels might actually be conspecific (vertebral count differences were believed to be entirely ecophenotypic), although this was never considered to be very likely (Van Den Avyle 1984) and has been clearly shown to be incorrect by a variety of types of information. Separate species status has been confirmed by recent demonstrations that American and European Eels comprise two largely separate gene pools (see Avise et al. 1990, Bastrop et al. 2000, Avise 2003, Bernatchez, St-Cyr et al. 2011). Eels in Iceland include, in low frequency, the products of hybridization between American and European eels (Avise et al. 1990, Avise 2003, Albert et al. 2006, Pujolar et al. 2014). Phylogenies of the genus Anguilla constructed based on mitochondrial DNA have shown the two species to be distinct, although more closely related than most species of the genus (Aoyama et al. 2001, Minegishi et al. 2005).

The preponderance of evidence indicates that American Eels do not exhibit significant geographic or latitudinal patterns of genetic variation (Avise et al. 1986, Avise 2003, Wirth and Bernatchez 2003, Côté et al. 2013). However, Bernatchez, Côté et al. (2011) suggest that there may be minor quantitative genetic differences between American glass eels colonizing different parts of the range despite the fact that all belong to a single genetic population. They consider that plausible explanations for this pertain either to non-random dispersal or to selective mortality based on individual genetic differences. They emphasize that on one hand, evidence for panmixia justifies the need for global co-operative action toward improved management and conservation of the species, but that on the other hand, evidence for local genetically based phenotypic differences also justify the need for local actions, citing eels of the St. Lawrence River basin as an example.

Hall (1981) treated M. broweri as a subspecies of M. caligata, but Jones et al. (1992) and Hoffman et al. (in Wilson and Reeder 1993) and Thorington and Hoffmann (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) recognized M. broweri and M. caligata as distinct species.

There are three subspecies of this butterfly: the nominate subspecies astyalus (Godart, 1819); subspecies hippomedon (Felder & Felder, 1859); and subspecies phanias (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906) (Warren et al. 2016).  


Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

This species was recently proposed, following the discovery that southwestern and eastern populations of Heraclides cresphontes differed both genetically and in wing patterning (Shiraiwa et al. 2014). Described as part of the genus Heraclides, but now part of the genus Papilio, of which Heraclides is a subgenus (see below).

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).
This species is very similar to Anotopterus pharao and may need further taxonomic investigation (Mundy 2005).

This species is listed as valid by Sato and Nakabo (2002) and Kobyliansky (2013) without explanation. Previously, the species was considered a synonym of Chlorophthalmus agassizi, and further taxonomic work is needed to resolve its validity.
This species can be easily misidentified as Scopelosaurus harryi, and some workers have considered it a synonym of S. harryi previously (Balanov and Savinykh 1999, Milkova et al. 2016).
This species can be easily confused with Scopelosaurus adleri (Milkova et al. 2016).

Harry (1953) reported that the two known types were not conspecific and recognized the holotype as a valid species and the paratype was described as a new species, Lestidium neles (now Lestidiops neles). Some records from the western Pacific Ocean were confused with Lestidiops jayakari (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).
This species may belong in the genus Lestidiops. The taxonomy of Lestidiops is quite confused and a complete revision is needed (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.

The nearly circumtropical T. myops was recently separated into three valid species: T. myops, restricted to the Atlantic Ocean; T. trachnius, known from throughout the Indo-West Pacific; and T. gauguini known from the Marquesas Islands (Polanco et al. 2016) and New Ireland, PNG (Wang et al. 2018). However, more recent genetic analyses suggest that this may actually consist of several cryptic species in the Western Indian Ocean (B. Russell unpublished data). More research is needed to resolve this.

According to Moore (2002), this species is only known from juvenile specimens and some specimens identified as Anoplogaster cornuta may be adult forms of A. brachycera. The validity of this species is in question due to recent genetic analyses (J. Moore pers. comm. 2018).
Savinykh and Baitalyuk (2011) suggested Trachipterus altivelis is a junior synonym of T. trachypterus, but this requires further study.
<span id="docs-internal-guid-39cb8422-7fff-0882-ba8c-052d6bbd6d58">The family Veliferidae is in need of revision (Olney 1999).

This species was previously considered a synonym of P. dentex (Bloch & Schneider 1801 (Springer and Smith-Vaniz 2008, Eschmeyer et al. 2017). Genetic studies may be needed to resolve the taxonomic confusion (Randall and Cea 2011). However, until more information is available, it is treated here as a valid species.

This species was previously considered a junior synonym of Seriola lalandi, until Martinez-Takeshita et al. (2015) considered it to be distinct based on genetic data. Evidence reported by Purcell et al. (2015) reinforces the distinctiveness of these populations, but further research is needed to improve the spatial resolution of genetic structure in some regions.
The taxonomy of the species in the genera Samaris and Samariscus is still in need of further work.
There are two recognized subspecies in North America: Bison bison bison and B. b. athabascae.

The status of the subspecies is unclear. Although eight subspecies have been recognized (Seymour 1989), morphological and genetic analyses do not support the existence of discrete subspecies (Larson 1997, Eizirik et al. 2001, Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2006). While not elevating the regional differences to the subspecies level, Eizirk et al. (2001) found evidence for four incompletely isolated phylogeographic groups: Mexico and Guatemala, southern Central America, northern South America, and South America south of the Amazon River. Similarly, Ruiz-Garcia et al. (2006) found that the Andes Mountains incompletely isolates Jaguar populations in Colombia.

Neotoma bryanti formerly was known as N. lepida intermedia (Patton et al. 2008). This species now also includes the previously recognized insular species N. anthonyi, N. martinensis, and N. bunkeri, and all other insular named taxa (excluding insularis from Ángel de la Guarda) as subspecies (Patton et al. 2014).

Taxonomy of the genus Centrophorus has been much controverted during the last fifty years. Part of the confusion has been focused on two species with sessile dermic denticles (thus different from C. squamosus) whose most conspicuous anatomic differences are maximum size and size at sexual maturity. The species assessed here is to be considered the “smaller” species, and has been recently reported under the name of C. granulosus or C. uyato. In Australia, this species has been referred to as C. zeehaani.

Taxonomic confusion comes from a long history of mistakes in the literature but also from a problem of nomenclature. A recent review by White et al. (2013) included a re-description and the settlement of a neotype of the “larger species” as C. granulosus (Bloch and Schneider 1801). Nomenclature status of this species is pending a paper in preparation that is based on classic taxonomy, review of nomenclature and genetic data, and that will also include a re-description of the species (Guallart et al. 2013, Veríssimo et al. 2014).

At present this assessment is presented under the name C. uyato (Rafinesque 1810) pending this review. It must be noted that this species is assumed not to fit the description made as Squalus uyato by Rafinesque (1810) but its first descriptions of reference are those made as Spinax uyatus by Bonaparte (1834) and Müller and Henle (1839) as C. granulosus.

Apristurus atlanticus was previously distinguished from A. laurussonii (Nakaya and Sato 1998), however Iglésias and Nakaya (2004) could not find any significant differences between the holotype of A. atlanticus and A. laurussonii, and therefore consider A. atlanticus to be a junior synonym of A. laurussonii.

Research is required to clarify the taxonomic status of nominal records of A. laurussonii from the US east coast, Gulf of Mexico, and Caribbean (Nakaya and Sato 1998, Kiraly et al. 2003). These records are not considered here to represent A. laurussonii, and as such these regions are not included in this assessment.

Nominal records of this species from the Eastern Atlantic are possibly A. manis or another species of Apristurus (Ebert and Stehmann 2013). This species is potentially confused with A. laurussoni of which there are only two confirmed records west of Iceland — one from “Davis Strait” on the Canadian side and the other in the Denmark Strait between Iceland and Greenland (Møller et al. 2010).
A careful examination of North Atlantic vs. southern African forms is needed.

The distinction between R. atlantica and R. pacifica is problematic and based solely on the number of caudal tubercles, a highly variable and often overlapping characteristic (tends to be greater in R. atlantica). Resolution on the distinction of these two species will require examination of a larger series of specimens and potentially molecular data (Compagno et al. 1990).
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

This species is part of a complex of giant black or purple-black species of Hydrolagus, which includes H. affinis and all 'trolli-like' species from Australia and New Zealand, South Africa, the southern Atlantic, and the California coast including the Davidson and San Juan Seamounts in the Eastern Pacific. The giant black Hydrolagus from the Atlantic is likely Hydrolagus affinis; however, the giant black or purple-black species of Hydrolagus from the Pacific may represent at least two separate species, one of which is H. purpurescens (Gilbert, 1905). Hydrolagus eidolon (Jordan & Hubbs, 1925) described from Sagami Bay, Japan, is here considered a synonym of H. purpurescens.

This species belongs to the long-snout group of Centrophorus which includes C. harrissoni, C. isodon, C. seychellorum, and C. westraliensis. The long-snout species group requires further taxonomic attention (White et al. 2017).
Yano et al. (2004) confirm that sleeper sharks found in the South Atlantic Ocean and Southern Ocean are a separate species, Somniosus antarcticus Whitley, 1939.
In geographic regions other than North America sharks referred to as this species are Etmopterus baxteri or Etmopterus unicolor (Compagno and Niem 1998).

While there has been some previous discussion over the validity of Hydrolagus pallidus, recent research confirms that H. pallidus is genetically distinct from H. affinis (Violi et al. 2018). Some genetic evidence suggests H. lusitanicus is synonymous with H. pallidus (Violi et al. 2018).
Appearance is very similar to Hydrolagus pallidus; recent research confirms that H. affinis is genetically distinctive from H. pallidus (Violi et al. 2018).
The quality of taxonomic identification of some skate species may be an issue particularly with historic data, however, Bathyraja spinicauda is a relatively easy species to identify.

There are only two possible specimens from Grand Banks, that have been taken to represent the Western Atlantic. These are likely to be confused with Rajella bathyphila in Canada as older specimens captured there tended to be named Rajella lintea (D. Kulka pers. comm. (20/06/2019).
This species has been confused with Breviraja spinosa in the past.

Sympatric to the Winter Skate (Leucoraja ocellata), immature Little Skates are often confused with immature Winter Skates (especially females). However, the probability of misidentification decreases with skate size as they mature. Skates originally identified as little skate in the Gulf of St. Lawrence were later confirmed as winter skate.

The genus has changed from Raja to Leucoraja (McEachran and Dunn 1998). This assessment assumes a single species. However, populations north of Cape Hatteras have been considered as the subspecies L. garmani virginica while those between the Cape and the Dry Tortugas have been considered as L. g. garmani, but they may represent two distinct species (McEachran 1977, McEachran 2002).

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000).

In the northwest Atlantic, this species is easily confused with Arctic skate (Amblyraja hyperborea)  (Bigelow and Shroeder 1953). There is clear geographic separation of both species and tooth count distributions are almost completely separated, but all other meristics are not significantly different (D.W. Kulka unpubl. data 2019). Further, Jensen's Skate is genetically indistinguishable from Arctic Skate (Amblyraja hyperborea) using COI barcoding. In-turn the sequence divergence between both these species and Badia’s Skate (A. badia) is minimal (0.2 to 0.3%). This could result from (1) hybridization, (2) they are all the same species, or (3) “recent divergence and insufficient time for reciprocal monophyly to have occurred” and distinguishing among these hypotheses would require evaluation with other molecular markers (Coulson et al. 2011).
A comparison of Southeastern to North Atlantic specimens should be carried out to determine if both populations are the same species.
Often confused with Breviraja claramaculata.
McEachran and Dunne (1998) moved this species from genus Raja to Amblyraja.

Sympatric to the Little Skate, immature specimens of the two species are often confused, especially females. However, chance of misidentification decreases as they mature. Disk is rounded, with many small dark spots on upper surface. Usually 1-4 ocelli are found on the upper surface on each side of disk, each with a dark brownish center and pale edge. Young have long middorsal row of large spines on disk and tail. Upper jaw has 72 rows of teeth. Lower surface is usually white but marked with irregular pale brownish blotches (although this colouration is found in several other species within range).
Often confused with Breviraja claramaculata.

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000). This species was previously known as Galeus arae antillensis (in part) and was noted as the island form of Galeus arae (Springer 1979).

There has been a great deal of historic uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Eastern Pacific gymnurids, with some authors considering Gymnura crebripunctata to be a junior synonym of G. marmorata. However, Smith et al. (2009) confirmed the validity of G. crebripunctata as a distinct species using both morphometric and molecular techniques.
 
In previous IUCN Red List publications Gymnura marmorata included G. crebripunctata as a synonym. Therefore assessments of G. marmorata from 2012 onwards are not directly comparable with previous assessments under that name.

While there are reported subpopulations of Squalus acanthias (Linnaeus, 1758) elsewhere in the world, the North Pacific subpopulation is now considered a separate species, Squalus suckleyi (Girard, 1854) (see Ebert et al. 2010). Further taxonomic studies on this genus are required, including in relation to Mediterranean and Black Sea subpopulations. In Europe, three subpopulations are inferred to occur.
Molecular phylogenetic results (e.g., Koepfli et al. 2008) indicate that the Fisher should in the future be classified in a monospecific genus Pekania Gray, 1865.
Meurgey (2016) treats Brechmorhoga grenadensis as a subspecies of B. praecox.
Transferred from the genus Hylogomphus to Gomphus as the former is now a subgenus.
Hemignathus lucidus, H. hanapepe and H. affinis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. lucidus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Even though some previous studies have treated Limia as one of the multiple subgenera in the genus Poecilia (Rosen and Bailey 1963, Meredith et al. 2010, Meredith et al. 2011), several other works have supported the generic classification for Limia (Rodriguez 1997, Hamilton 2001, Poeser 2003, Palacios et al. 2016, Weaver et al. 2016). Here we endorse the latter assessment that Limia should be considered a valid, separate genus.

The taxonomic role of genera to express relationships among species is clearly justified in the case of Limia from different points of view. From the biogeographic point of view, species of Limia show a discrete distribution since they are only found in the Antilles, specifically on Hispaniola, Cuba, Jamaica and the island of Grand Cayman. However, only three species of Poecilia sensu strictu occur in this region and they are restricted exclusively to Hispaniola. In addition, recent phylogenetic analyses have found Limia to be a monophyletic group probably originated from a South American ancestor with the three Hispaniolan Poecilia species mentioned above representing the closest sister group (Palacios et al. 2016, Weaver et al. 2016). A very detailed analysis is currently in prep, also confirming Limia as monophyletic (Spikes et al. in prep). Moreover, there is enough morphological distinctiveness in characters with adaptive value such is the case of gonopodial traits to separate species of Limia and Poecilia (Rivas 1978). Furthermore, all of the existing ecological and behavioral literature is using Limia, not Poecilia. Not recognizing Limia as a separate genus from Poecilia may obscure their similarities and cause even more confusion in a group that in fact deserves more taxonomic attention.

At least some specimens previously identified as M. ginkgodens have been re-identified as the recently resurrected M. hotaula (Dalebout et al. 2014), which has resulted in some confusion about the distribution of both species.
The taxonomy of species in the Mugilidae family is complex and under revision.
The genus Monomitopus is in need of revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).

According to the Catalog of Fishes, this species has been synonymized with Brephostoma carpenteri; however, recent genetic studies of both species indicate they are valid as separate (J. Moore pers. comm. 2019).
This species is easily confused with Neoscopelus macrolepidotus (Roberts 2015).

Wiens and Penkrot (2002) examined variation in Sceloporus jarrovii using morphological and DNA data and found that three approaches each supported division of S. jarrovii into five species, but only two species were the same among the three approaches. They found the greatest support for the five species that were delimited by mtDNA data. Following Wiens and Penkrot (2002) and Wiens et al. (1999), S. jarrovii occurs in Arizona, New Mexico, and Mexico and the other four species (S. cyanostictus, S. minor, S. oberon, and S. sugillatus) occur in Mexico. These species do not strictly conform with traditional subspecies circumscriptions. We currently follow Wiens and Penkrot (2002) in retaining S. lineolateralis within S. jarrovii.
There is some taxonomic uncertainty within this species complex that requires further work (Mundy 2005).
There is possibly confusion between identifications of Diaphus aliciae and D. impostor, and taxonomic work is ongoing (A. Williams and J. Paxton pers. comm. 2018).
Lampanyctus fernae has been misidentified as L. ritteri in the past (Wisner 1976).
This species has been misidentified as Lampanyctus atrum in the past (Mundy 2005).
According to Evseenko (2008), Triphoturus mexicanus has two genetically different forms; one in California and one in Peru.
Closely related to Elops saurus of the western Atlantic.

This species was removed from the genus Agosia and placed in the genus Rhinichthys by Woodman (1992). Simons and Mayden (1999) recommended that the species be retained in the monotypic genus Agosia until its relationships are further clarified. Nelson et al. (2004) followed this recommendation.
Monotypic genus; the only North American freshwater representative of a large family.

This species is distinguished from other Campostoma by numerous morphological and biochemical characteristics (Buth and Burr 1978), but it is morphologically variable in confounding geographic patterns. Taxonomic status of the two allopatric (Arizona, Texas) U.S. populations warrants further study (Starnes 1995).

This species was regarded as member of genus Pantosteus by Clarkson and Minckley (1988); other authors regard Pantosteus as a subgenus (Sublette et al. 1990). See Clarkson and Minckley (1988) for information on hybridization between Catostomus clarkii and Catostomus insignis. See Smith (1992) for a study of the phylogeny and biogeography of the Catostomidae. See also Crabtree and Buth (1987) for information on taxonomic relationships.
This species is going to be split into two different species. D. diaboli with distribution in the US and in Rio Conchos in Mexico.
Other workers have questioned the separation of this species from Brotulotaenia crassa in the past, but Nielsen and Møller (2015) consider it a valid species.
Molecular studies suggest that the genus Schedophilus is not monophyletic (Milana et al. 2011).
This species was previously considered a possible synonym of Pseudoscopelus scriptus by Prokofiev and Kukuev (2007), but further investigation by Prokofiev (2011, 2014) concluded it is valid.

The Gila robusta complex includes nominal species G. robusta, G. intermedius, and G. nigrescens, all of which are described from the lower Colorado River basin in Arizona and New Mexico (Page et al. 2017). While they are currently considered valid, several studies suggest combining the complex under the senior synonym G. robusta (Page et al. 2017, Carter et al. 2018, Copus et al. 2018). Observed morphological and genetic variation is likely the result of past geographic isolation and differentiation followed by recent mixing and hybridization (Page et al. 2017). If such changes occur, reassessment is warranted based on a non-genuine change in total population size and distribution.

Species delineation across R. cataractae s. l. has been an area of controversy for nearly a century (Kim and Conway 2014). Several subspecies have been proposed, although the validity of some are still a topic of debate (Rusket and Taylor 2016). Some evidence suggests that species level consideration is warranted for western and eastern populations (Kim and Conway 2014). Pending formal descriptions of species level delineation, non-genuine changes in the distribution or listing of R. cataractae are likely, which may warrant reassessment.

Rhinichthys osculus exhibits high genetic diversity throughout much of its native range, under which several subspecies have been proposed or validated (Oakey et al. 2004, Billman et al. 2010, Hoekzema and Sidlaukis 2014, Wiesenfeld et al. 2018). Some studies suggest that many of these populations warrant consideration at the species level (Hoekzema and Sidlaukis 2014). Pending description of the high cryptic diversity within the R. oculus subspecies complex, non-genuine changes in the distribution or listing of R. osculus are likely.

At the southern end of the range in Durango and Zacatecas, Mexico, the population in the Pacific slope Rio Mesquital drainage was markedly genetically divergent from populations in the Rio Nazas and Rio Aguanaval drainages; possibly two different taxa are represented (Ferris et al. 1982, Echelle 1991). Miller (2005) recognized the Rio Nazas population as distinct (Catostomus nebuliferus). Populations in the rios Fuerte, Mezquital, and Piaxtla (Pacific Slope of Mexico) may constitute one or more distinct taxa and (pending further study) that were not identified to the species level (Miller 2005, Unmack et al. 2014).
Campostoma spadiceum (highland stoneroller), formerly included in this species, was recognized as a distinct species by Cashner et al. (2010).
This species is part of the Diaphus fulgens complex in the eastern Pacific (Wisner 1976).

Becker (1964) recognised four valid species of Centrobranchus, and was followed by most authors until the review of Gago and Lavenberg (1992), who recognised only the two species C. andrae and C. nigroocellatus. A number of authors in the last decade have considered Centrobranchus choerocephalus (Fowler, 1904) a valid species without mention of the problems described in Gago and Lavenberg (1992). The record of C. choerocephalus from Lord Howe Island (Allen et al. 1976), inadvertently omitted from the first Zoological Catalogue of Australia, Pisces (Paxton et al. 1989), and subsequent editions, is now considered C. nigroocellatus (J. Paxton pers. comm. 2018).
This species is very similar to Protomyctophum crockeri (Shinohara et al. 1994).

This species was originally described as distinct from Tarletonbeania crenularis by Eigenmann and Eigenmann in 1890. Gilbert (1915) reports that original described differences between T. tenua and T. crenularis are due to the poor condition of the original specimens and that T. tenua and T. crenularis are not significantly different. Parr (1929) accepted Gilbert’s opinion on this and also T. tenua as a junior synonym of T. crenularis. Kobayashi (1958) refers to T. tenua as a junior synonym of T. crenularis. In summary, it is doubtful that T. tenua is a valid species.
Some workers consider this species to be a synonym of Scopelgenys tristis (Becker and Shcherbachev 1990, Mundy 2005).

The Sei Whale, Balaenoptera borealis is a recognized species but catch and sightings records of Sei Whales prior to 1972 tended to include Bryde's Whales (B. edeni or B. brydei) in areas where both species occur. The Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (Committee on Taxonomy 2017) recognizes two subspecies, B. b. borealis in the Northern Hemisphere and B. b. schlegelii in the Southern Hemisphere, as proposed by Tomilin (1957). The Sei Whales found in the North Pacific and North Atlantic have not been formally compared and so are still placed in the same nominate subspecies by default, although Huijser et al. (2018) found a high degree of genetic divergence between North Atlantic and North Pacific Sei Whales.
Loxops coccineus, L. ochraceus and L. wolstenholmei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. coccineus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species is a synonym of Cynoscion parvipinnis (Chao et al. 1995, Chao 2002).

Poecilia sonoriensis is considered a valid species from the formerly synonymized P. occidentalis (Minckley and Marsh 2009, Eschmeyer et al. 2018), supported by genetic evidence by Parker et al. (1998) and Hedrick et al. (2001). Changes to current systematics would likely warrant reassessment of this species.
Original orthography is stearnsii.
This species is often misidentified with cogenerics.
Pica nutalli (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as P. nuttalli.

Setophaga striata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
This species previously synonymized with Poromitra crassiceps.

Hesperiphona vespertina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Coccothraustes and listed as C. vespertinus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Antrostomus vociferus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus. Caprimulgus vociferus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously split into C. vociferus and C. arizonae following AOU (2010).

Lonchura oryzivora (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Padda following AOU (1998 & supplements); Christidis & Boles (2008); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Chloris sinica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Setophaga caerulescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Anser caerulescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Chen.

Branta canadensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as B. canadensis and B. hutchinsii following AOU (2004), and before then lumped as B. canadensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Aratinga nenday (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Nandayus.

Euodice cantans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Lonchura following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Euodice malabarica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Lonchura following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Crithagra mozambica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Serinus and listed as S. mozambicus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Haemorhous mexicanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carpodacus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Geothlypis tolmiei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Oporornis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Ammospiza nelsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Ammodramus following AOU (1998 & supplements).
Bubo virginianus and B. magellanicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as B. virginianusfollowing Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Alauda arvensis (AERC TAC [2003]; AOU [1998 and supplements]; Christidis and Boles [2008]; Cramp et al. [1977-1994]; Dowsett and Forbes-Watson [1993]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]; Turbott [1990]) and A. japonica (Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into A. arvensis following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

Catharus ustulatus and C. swainsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. ustulatus following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Catharus ustulatus and C. swainsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. ustulatus following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Pternistis erckelii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Francolinus.

Alexandrinus krameri (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Psittacula krameri (del Hoyo et al. 2014). Braun et al. (2019) report the situation where the parrot genera Psittinus, Tanygnathus and Mascarinus nest genetically within Psittacula, meaning that either Psittacula replaces these latter three genera or it breaks down into monophyletic genera of their own. The latter course is preferred, building on Braun et al. (2016), where several genera were established, including Alexandrinus for P. krameri, P. eques and P. exsul.
Spinus psaltria (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Passerella arborea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Spizella following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Melozone fusca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as M. fuscus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Setophaga americana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Parula following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Setophaga occidentalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Setophaga virens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Setophaga palmarum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Setophaga castanea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Tangara episcopus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Thraupis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Melanospiza bicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Tiaris following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Setophaga dominica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AOU (1998 & supplements).

Oxyura jamaicensis and O. ferruginea (incorporating andina) (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. jamaicensis following SACC (2005), and before then were split as O. jamaicensis (incorporating andina) and O. ferruginea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Myiopsitta monachus and M. luchsi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. monachus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Oenanthe oenanthe and O. seebohmi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. oenanthe following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 and supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Passerella iliaca, P. unalaschcensis, P. schistacea and P. megarhyncha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. iliaca following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Passerella iliaca, P. unalaschcensis, P. schistacea and P. megarhyncha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. iliaca following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Passerella iliaca, P. unalaschcensis, P. schistacea and P. megarhyncha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. iliaca following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Passerculus sandwichensis, P. guttatus, P. sanctorum and P. rostratus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. sandwichensis following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements).

Troglodytes troglodytes, T. pacificus and T. hiemalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. troglodytes following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Thryothorus ludovicianus and T. albinucha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. ludovicianus (see AOU [1998 & supplements]; Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]).
Puffinus bryani (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was first described by Pyle et al. (2011).

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.

Rallus longirostris, R. crepitans and R. obsoletus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. longirostris following AOU (2000). Rallus elegans and R. tenuirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. elegans following AOU (2000). Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) included tenuirostris within R. longirostris.
This species was previously misidentified as Hime japonica (Gomon and Struthers 2015).

Hydrobates castro (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into H. castro and H. jabejabe (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Previously, Oceanodroma castro (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was been split into O. castro and O. monteiroi following Bolton et al. (2008) and all Oceanodroma species were moved to Hydrobates (del Hoyo and Collar 2014).

Hydrobates leucorhous has been split into H. leucorhous, H. socorroensis and H. cheimomnestes (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018), based on the proposal of Howell (2012).

Hydrobates leucorhous (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into H. leucorhous, H. socorroensis and H. cheimomnestes (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018), based on the proposal of Howell (2012).

Catharacta skua (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Stercorarius.

Catharacta skua, C. antarctica and C. maccormicki (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), cross-regional species, are retained as separate species contra Christidis and Boles (1994) and Turbott (1990) who include lonnbergi and antarctica as subspecies of C. skua and AERC TAC (2003) who include C. maccormicki as a subspecies of C. skua.

Catharacta maccormicki (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Stercorarius.

Catharacta skua, C. antarctica and C. maccormicki (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), cross-regional species, are retained as separate species contra Christidis and Boles (1994) and Turbott (1990) who include lonnbergi and antarctica as subspecies of C. skua and AERC TAC (2003) who include C. maccormicki as a subspecies of C. skua.
Hydrocoloeus minutus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Larus.
Thalasseus maximus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. maxima.
Thalasseus bergii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

Schmitter-Soto: for many years, this species was considered a synonym of A. mexicanus. The latter has been restricted to central-western Mexico, whereas A. argentatus is the species widespread in northern Mexico and Texas.
Sternula antillarum (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Onychoprion lunatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. lunata.

F. g. audoboni, recognised in del Hoyo and Collar (2014), is here synonymised with F. g. glacialis following the observation that the difference is based upon a cline and that there is no genetic evidence whatsoever to indicate a distinction (Kerr and Dove 2013).
Ardenna pacifica (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus as P. pacificus.
Ardenna bulleri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Ardenna creatopus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Ardenna gravis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Ardenna tenuirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Hydrobates microsoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genera Oceanodroma and Halocyptena.
Hydrobates homochroa (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.
Pterodroma feae and P. deserta (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. feae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Calonectris diomedea and C. borealis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. diomedea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), which was also formerly lumped with C. edwardsii following Hazevoet (1995), contra Brooke (2004).

Calonectris diomedea and C. borealis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. diomedea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), which was also formerly lumped with C. edwardsii following Hazevoet (1995), contra Brooke (2004).
Pterodroma feae and P. deserta (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. feae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sula dactylatra (AOU 1998 + updates) and Sula tasmani (Christidis and Boles 1994) have been lumped as S. dactylatra following Christidis and Boles (2008).
Pterodroma macroptera and P. gouldi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. macroptera following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Puffinus lherminieri (incorporating baroli), P. bannermani, P. persicus, P. subalaris and P. bailloni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. lherminieri and baroli was subsumed under P. assimilis, following Brooke (2004), before which P. bannermani and P. persicus where split following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Synthliboramphus hypoleucus and S. scrippsi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as S. hypoleucus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
This species was resurrected from synonymy under Spectrunculus grandis by Uiblein et al. (2008).

Calliphlox evelynae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been moved to the genus Nesophlox Ridgway, 1910, on the basis that Abrahamczyk et al. (2015) demonstrated that the species is sister to Mellisuga Brisson, 1760 and Feo et al. (2015) showed that it falls within a clade that also includes Mellisuga and Archilochus Reichenbach, 1854. 

Subsequently, N. evelynae (=C. evelynae [del Hoyo and Collar 2014]) has been split into N. evelynae and N. lyrura (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018).

Cibois et al. (2016) found that Procelsterna sits within Anous, which is accepted and results in P. cerulea changing name to Anous ceruleus (HBW and BirdLife International 2018). Procelsterna cerulea and P. albivitta (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cerulea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into six genera, with P. penicillatus, P. pelagicus and P. urile moved into Urile (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into six genera, with P. auritus, P. brasilianus and P. harrisi moved into Nannopterum (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into six genera, with P. auritus, P. brasilianus and P. harrisi moved into Nannopterum (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).
Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into six genera, with P. penicillatus, P. pelagicus and P. urile moved into Urile (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).
Calidris pygmaea (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Eurynorhynchus as E. pygmeus.
Also reported as Tilapia nilotica (antiquated name).
This species was previously misidentified as Melamphaes microps.

The placement of this species in the Macrouridae is not supported by current morphological and genetic analyses; instead, it belongs in the family Steindachneriidae (Howes 1993, Roa-Varón and Ortí 2009).
Species in the genus Barathronus were previously classified in the family Aphyonidae before reclassification to Bythitidae by Moller et al. (2016).
This species is commonly confused with Malacocephalus occidentalis and Ventrifossa mucocephalus (Cohen et al. 1990).
This species is commonly confused with Ventrifossa macropogon.

The systematics of the genus Chiasmodon is still poorly understood and the exact number of species is unknown. There are two main theories: Prokofiev and Kukuev (2009) consider the existence of only two species in the genus (C. niger and C. lavenbergi), while Melo (2009) defends the existence of seven species in the genus (including C. pluriradiatus). For the purpose of this assessment, we are treating C. pluriradiatus as a valid species. Further taxonomic research on this genus is needed.

Two species descriptions were occurring simultaneously, Kali caribbaea Prokofiev 2008 and K. colubrina Melo 2008. These descriptions were accepted and published within a very short time, leading to disagreement as to which species name had priority (Melo 2010, Prokofiev 2011). Based on the ICZN rules and interpretations, K. colubrina was given priority (e.g., Melo 2010, Eschmeyer et al. 2018).
There is an ongoing discussion on the correct identification of this species - especially whether it is valid in the Atlantic as according to Prokofiev (2009, 2011), or not (Melo 2010).

This species was considered a junior synonym of Bathyanthias cubensis by McEachran and Fechhelm (2005), but the Catalog of Fishes does not reference this. There are specimens of both B. cubensis and B. mexicanus taken off Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico, and they are recognized as distinct (M. Vegas-Cendejas pers. comm. 2018). However, specimens examined from Colombia by A. Polanco pers. comm. (2018) are recognized as B. cubensis. The genus Bathyanthias requires further taxonomic study, and it is not known how the ranges of B. mexicanus and B. cubensis overlap in the Gulf of Mexico (D.R. Robertson pers. comm. 2018).

Poulsen et al. (2018) placed this species under the family Neocyematidae and resolved the hypothesis that identified Leptocephalus holti specimens as Cyematidae larvae (Poulsen 2015, Poulsen et al. 2018).
This species is part of a complex of various forms of Melamphaes, and some further taxonomic work may be needed (Kotlyar 2011, Stewart and Bray 2015).

Bathophilus longipes has been treated as a junior synonym of B. digitatus by some authors, but is considered a valid species according to the Catalog of Fishes. Given this taxonomic uncertainty, its distribution is not clearly understood (T. Harold pers. comm. 2018).
This species was once considered a subspecies of Eustomias bigelowi (Parin and Pokhil’skaya 1974). It is considered a valid species by Clarke (2000, 2001) and Harold (2002).
Caryothraustes celaeno (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Rhodothraupis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Junco phaeonotus and J. bairdi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as J. phaeonotus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Passerculus bairdii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Ammodramus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Some variations were observed in the specimens collected from the Indonesian population. Examination of additional specimens may provide better information for the species (Ho et al. 2016).
Preliminary molecular and morphological analysis indicates Sladenia remiger may actually be a junior synonym of S. gardineri (J. Caruso pers. comm. 2019).

Basileuterus lachrymosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Euthlypis and listed as E. lachrymosa following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Oreothlypis superciliosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Parula following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
The genus Cataetyx needs revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
The genus Cataetyx needs revision (Nielsen et al. 1999).
The Microbrotula genus needs revision (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
This species is sometimes mis-identified as Astronesthes splendida (Nakabo 2002, Paxton et al. 2006, Liao et al. 2006).
This species has been misspelled as Astronesthes trifibulata in the past.
The genus Dicrolene needs urgent revision (Nielsen et al. 1999, J.G. Nielsen pers. comm. 2019).
A taxonomic revision is needed (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
Further taxonomic study is needed on specimens collected elsewhere in the Pacific that are potentially this species to clarify the extent of its distribution (Mundy 2005).
Specimens listed as Idiacanthus panamensis are tentatively considered to be synonyms of I. antrostomus (Gibbs 1964, Eschmeyer et al. 2018).
A revision of the Leptostomias genus is needed to clarify the distribution of this species (Mundy 2005).

Cyanecula svecica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Luscinia following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Poecile sclateri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus sclateri.
Cyanocorax morio (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Psilorhinus morio.

Vireo olivaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into Red-eyed Vireo V. olivaceus and Chivi Vireo V. chivi, as previously adopted by Stotz et al. (1996). Battey and Klicka (2017) strengthen this case on the basis of complete genetic separation and entirely antithetical patterns of movement but make no attempt to consider morphological characters. Boesman (2016) provides further support via finding that there is an extreme likelihood that there are consistent differences between the songs, (allowing a score of 4), plus chivi has a dark brown versus ruby-red iris (3) and the different migratory habits (maximum permitted score 1). Consequently, Chivi Vireo V. chivi is accorded species status.

Piranga hepatica and P. flava (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. hepatica following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Pyrocephalus rubinus, P. nanus and P. dubius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. rubinus following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

This species is distributed in two disjunct localities: the eastern Pacific (type locality) and eastern Indian Ocean (Caruso 1989). It is possible that specimens from these two localities represent distinct species, but further taxonomic research is needed (Caruso 1989, Lundsten et al. 2012, Ho and McGrouther 2015).

Chaunax stigmaeus is highly suspected to be a synonym of C. pictus, but until gene sequencing research is conducted, C. stigmaeus remains recognized as distinct (J. Caruso and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2018). Chaunax pictus is the older name, therefore, C. stigmaeus would be designated as a synonym of C. pictus.

This species was described by Tanaka (1918) and was later brought in to synonymy with Himantolophus groenlandicus Reinhardt, 1837 (Regan 1927, Bertelsen 1951). It is now considered valid according to Bertelsen and Krefft (1988); however, its validity is not recognized by Amaoka et al. (1995) or Nakabo (2002).
Thaumatichthys is a very poorly understood genus, and identifications of specimens are subject to change, pending the discovery of additional material (T. Pietsch pers. comm. 2019).
This species is easily confused with Halieutopsis nudiventer (Ho et al. 2013, Roberts et al. 2015).

This species is now considered endemic to the Hawaiian Islands, and all records previously identified from elsewhere are now attributed to the newer species, Malthopsis gigas (Ho and Shao 2010). It belongs to the Malthopsis annulifera species complex.

The taxonomy of the Malthopsis genus has been long debated, and is in need of further revision (Bradbury 2003). This species is quite distinct and is unlikely to be confused with other taxa (H. Ho pers. comm. 2019).

Leuconotopicus arizonae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Picoides. Picoides stricklandi (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously split into P. stricklandi and P. arizonae following AOU (2000).
Leuconotopicus villosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Picoides.
This species is currently comprised of two subspecies: Scopeloberyx malayanus balushkini and Scopeloberyx malayanus malayanus (Kotlyar 2004).
This species was previously considered a subspecies Scopelogadus mizolepis. A revision of the Scopelogadus genus is currently underway (J. Moore pers. comm. 2019).

Previously two subspecies of Megalagrion koelense were listed: M. koelense peles and M. koelense waianaeanum. The subspecies status is doubted, therefore only the nominate species is currently considered (see Polhemus 1997, Polhemus and Asquith 1996).

In a recent study, Faria et al. (2013) demonstrated that the existing taxonomy of the Pristidae required modification, recognising a total of five species in two genera. Pristis pristis had been recognised previously as consisting of up to three species (Pristis pristis, P. microdon and P. perotteti), but utilising a combination of mitochondrial DNA and morphological characters appears to be one species. While the P. pristis group is best considered a single species, it can be composed of a network of geographical units (subpopulations) that are not genetically distinct, but may be considered ecologically different.
 
Pristis pristis, has been referred to by many other names throughout its range. It was formerly known as P. perotteti in the Atlantic and sometimes in the Eastern Pacific, and P. microdon in the Indo-West Pacific.

Faria et al. (2013) state that both morphology and genetics support the current specific status of the Smalltooth Sawfish (Pristis pectinata) and propose modification of the distribution of the species to an Atlantic only range. No geographical structure of Smalltooth Sawfish subpopulations is present, and Western and Eastern Atlantic subpopulations of Smalltooth Sawfish likely represent separate units for conservation purposes.
There is some taxonomic uncertainty associated with this species (Struhsaker 1973).

Although Grubb (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) included canadensis in C. elaphus sharing this conclusion with most taxonomists of 20th century, all original scientific papers published since 1995 have concluded that C. elaphus and C. canadensis are two valid species regardless of whether this conclusion was based on comparison of molecular (Kuwuyama and Ozawa 1999, Randi et al. 2001, Ludt et al. 2004, Pitra et al. 2004, Zhang and Zhang 2012, Liu et al. 2013, Lorenzini and Garofalo 2015), or ethological data (Cap et al. 2008, Frey and Riede 2013). Based on morphological data this was suggested earlier by several authors, e.g. Lydekker (1898), Flerov (1952) and Geist (1998) and both recent reviews on cervid taxonomy are in line with this opinion (Groves and Grubb 2011, Mattioli 2011).

A recent analysis (Lorenzini and Garofolo 2015) of the Cervus group has provided the first indications of another, third, species (aside from Cervus nippon). Mitochondrial complete cytochrome b and control region sequences were analysed under a Bayesian coalescent framework to derive phylogeny, with particular attention on populations from Central Asia. The resultant phylogenetic reconstruction confirmed that red deer is differentiated into two robust monophyletic clades corresponding to the western and eastern part of the range. At the species level, molecular data suggested a fourth species should be recognised, the Tarim Red Deer from Central Asia, including the populations from the Yarkand-Tarim and Bukhara regions and Indian Kashmir, which were formerly considered as subspecies of C. elaphus (C. e. yarkandensis, C.e. bactrianus and C.e. hanglu, respectively). The authors suggest this taxon should be recognised as the Tarim Red Deer (Cervus hanglu, Wagner 1844), as the name with priority over C. yarkandensis or C. bactrianus. Further investigations need to be conducted from additional molecular sources and nuclear coding genes as well as verification of morphology from museum specimens, before the elevation of this taxon to species level can be confirmed (Lorenzini and Garofalo 2015). We provisionally follow this taxonomy here for the purpose of the IUCN Red List assessment in 2016. However, it should be noted that future clarification on genetic relatedness, especially studies with nuclear markers and a more formal morphological description, may lead to further revisions to the taxonomy of the provisional species, C. hanglu, as more information becomes available.

C.c. macneilli and wallichii are included here as subspecies of C. canadensis, both are sometimes placed in the “primitive group” of elaphines (with hanglu) based on morphological characters (Geist 1998, Groves 2003, Wilson and Mittermeier 2011), although genetic data place these taxa with the C. canadensis group (Ludt et al. 2004, Lorenzini and Garofalo 2015).

The North American population of the Wapiti has been split into a number of subspecies by various authors, including manitobensis, nelsoni, roosevelti, nannodes, canadensis and merriam (e.g. Meredith et al. 2007, Speller et al. 2014). Polziehn et al. (1998) conducted a phylogenetic study of North American Wapiti and concluded that there is a slight difference between North American Wapiti populations, most likely due to the limited numbers of founders of these populations, but that Roosevelt Elk (Cervus canadensis roosevelti) and Tule Elk (C. c. nannodes) are monophyletic which supports their subspecific status. Polziehn et al. (2000) questioned the subspecific status of C. c. manitobensis and C. c. nelsoni following analysis of 11 populations of North American Elk for genetic diversity.

Here we recognise the subspecies and their distributions as follows:

C. c. canadensis – N America
C. c. alashanicus – N China
C. c. nannodes - California
C. c. roosevelti - Vancouver Island, Washington state and Oregon
C. c. sibiricus – NE Kazakhstan and N Xinjiang to S Siberia and N Mongolia
C. c. xanthopygus – SE Siberia, Russian Far East, Ussuriland, Manchuria
C. c. macneilli – Lydekker 1909 (Central and SW China (N Qinghai, Gansu, Shaanxi, W Sichuan and E Xizang)
C. c. wallichii - G. Cuvier 1823 (SW China (SE Xizang), Bhutan)
There is taxonomic uncertainty associated with this recently described species. According to Prokofiev (2010), this species is a junior synonym of Chiasmodon lavenbergi.

According to Melo (2010), Pseudoscopelus parini and P. vityazi are the same species that was described twice using the same diagnostic characters. However, Prokofiev (2011) still regards P. vityazi as a valid species. According to Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes, P. vityazi is currently considered a synonym of P. parini (Fricke et al. 2019); therefore, for the purposes of this Red List assessment, all records of P. vityazi will be treated as P. parini.
Populations occurring in southwestern California and northern Baja California have recently been considered to be a distinct species, P. fraterculus (Hafner et al. 2001, Riddle et al. 2000).

Sardinops sagax has historically comprised five geographically isolated subpopulations that were given taxonomic names at some time in their history. There has been considerable confusion as to what rank these subpopulations should be recognized. The current version of the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer et al. 2018) accepts three valid species within this complex: S. sagax (Jenyns 1842), S. melanosticta (Temminck and Schlegel 1846) and S. ocellatus (Pappe 1853). However, the most recent global analyses found no morphological or genetic differentiation between any of the five subpopulations (Parrish et al. 1989, Grant and Leslie 1996). Therefore, for the purposes of this assessment, we are treating S. sagax as a single species with five geographically isolated subpopulations.

Randall and DiBattista (2012) proposed Etrumeus acuminatus as a valid species. According to the Catalog of Fishes, the name was valid in Eschmeyer and Herald (1983); but not in Whitehead (1985). This species was considered Etrumes teres, but was changed back to the older name Etrumeus sadina. All accounts of either Etrumeus teres or E. sadina in the eastern Pacific are most likely Etrumeus acuminatus (Randall and DiBattista 2012). DiBattista et al. (2014) provided molecular evidence that this species is valid and distinct from other species of Etrumeus from the Pacific Ocean.

This widespread species has the following subspecies:
Leiocephalus carinatus carinatus Gray, 1827,
Leiocephalus carinatus aquarius Schwartz & Ogren, 1956,
Leiocephalus carinatus armouri Barbour & Shreve, 1935,
Leiocephalus carinatus cayensis Schwartz, 1959,
Leiocephalus carinatus coryi Schmidt, 1936,
Leiocephalus carinatus granti Rabb, 1957,
Leiocephalus carinatus hodsdoni Schmidt, 1936,
Leiocephalus carinatus labrossytus Schwartz, 1959,
Leiocephalus carinatus microcyon Schwartz, 1959,
Leiocephalus carinatus mogotensis Schwartz, 1959,
Leiocephalus carinatus virescens Stejneger, 1901, and
Leiocephalus carinatus zayasi Schwartz, 1959.

L. varius, previously considered a subspecies, is treated as a full species following McCranie (2015).
In 2009, Craig et al. confirmed that the Pacific “subpopulations” of Epinephelus itajara as a distinct species: E. quinquefasciatus (Craig et al. 2009).

No subspecies of False Killer Whale (Pseudorca crassidens) are currently recognized. However, there is evidence of geographic variability in skull morphology and life history (Kitchener et al. 1990, Ferreira et al. 2014). Based on genetics there is substantial population structure, both between and within-ocean basins, and even within a single archipelago (Martien et al. 2014). This species has been intensively studied only in Hawaii (Baird 2016) and more recently in New Zealand (Zaeschmar 2014). In Hawaii, three subpopulations have been identified based on a combination of genetic studies (Martien et al. 2014), satellite tagging (Baird et al. 2010, 2012, 2014, Bradford et al. 2014a), and analyses of photo-identification data (Baird et al. 2008, Baird 2016). These include two partially overlapping insular populations, one around the main Hawaiian Islands, and one in the northwestern Hawaiian Islands, as well as a partially overlapping pelagic population that ranges throughout and beyond the U.S. Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) around the Hawaiian Archipelago. In New Zealand, based on high resighting rates of photo-identified individuals and a relatively small number of individuals documented, it is likely that this represents a distinct subpopulation (Zaeschmar 2014). While the number of subpopulations world-wide is unknown, this is due primarily to incomplete sampling in most of the range. Based on the evidence from Hawaii, subpopulation structure likely exists throughout their range.

authority: Johnson, Warén, Tunnicliffe, Van Dover, Wheat, Schultz & Vrijenhoek, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Although Macrobrachium grandimanus was previously considered to be endemic to the Hawaiian islands, it is now considered to also occur in Fiji, Tonga, the Rykyus, Moorea and New Caledonia.  As records of this species from Hainan Island (China) have been recently re-assigned to a new species, M. trichodactylum, the other non-Hawaiian records require further scrutiny.

The taxonomy of Least Weasel Mustela nivalis was reviewed by Abramov and Baryshnikov (2000), who considered Egpytian Weasel M. subpamata to be a distinct species, a treatment followed here. Tonkin Weasel M. tonkinensis and Sichuan Weasel M. russelliana, here treated as distinct species following Groves (2007), were included as part of M. nivalis by Abramov and Baryshnikov (2000) (and in previous versions of its Red List assessment). A weasel population found in Taiwan in the late 20th century and considered by its finders to be a new species allied to Stoat M. erminea is here considered, following Abramov (2006) to be part of M. nivalis.

This species is known from a single female, described in 1917 and reportedly from the Dry Tortugas islands, Florida, USA (Chamberlin 1917). This species will likely be reevaluated as nomen dubium after an ongoing taxonomic revision is published.

Recently, Schmitter-Soto (2007) described three new species from Amatitlania nigrofasciata. However, mtDNA studies revealed that there may not be enough genetic divergence to warrant this split (Bagley et al. 2016). More studies are necessary to resolve these taxonomy uncertainties.

Python bivittatus was recently recognized as a full species (Jacobs et al. 2009), having previously been considered a subspecies of P. molurus. The subspecies P. b. progschai has been erected to describe populations from Sulawesi (Jacobs et al. 2009).

Antrostomus arizonae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus. Caprimulgus vociferus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously split into C. vociferus and C. arizonae following AOU (2010).

The form lambi was reassigned to Megascops asio from M. cooperi in del Hoyo and Collar (2014), however the claimed sympatry of lambi and M. cooperi (König et al. 2008) is not clear (T.S. Schulenberg in litt. 2019) and lambi is reassigned back to M. cooperi.

Carduelis carduelis and C. caniceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. carduelis following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Christidis & Boles (2008); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Turbott (1990).

Puffinus newelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into P. newelli and P. myrtae (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) found molecular evidence that Newell’s Shearwater Puffinus newelli and Townsend’s Shearwater P. auricularis are conspecific. Although they mention the morphological analysis in del Hoyo and Collar (2014: p386) which gave a Tobias score of 7 to newelli, these authors did not consider the characters in question: larger size (an effect size of 3.29 on tail length yielded a score of 2; new data in Shirihai et al. [2017] yields an effect size of 2.41, thus again a score of 2); cleaner-cut head pattern (score 1); bolder, squarer neck mark (score 2); all-white undertail-coverts (score 2); plus darker upperparts (scored 1 but uncounted).

(These characters and scores are revised below.)

Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) also mentioned that ‘Howell (2012) proposed a separate treatment based on their differences in morphology, breeding chronology (Ainley et al. 1997; Bourne et al. 1988), and breeding ecology (Spear et al. 1995)’ [NB these citations in quotation marks are not in the reference list below]. Thus it appears that there are behavioural and ecological differences between the taxa in addition to the morphological ones. Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) cited the case of Charadrius dealbatus as one in which morphological characters are strong but genetic ones non-existent, but they did not mention that del Hoyo and Collar (2014) accepted the morphological characters despite the genetic evidence. In the present case it seems appropriate to continue to consider that two species are involved, pending confirmation of the authors’ molecular work, clarification of the accuracy of the scoring used to maintain the split of newelli in del Hoyo and Collar (2014), and evidence of the behavioural and ecological differences between the taxa.

            However, Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) also found that P. n. myrtae, ‘Rapa Shearwater’, is genetically more distinct from newelli than newelli is from auricularis. On this basis they propose that myrtae be treated as a full species. Such an arrangement is supported by Shirihai et al. (2017), who noted:

Rapa Shearwater is much smaller (in all biometric characters) than the other two taxa…, and is furthermore highly distinctive in having a unique combination of white undertail-coverts (vs. dark in both newelli and auricularis) and whitish inner webs to the remiges, as well as a white face.

There is a contradiction here with del Hoyo and Collar (2014), where the undertail-coverts of newelli, compared to auricularis, are given as ‘white vs white-edged grey’. Further consideration of this point, by examining images online and Plate 16.1 in Howell (2012: 147), indicate that auricularis has marginally more extensive black undertail-coverts than newelli. However, the information contained in Howell (2012) and the references he cited, plus that conveyed in Howell’s Plate 16.1, lead to somewhat differently scored and parsed characters for newelli vs auricularis:  larger size (effect size 2.41 [see above]: 2);  cleaner-cut and blacker head- and neck-sides (2);  more white on undertail-coverts (1); darker upperparts (1); somewhat different feeding ecology, using less upwelled, more stratified waters with more turbulent meteorological features (Spear et al. 1995; allow 1); breeding chronology (Ainley et al. 1997; no score allowed).

By this means newelli continues to achieve species rank under the Tobias criteria. We therefore retain P. newelli as a separate species from P. auricularis until independent genetic analysis supports Martínez-Gómez et al. (2015) and/or until a new full assessment of morphological characters, and of the behavioural/ecological evidence, can be undertaken.

The taxonomic concept for Bigeye Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus nakamurai) has been revised and the Atlantic Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus vitulus) has now been resurrected to a separate species that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean (Daly-Engel et al. 2019).

Prior to 2018, the literature referred to this species as Squalus mitsukurii or S. cf. mitsukurii. Further, this species is sometimes confused with Squalus cubensis and may be confused with recently described or undescribed species in the South Atlantic (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020). Prior western Atlantic records of Squalus blainville may refer to this species (Kiraly et al. 2003, Pfleger et al. 2018), however eastern records of S. blainville represent a different species (Pfleger et al. 2018). Old records of S. acanthias in the Gulf of Mexico (and its junior synonyms S. fernandinus and S. barbouri) likely refer to this species (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).

This species has been split from Gymnura micra and is morphologically similar but can be distinguished on the basis of internal diagnostic characters such as the contour of the hyomandibula (Yokota and de Carvalho 2017).

authority: Grace, Doosey, Denton, Naylor, Bart & Maisey, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This species is known only from the holotype collected in 2010. It is distinct from Mollisquama parini Dolganov, 1984, the only other member of the genus (Grace et al. 2015, Grace et al. 2019).

Setophaga cerulea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Gelochelidon nilotica and G. macrotarsa (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Sterna and lumped as S. nilotica following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Spatula clypeata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.
Antrostomus carolinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus.
Haemorhous cassinii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carpodacus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Ardenna grisea (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus as P. griseus.
Streptopelia decaocto and S. xanthocycla (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as S. decaocto following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Thalasseus sandvicensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Onychoprion anaethetus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

Motacilla flava and M. tschutschensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. flava following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
The specific name was incorrectly spelt on earlier Red Lists as kempi.
The species blandingii has generally been placed in Emydoidea in recent years, but has also been argued to belong in the genus Emys, based on molecular phylogeny results.
Hydrobates tristrami (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Oceanodroma.
Acanthis flammea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis following Ottvall et al. (2002).

Himantopus himantopus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as H. himantopus, H. leucocephalus and H. mexicanus and following AOU (1998) and SACC (2006). Prior to that, H. melanurus had been split from H. mexicanus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Passerculus henslowii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Ammodramus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Anas platyrhynchos and A. fulvigula (incorporating diazi) (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously treated as A. platyrhynchos (incorporating diazi) and A. fulvigula following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Ardea alba (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Casmerodius as C. albus. Casmerodius albus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously retained as a cross-regional species contra Christidis and Boles (2008) who moved C. albus into the genus Ardea and split it into two cross-regional species A. alba and A. modesta (note gender agreement of specific name for alba).
Ardenna carneipes (del Hoyo et al. 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Sternula albifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Calidris falcinellus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Limicola.
Falco peregrinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as F. peregrinus and F. pelegrinoides following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cuculus saturatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as C. saturatus and C. optatus following Payne (2005). Prior to that, C. lepidus (Payne 2005, del Hoyo and Collar 2014), C. saturatus and C. optatus had been lumped as C. saturatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hydroprogne caspia (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

Passer domesticus and P. italiae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. domesticus following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 and supplements); Christidis and Boles (2008); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); SACC (2005 and updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996); Turbott (1990).

Riparia riparia and R. diluta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. riparia following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.

Larus glaucoides and L. thayeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) have been lumped as L. glaucoides (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018). Chesser et al. (2017) made Thayer’s Gull Larus thayeri a subspecies of Iceland Gull L. glaucoides, with the race L. g. kumlieni retained ‘as a separate group’ although the proposal (http://checklist.aou.org/assets/proposals/PDF/2017-C.pdf) on which the decision on thayeri was based argued that kumlieni is the product of non-assortative mating between the taxa thayeri and glaucoides; see also Ayyash (2017). The close relationship of thayeri and glaucoides is shown without commentary in Figure 8B in Sonsthagen et al. (2016). We accept Larus thayeri as a subspecies of L. glaucoides but treat kumlieni as an apparent hybrid population having no taxonomic status.
Larus argentatus and L. smithsonianus (the latter including vegae and mongolicus) (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as L. argentatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Selasphorus calliope (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Stellula.

Sylvia curruca (AOU [1998 and supplements]; Dowsett and Forbes-Watson [1993]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]), S. minula and S. althaea (Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into S. curruca following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
